3-3-3: MAINTENANCE OF ORDER, REPORT OF VIOLATION:
It shall be the duty of each licensee and of each manager or supervisor at any
time charged with the management and supervision of any retail liquor, retail
table wine or retail malt or brewed licensed premises, while the same are open
to the public, to maintain order upon the premises and to exclude from the
premises any person who is drunk and disorderly or who commits any breach of
the peace, or who uses or engages in offensive, disorderly, threatening,
abusive or insulting language, conduct or behavior with the intent to provoke a
breach of the peace, or whereby a breach of the peace might be occasioned. It
shall be the duty of each officer, licensee, manager, or person-in-charge of
any retail liquor, retail table wine or retail malt or brewed beverage licensed
premises within the city, immediately to make an appropriate report to the
police department of the city of each assault, assault and battery or affray,
occurring on the licensed premises while said premises are open for business.
It shall further be the duty of said person to make a written report of each of
said incidents to the police department of the city and to the local field
office of the ABLE Commission within thirty-six (36) hours thereof. (Ord. 512,
12-11-2018)
3-3-4: OFFENSES IN PUBLIC:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to drink, sell, serve, dispense or
give away, or attempt to drink, sell, serve or give away, any liquor, wine or
malt or brewed beverages, while upon any street, alley, sidewalk, public
easement, right-of-ways, parking lots designed for use by the general public or
in any public building or upon any public property, or while in any other
public place in the city, unless permitted by the City Council under a special
retail liquor or special events license. As used in this section, the term
"public place" shall mean and include any place or gathering which the public
generally attends or is admitted to, either by invitation, common consent or
right or by the payment of any admission or other charge, and without limiting
the generality of the foregoing, shall include public parks, city hall,
library, school buildings, auditoriums, any store or place where amusement and
any high school athletic contest; provided, that such term shall not mean or
include premises which have been duly licensed by the City as provided by this
chapter.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for a business licensed by the City of Wewoka
(whether or not the business is licensed to sell or furnish alcohol) to allow
patrons, customers, invitees or guests to bring alcoholic beverages onto the
licensed premises.
   C.   It shall be unlawful for patrons, customers, invitees or guests to
bring alcoholic beverages onto premises licensed to do business by the City of
Wewoka, whether or not the business is licensed to sell or furnish alcohol.
   D.   It shall be the duty of each licensee to require any person to present
any one or more of the following documents from which his or her name,
residence and age may be ascertained prior to the sale, service, dispensing or
giving away, of any liquor, wine or beer to any person:
      1.   A valid driver license of any state;
      2.   A valid uniform United States service identification (military ID);
      3.   A valid passport; or
      4.   A valid identification card issued by any agency of a state bearing
a photograph and date of birth of the individual presenting such
identification. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-5: MINORS, DRUNKARDS, INSANE PERSONS; OFFENSES BY SELLER OR AGENT:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person or for any employee, servant or
agent of any person to sell, or offer for sale, any liquor, wine or beer to any
person visibly intoxicated, or to any insane person, to any minor, to any
habitual drunkard or person of known intemperate habits.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to serve a minor or allow a minor
to be served any liquor, beer, or wine in any place where such beverages are
sold.
   C.   It shall be unlawful for any person who operates any business or
selling liquor, beer or wine to allow any liquor, beer or wine to be sold to
any minor, or to be consumed by any minor, on the premises where such liquor,
beer or wine is sold. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-6: OFFENSES GENERALLY:
It shall be unlawful to do or perform any of the acts or things designated as
follows:
   A.   For any minor person, directly or indirectly, to purchase any malt or
brewed beverages, any wine or liquor, or any alcoholic or intoxicating
beverage, or to attempt to purchase any of said beverages.
   B.   For any minor person to possess or to consume any malt or brewed
beverages, any wine or liquor, or any alcoholic or intoxicating beverage, or to
attempt to purchase any of said beverages.
   C.   For any person to sell, furnish, give to, or to purchase for any minor
person any malt or brewed beverages, any wine or liquor, or any alcoholic or
intoxicating beverage, or to attempt to sell, furnish, give to or purchase for
any minor person any of said beverages.
   D.   For any person to hire, employ or allow any person less than twenty-one
(21) years of age to serve or dispense alcoholic beverages of any kind.
However, this prohibition does not apply when the only license held by the
licensee is an off-premises beer license or any off-premises table wine license
or combination thereof, and provided there is an adult in attendance at all
times. Provided further that persons who are nineteen (19) years of age or
older and working as a waiter, waitress, or server may serve alcoholic
beverages as provided in the preceding sentence shall be a licensee of the ABLE
Commission who has been annually certified as a responsible vendor under
Article 28A of the Oklahoma Constitution governing the sale and consumption of
alcoholic beverages and pursuant to the provisions of Title 37A Oklahoma
Statutes as amended.
   E.   For any minor person, directly or indirectly, to falsely represent that
such person is not a minor or is not under twenty-one (21) years of age, by
means of which false representation such person buys, receives or otherwise
obtains or attempts to buy, receive or otherwise obtain any malt or brewed
beverages, any wine or liquor or any alcoholic or intoxicating beverages.
   F.   For any person, directly or indirectly, to falsely represent that a
minor person is not a minor or is not twenty-one (21) years of age, by means of
which false representation such person aids or abets or attempts to aid or
abet, such minor person to buy, receive or otherwise obtain any malt or brewed
beverage, any wine or liquor or any alcoholic or intoxicating beverages. (Ord.
512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-7: FALSE REPRESENTATION:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person who is under the age of twenty-one
(21) to knowingly falsely represent by word or act that such person is not
under the age of twenty-one (21) including, without limitation, knowingly
presenting or possessing a false instrument or identification or an instrument
of identification which misrepresents the age of that person.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person, directly or indirectly, to falsely
represent that a minor person is not a minor or is not of minority age under
the state alcoholic beverage licensing code, and, by means of such false
representation, to aid or abet, or attempt to aid or abet, such minor person to
buy, receive or otherwise obtain, or aid and abet such minor person to attempt
to buy, receive, or otherwise obtain, from any licensee or any other person,
any malt or brewed beverage or alcoholic liquor. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-8: HOURS AUTHORIZED:
No alcoholic beverages may be sold, dispensed, served or consumed on the
premises of a mixed beverage, caterer, public event, charitable event, special
event, on premises beer and wine between the hours of two o’clock (2:00) A.M.
and ten o’clock (10:00) A.M. Counties that elect to authorize sales of
alcoholic beverages by the individual drink may designate any or all of the
following days as days or portions thereof on which the sales of alcoholic
beverages are not authorized, to-wit: (1) On Sunday; (2) On Decoration or
Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day.
Counties that elect to authorize sales of alcoholic beverages by the individual
drink shall not prohibit such sales on the day of any national, state, county
or city election, including primary elections, provided that the Election Day
does not occur on any day on which such sales may otherwise be prohibited by
any other law. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-9: REGULATION OF CONDUCT IN LICENSED PREMISES:
It shall be unlawful for any person, club, firm or corporation or the officers,
members, agents, servants or persons in charge thereof at any club, or at any
other place to which the public generally resorts or is admitted, which is a
liquor, wine or beer licensed place, or any combination thereof, to permit,
allow, conduct or condone any of the following:
   A.   Topless or bottomless waitresses, waiters, dancers, servers,
performers, or cashier or any lewd or indecent conduct.
   B.   Acts, or simulated acts, of sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy,
bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual acts which are
prohibited by law.
   C.   Acts, or simulated acts, of caressing or fondling of the breasts,
buttocks, anus or genitals.
   D.   Acts involving the displaying of the anus, vulva or genitals.
   E.   Permitting any patron, customer or member to touch, caress or fondle
the breasts, buttocks, anus or genitals, or any part of the body or clothing of
a performer or entertainer.
   F.   Permitting the showing of films, still pictures, electronic
reproductions or other visual reproductions depicting:
      1.   Acts or simulated acts of sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy,
bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual acts which are
prohibited by law.
      2.   Any person being touched, caressed or fondled on the breasts,
buttocks, anus or genitals.
      3.   Scenes wherein a person displays the vulva or the anus or the
genitals.
      4.   Scenes wherein artificial devices or inanimate objects are employed
to depict, or drawings are employed to portray, any of the prohibited
activities described above in this section.
   G.   Any employee including, but not limited to, waiter, waitress, dancer,
entertainer, performer or model employed upon the licensed premises to sit at
tables with the customers or members and guests while so employed and during
the time that said establishment is open for business.
   H.   The showing of the human male or female genitals, pubic area or
buttocks with less than a fully opaque covering, or the showing of the female
breast with less than a fully opaque covering of any portion thereof below the
top of the darkened area surrounding the nipple, or the depiction of covered
male genitals in a lewd or indecent manner by any waiter, waitress, dancer,
entertainer, employee, model or customer.
   I.   Any person at the time employed or engaged on the licensed premises as
an entertainer or performer, to also serve as a waiter or waitress while so
employed. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-10: ADVERTISING:
It shall be unlawful for any business to display signs of any kind advertising
alcoholic beverages, whether electric, painted, or any other nature, outside
any place of business. There shall be no signs or banners outside the premises
of any retain licensee which advertises a particular manufacturer or brand of
beer except that special events retain licensees shall be permitted to have
such signs and banners which advertise a particular brand of beer, wine, malt
beverage, or liquor. Display of advertising and violation of this section shall
be considered a violation of the ordinance and punishable in accordance
therewith. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-11: RECORDS, REPORTS:
It shall be the duty of each person subject to the license tax imposed by this
chapter to keep full and complete records of all purchases, sales and
deliveries of alcoholic beverages, from which records can be readily obtained
information as to the correct amount of license tax due the City of Wewoka. As
a part of such records, each wholesaler shall keep an individual ledger or card
account for each record, each wholesaler shall keep an individual ledger or
card account for each of his customers, and said ledger or card account shall
show the correct name and address of each person to whom any alcoholic
beverages are delivered, together with the dates thereof and the number of
cases sold or delivered, and each wholesaler shall also keep, as evidence of
the foregoing, a receipted delivery ticket signed by each purchaser or by his
authorized agent. Each retailer shall keep an individual ledger or card record
showing the correct name and address of each person from whom he purchased
alcoholic beverages, a delivery ticket showing each such purchase, the date
thereof and the number of cases purchased. The aforesaid records shall be kept
and posted currently and shall be preserved for not less than three (3) years
succeeding said calendar year. All such records shall be open for inspection
and audit at the licensed premises within the city during such regular business
hours as the City Clerk, or duly authorized representative, may request.
Failure to keep any of the records required by this section, or elsewhere in
this chapter, or any amendment thereto, or refusal to make the same available
to the City Clerk, or duly authorized representative, shall constitute grounds
for revocation of any license issued under this chapter. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-12: PACKAGING OF BEVERAGES:
Retail licenses for off-premises sale of individual or packages of six (6) or
less alcoholic beverages must place each container thereof in a bag, box or
other similar opaque covering prior to the customer's leaving the license
building used for alcoholic beverage sales. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-13: DELIVERY VEHICLES:
A manufacturer or wholesaler shall deliver any alcoholic beverages in vehicles
bearing the required information on each side of the vehicle as required by the
ABLE Commission. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-14: OPEN CONTAINERS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to allow or allow another person to:
   A.   Possess, consume or otherwise use any open container containing
alcoholic beverages while upon or along any public place, street, road or
highway in the city or while in any automobile or other motor vehicle on or
along any public street, road or highway in the city except in the trunk or
luggage compartment of a motor vehicle, or while in any other public place in
the city.
   B.   Possess alcoholic beverages in an open glass, bottle, cup, can, keg,
bag or other receptacle not its original container while upon or along any
public street, road or highway in the city or while on any automobile or other
motor vehicle on or along any public street, road or highway in the city; or
while in any other public place in the city unless permitted by the City
Council by a special events license or special retail license.
   C.   The above notwithstanding this section shall not apply to any person
that has in his or her possession alcoholic beverages in an open container in
the passenger area of a motor vehicle of any kind on a public highway or right-
of-way of a public highway as defined by public law. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-15: DISCRIMINATION PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for an alcoholic beverage licensee of the City of Wewoka
to discriminate against any person with respect to the sale of any food,
beverage, product, cover charge, or admission charge based upon race, color,
creed, or sex. It is specifically provided that no alcoholic beverage licensee
shall have or permit any entertainment, show, or presentation on the licensed
premises to which any person is excluded based upon race, color, creed, or sex.
This section shall apply to the licensee, manager, to any person in charge of
any licensed premises, and to any employee of the licensee authorizing,
permitting, or committing any violation hereof. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-16: CITY OF WEWOKA ALCOHOL LICENSE REVIEW COMMITTEE:
   A.   There is hereby created for the purpose of assisting and advising the
City Council in the review of applications for City licenses and inquiry and
recommendation concerning complaints or disciplinary action of a city licensee,
a Committee to be known and designated as the City of Wewoka Alcohol License
Review Committee to be composed as follows: the City Clerk, or designated
representative; the Chief of Police, or designated representative; the Fire
Chief, or designate representative; the Mayor or designated representative; and
three (3) other members to be appointed by the City Council. The members
appointed by the City Council must be residents of the City of Wewoka, The
terms of office of the members appointed by the City Council shall be staggered
with the first members being appointed for a term of one (1), two (2) and three
(3) years and thereafter each member shall serve a term of three (3) years.
Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term of any member whose term
becomes vacant. Members of the Committee may be removed for cause by the City
Council upon written charges and after a public hearing. The City Clerk, or
designated representative, shall act as liaison to the City Council on behalf
of the Committee. The Committee shall hold meetings as are necessary to
consider appeals by applicants for alcohol licenses, resolve matters of public
concern, or make inquiry into the compliance of a current city licensee with
this chapter and other provisions of this chapter.
   B.   The Committee shall review the information contained within the
application for an alcoholic beverage license and shall submit a written
recommendation to the City Council concerning the approval or disapproval of
the application before the applicant is submitted to the ASBLE Commission.
   C.   The Committee shall investigate complaints, or initiate its own
inquiry, into conditions which may violate provisions of this chapter
concerning the operation of any establishment licensed by the City to conduct
routine business in the sale of alcoholic beverages as allowed by State law.
   D.   The Committee shall have the authority to require the licensee to
produce records for its review as related to the operation, ownership, or
management of the licensed establishment. The Committee shall promulgate
procedures for documenting and investigating complaints concerning the
operation of an alcoholic beverage establishment as well as establishing a
method of documenting violations of this chapter by a licensee or its
employees.
   E.   The Review Committee shall operate under bylaws created and approved by
the City Council. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
ARTICLE II. LICENSE
3-3-20: APPLICABILITY WHEN COUNCIL APPROVAL REQUIRED:
In those instances where the consent and approval of the City Council is
required for an alcoholic beverage license, other than where specified by
statute, the application provisions of this chapter shall apply other than
those contained in Section
3-3-25. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-21: REQUIRED; TRANSFER, SUSPENSION; DISPLAY:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to have in such person's possession
any alcoholic beverages, within the city for the purpose of sale, or to sell,
or keep for sale, or offer for sale, any alcoholic beverage without having
first procured from the City of Wewoka a privilege license and the ABLE
Commission a liquor license therefor. Licenses issued under this chapter may
not be assigned or transferred. The City is hereby authorized to allow the
address for the privileged licensed premises to be changed from one place to
another within the city, as the City may determine appropriate; but shall not
allow the transaction of business at a place for which the license could not
originally have been issued lawfully.
   B.   In the event of a change of ownership of a licensed establishment, the
current licensee shall be required to file a written statement with the City
Clerk indicating this occurrence prior to either completing the sale of the
licensed business, or relinquishing management or financial control of the
business operation, whichever occurs first; and additionally, the party to whom
the licensed establishment is to be sold must file with the City a complete
application city license within twenty (20) days of notification to the City of
the intent to sell, transfer, or assign the establishment. Upon request of the
City Clerk, or designated representative, any applicant may be requested to
produce records of the business or the transaction surrounding the sale of the
business to determine the parties involved or the effective date of the
transaction. These records include, but are not limited to, lease agreements,
land sale agreements, bank statements, stock transfers, minutes of corporate
board meetings, and/or purchase invoices. Any failure to produce the requested
records, or a determination by the City that the transaction is not in
compliance with the requirements specified herein will result in an immediate
forfeiture of the city license upon notification of this determination and an
opportunity for a public hearing by the City Council.
   C.   Licenses issued by the City shall be deemed to expire, terminate, or
otherwise be void when there is a substantial change in ownership in a licensed
establishment, or when a licensed establishment is leased, rented, or
abandoned, or when possession is otherwise surrendered to another party or
parties. Provided, however, that an applicant for a new license at a currently
licensed establishment may be allowed to operate the establishment for a period
not to exceed sixty (60) days if said applicant is in compliance with
subparagraph B. of this section. In such case, the original licensee shall
continue to be responsible for the conduct, operation and city tax liabilities
of the establishment until such time as a license is issued by the City in the
new licensee's name.
   D.   Upon the death of an individual licensee, sale of the licensed
establishment, or temporary closing of the licensed establishment for a period
in excess of thirty (30) days, the city license to sell alcoholic beverages
shall be immediately returned to the City Clerk, or designated representative,
to be held pending the reopening of the business. In the event the temporary
closing is due to any renovation, remodeling, or repair to the licensed
premises, the licensee shall provide written evidence of compliance with
applicable building, fire, and health codes to the City Clerk, or designated
representative, prior to the release of the license.
   E.   For the purposes of this section, and to assist in defining a
substantial change in ownership, the sale or transfer of twenty-five percent
(25%) or more of a corporation's stock shall constitute a substantial change in
ownership of the licensee.
   F.   The City of Wewoka shall have the right to revoke any privilege license
issued by the City for any violation of this chapter or the ABLE Commission's
rules and regulations, after notice and opportunity for a hearing before the
City Council.
   G.   Every privilege license issued by the City to conduct normal and
routine business and license issued by the ABLE Commission shall be
conspicuously and constantly exposed under a transparent substance in an area
visible to the general public on the licensed premises. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-22: APPLICATION FOR LOUNGE, CLUB, RESTAURANT LICENSE; DEPOSIT:
Each applicant seeking the consent and approval of the City Council for lounge
retail liquor license, a club retail liquor license, a restaurant retail liquor
license or other license issued by the ABLE Commission shall make application
to the City Council as required in this chapter. Said application shall be upon
an appropriate form supplied by the City Clerk, or duly authorized
representative, and shall be signed and verified by oath or affirmation by the
licensee, if a natural persons, or in the case of a partnership, association or
unincorporated enterprise, by a partner, limited liability company or managing
member thereof, or in the case of a corporation, by an executive officer
thereof. The applicant shall deposit with the City Clerk the required
application fee that includes the background check with the ABLE Commission and
the amount of publication costs to be incurred hereunder upon filing the
application. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-23: APPLICATION FOR RETAIL LIQUOR LICENSE:
Application for retail liquor license shall be made in accordance with City of
Wewoka Procedures. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-24: REVIEW OF APPLICATION:
   A.   The application shall be submitted to the City Clerk, or designated
representative as required by this chapter.
   B.   In the event of approval by the City Council, the City Clerk, or
designated representative, shall be responsible for ensuring that written
approvals of zoning, building, fire and health, and City Clerk, or designated
representative, are included as part of the application indicating the
satisfactory compliance with the applicable requirements for each respective
department.
   C.   Subsequent to the City Council approval and the applicant's compliance
with this chapter, the City Clerk, or designated representative, is hereby
authorized to indicate, and communicate in writing, the City's approval for the
issuance of a license for the applicant to the ABLE Commission. The method for
the communication of this approval by the City shall be determined based on the
most current mechanisms indicated as acceptable by the ABLE Commission. (Ord.
512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-25: CONSIDERATION OF APPLICATION:
In rendering a decision on each application for a license under this chapter,
the City Council shall consider, among others, the following factors:
   A.   The effects upon residents, real property owners and business within
five hundred (500) feet of the property for which a license is sought.
   B.   The character and reputation of the applicant, each partner, member,
officer, member of board of directors, landlord, bartender and manager
requiring being currently a five (5) year resident of Oklahoma with no felony
conviction.
   C.   The criminal court records of the applicant, each partner, member,
officer and member of the board of directors, landlord, bartender and manager.
   D.   The compliance by applicant, each partner, member, officer, member of
the board of directors, landlord and manager with the laws of the state and
ordinances for the City.
   E.   The recommendation of the City of Wewoka Alcohol License Review
Committee. Any recommendation factor must be grounded in the protection of the
health, safety, and public welfare of the community. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-26: FILING FEE:
There is hereby required, as a filing fee to cover the costs of processing and
investigating each application filed with the City for a city license of any
kind or class, the sum to be set by Wewoka City Council, and the City Clerk or
duly authorized representative shall not accept any application for any such
license not accompanied by said payment to the City along with the payments of
the publication costs, as required in this chapter. The City shall retain a
filing fee to cover the expenses of processing and investigating said
application, whether or not said application results in approval or denial,
provided however, that the filing fee for a special events license application
shall be set by the Wewoka City Council. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-27: CITY ALCOHOL LICENSE FEES:
Each person licensed by the ABLE Commission, who shall engage in the alcoholic
beverage, liquor, beer or wine business within the corporate limits, prior to
engaging in such business shall pay to the City, for the privilege of so
engaging in business, an annual privilege business license fee and further
license fees as established below:
   A.   Beer wholesale license. Each person licensed as a beer wholesaler, etc.
   B.   Wine wholesaler license.
   C.   Beer and wine wholesaler license.
   D.   Warehouse license.
   E.   Club retail liquor license.
   F.   Hotel/motel lounge retail liquor license.
   G.   Lounge retail liquor license.
   H.   Retail liquor, wine and beer license for off-premises consumption
(package store).
   I.   Restaurant retail liquor license.
   J.   Retail table wine license for off-premises consumption.
   K.   Retail table wine license for on-premises and off-premises consumption.
   L.   Retail beer for on-premises and off-premises consumption.
   M.   Retail beer for off-premises consumption.
   N.   Special retail liquor license for on-premises consumption.
   O.   Special events retail license for on-premises consumption.
   P.   Manufacturer license.
   Q.   Importer license.
   R.   Liquor wholesale license.
   S.   Brewpub license. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-28: REPORTS OF BUSINESS DONE AND TAX DUE:
The person liable for any license tax or other tax imposed by this chapter
shall file with the City Clerk or duly authorized representative, on or before
the final date on which the tax may be paid without a penalty, such report or
reports in such form as the City Clerk or duly authorized representative, may
prescribe, evidencing the amount of business done and the amount of license tax
or other tax due thereon, together with full payment for any tax liability. Any
failure to comply with this section shall be declared unlawful and be
punishable as such. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-29: RESERVED:
(Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
ARTICLE III: VIOLATIONS; PUNISHMENTS; GENERAL PROVISIONS
3-3-35: VIOLATIONS DECLARED MISDEMEANOR:
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor and unless otherwise provided herein, shall, upon conviction or
adjudication of guilt, be punished by paying a fine not to exceed five hundred
dollars ($500.00) or to be incarcerated in the County jail for a period not to
exceed thirty (30) days or by both such fine and incarceration. (Ord. 512, 12-
11-2018)
3-3-36: APPLICATION OF MUNICIPAL CODE AND ORDINANCES:
Ordinances of the City of Wewoka, Oklahoma, shall apply in all respects to any
violations of this chapter. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-37: SEVERABILITY:
The provisions of this chapter are severable so that if any provision hereof is
declared unconstitutional, void, or invalid by a court of competent
jurisdiction, all other provisions hereof shall not be affected by such
declaration and shall remain in full force and effect as though the
unconstitutional, void or invalid provision had not been included in the
chapter as originally adopted. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-38: CONFLICTS WITH STATE STATUTES:
This chapter shall be deemed cumulative with and supplemental to any and all
statutes of the State of Oklahoma regarding the subject matter hereof and to be
subordinate to same and in no manner intended to supersede any such statutes of
the State Of Oklahoma. Any provision hereof in conflict with any provision of
any State statue shall be construed so as to be in harmony with the same where
possible and otherwise to be subordinate to and superseded by the provisions of
such State statute. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-3-39: EFFECTIVE DATE:
This chapter shall become effective immediately in the entire City of Wewoka
upon certification by the City Clerk that the legalized sale of alcoholic
beverages in the city has been authorized pursuant to provisions of the laws of
the State of Oklahoma. (Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
ARTICLE A. ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES
(Rep. by Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
ARTICLE B. LOW POINT BEER
(Rep. by Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
CHAPTER 4
SPECIAL EVENTS
SECTION:
3-4-1: General Requirements And Restrictions
3-4-2: License Required; Fee
3-4-1: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS AND RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   License Issuance Authorized: A special event license may be issued by
the city clerk to a nonprofit organization, association, or corporation
organized for political, fraternal, charitable, religious or social purposes.
   B.   Location Restriction: If the location for which the license is sought
is not within a residential district as described in the Wewoka zoning
ordinance, the holder of a special event license is authorized to sell and
distribute intoxicating beverages and low point beer for consumption on the
premises for which the license is issued.
   C.   Licensing Restrictions:
      1.   No special event license may be issued to any applicant already
licensed pursuant to chapter 3.
      2.   No organization may obtain more than one such license within a one
hundred fifty (150) day period.
   D.   Term Of License: A special event license shall be valid for period not
to exceed ten (10) days.
   E.   Licensee Performance Agreement; Bond:
      1.   No license shall be issued hereunder until the applicant shall have
executed an agreement to provide, at the applicant's cost, security for crowd
control, toilet facilities, labor to remove all trash and refuse from the
licensed site on each day for which the license is issued, and provide any
necessary utility services.
      2.   An applicant for such license shall also provide a bond to the city
in the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00) to ensure payment of all such
costs. (Ord. 444, 6-11-2002; amd. 2005 Code; Ord. 512, 12-11-2018)
3-4-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE:
   A.   License Required: No person shall operate a special event without first
obtaining a license from the city clerk. (Ord. 444, 6-11-2002; amd. 2005 Code)
   B.   License Fee: Persons required to obtain a license pursuant to the
provisions of this chapter shall pay a fee to the city in the amount of two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). (Ord. 444, 6-11-2002)
CHAPTER 5
FOOD AND DRINK
ARTICLE A. FOOD AND RESTAURANTS
SECTION:
3-5A-1: Food Service Code Adopted
3-5A-2: Health Authority Defined
3-5A-3: Permit Required; Conditions
3-5A-4: Application For Permit; Inspection; Fee
3-5A-5: Food Handlers' School
3-5A-6: Noncompliance; Suspension Of Permit
3-5A-7: Penalty
3-5A-1: FOOD SERVICE CODE ADOPTED:
   A.   Adoption Of Code: The unabridged form of the latest edition of the
"United States Public Health Service Food Service Sanitation Ordinance And
Code" is hereby adopted and incorporated in this code by reference. Three (3)
copies of the sanitation ordinance and code shall be on file in the office of
the city clerk. The sanitation ordinance and code shall govern the definitions;
inspection of food service establishments; the issuance, suspension, and
revocation of permits to operate food service establishments; the prohibiting
of the sale of adulterated or misbranded food or drink and the enforcement of
this section. In the sanitation ordinance and code, however, all parenthetical
phrases referring to grading and the following subsections shall be understood
to be deleted: subsections H.2.e., H.7. and H.8.
   B.   Health Authority Defined: "Health authority" means the director of the
county health department of this county or his designated representative.
   C.   Violation; Penalty: Any person who violates any of the provisions of
this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof,
shall be punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. In addition thereto, any person convicted of a violation
may be enjoined from continuing the violation. (1983 Code § 8-201)
3-5A-2: HEALTH AUTHORITY DEFINED:
"Health authority" means the state sanitarian assigned to the county, and
representing the city as a designated representative of the state health
officer. (1983 Code § 8-203)
3-5A-3: PERMIT REQUIRED; CONDITIONS:
   A.   Permit Required; Issuing Agency: It is unlawful for any person to
operate a food service establishment within the city or its police
jurisdiction, who does not possess a valid permit issued to him through the
health authority. (1983 Code § 8-202; amd. 2005 Code)
   B.   Compliance Required: Only a person who complies with the requirements
of this article shall be entitled to receive and retain such a permit.
   C.   Permit Nontransferable: Permits shall not be transferable from one
person to another person or place.
   D.   Posting Of Permit: A valid permit shall be posted in every food service
establishment.
   E.   Temporary Food Service Establishments: Permits for temporary food
service establishments shall be issued for a period of time not to exceed
fourteen (14) days. (1983 Code § 8-202)
3-5A-4: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; INSPECTION; FEE:
   A.   Contents Of Application: Any person desiring to operate a food service
establishment shall make written application for a permit on forms provided by
the health authority. The application shall include:
      1.   The applicant's full name and post office address and whether the
applicant is an individual, firm or corporation and, if a partnership, the
names of the partners, together with their addresses, shall be included;
      2.   The location and type of the proposed food service establishment;
and
      3.   The inclusive dates of the proposed operation.
   B.   Inspection; Permit Issuance:
      1.   Upon receipt of such an application, the health authority shall make
an inspection of the food service establishment to determine compliance with
the provisions of this article. (1983 Code § 8-205)
      2.   When inspection reveals that the applicable requirements of this
article have been met, a permit shall be issued to the applicant upon receipt
of application from the health authority. (1983 Code § 8-205; amd. 2005 Code)
   C.   Fee; Term; Issuance:
      1.   For each food or drink establishment as listed in this article, the
annual fee is five dollars ($5.00). All permits expire on June 30 of each year;
      2.   Permits will be issued upon receipt of application from the health
authority, to educational institutions, hospitals, nursing homes, daycare
centers, civic clubs, church groups and other eleemosynary organizations
without a permit fee. (1983 Code § 8-205)
3-5A-5: FOOD HANDLERS' SCHOOL:
   A.   Attendance Required; Cards Issued:
      1.   Mandatory attendance is required of food handlers at the food
handlers' school offered trimonthly by the county sanitarian located in the
Wewoka office.
      2.   Food handlers' cards will be issued and are good for one year, after
which renewal is obtained by attending the school again.
      3.   New employees will be required to attend the first school held after
their employment.
      4.   Food handlers' cards must be displayed with the establishment
license in a conspicuous place. Failure to comply with this subsection makes
the establishment subject to suspension of license.
   B.   Food Handlers' Permit Fee: There shall be no charge made for the food
handlers' school. Upon completion of such school, each food handler in
attendance shall be issued a food handlers' permit for a fee of fifty cents
($0.50) for each permit issued. The food handlers' permit shall be valid for
one year from date of issuance. (1983 Code § 8-204)
3-5A-6: NONCOMPLIANCE; SUSPENSION OF PERMIT:
   A.   Temporary Suspension: Permits may be suspended temporarily by the
health authority for failure of the holder to comply with the requirements of
this article.
   B.   Notice; Hearing: Whenever a permit holder or operator has failed to
comply with any notice issued under the enforcement provisions of this article,
the permit holder or operator shall be notified in writing that the permit is,
upon service of the notice, immediately suspended (or the establishment
downgraded), and that an opportunity for a hearing will be provided if a
written request for a hearing is filed with the health authority by the permit
holder.
   C.   Health Hazard; Order Discontinuance Of Permit: Notwithstanding the
other provisions of this article, whenever the health authority finds
insanitary or other conditions in the operation of a food service establishment
which, in his judgment, constitute a substantial hazard to the public health,
he may without warning, notice or hearing, issue a written notice to the permit
holder or operator citing such condition, specifying the period within which
such action shall be taken; and, if deemed necessary, such order shall state
that the permit is immediately discontinued. Any person to whom such an order
is issued shall comply immediately therewith, but upon written petition to the
health authority, shall be afforded a hearing as soon as possible. (1983 Code §
8-205)
3-5A-7: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this article or any
legal order or regulation of the health officer shall, upon conviction thereof,
be punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1983 Code § 8-206)
ARTICLE B. MILK REGULATIONS
SECTION:
3-5B-1: Regulations Adopted
3-5B-2: Enforcement
3-5B-3: Grade A Milk
3-5B-4: Penalty
3-5B-1: REGULATIONS ADOPTED:
The provisions of state law governing the sale, labeling, and certain standards
for milk or milk products as set out in 2 Oklahoma Statutes section 7-401 et
seq., are hereby incorporated by reference in this code and are enforceable by
the city and its designated officials as fully as if they were set out at
length herein. (1983 Code § 8-210; amd. 2005 Code)
3-5B-2: ENFORCEMENT:
All sampling, examining, grading and regrading of milk and milk products, all
inspections and issuing and suspension or revocation of permits shall be done
by the director of the county health department or his authorized
representative, who shall be a registered professional sanitarian, or the
county superintendent of health if there is no county health department. (1983
Code § 8-212)
3-5B-3: GRADE A MILK:
From and after thirty (30) days after June 11, 1974, only grade A pasteurized
milk and milk products shall be sold to the final consumer, or to restaurants,
soda fountains, grocery stores, or similar establishments. In an emergency, the
sale of pasteurized milk and milk products which have not been graded, or the
grade of which is unknown, may be authorized by the health authority; in which
case, such milk and milk products shall be labeled "ungraded". (1983 Code § 8-
211)
3-5B-4: PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined or
imprisoned as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1983 Code § 8-213)
CHAPTER 6
AMUSEMENT PLACES, SHOWS AND DEVICES
SECTION:
3-6-1: Coin Operated Music Devices
3-6-2: Vending Machines And Amusement Devices
3-6-3: Amusement Shows; License Required, Fees
3-6-4: Parades; Permit Required, Fee
3-6-5: Places Of Amusement; Public View
3-6-6: Skating Rinks Or Pavilions
3-6-7: Penalty
3-6-1: COIN OPERATED MUSIC DEVICES:
   A.   License Fees:
      1.   It is unlawful to operate, maintain or install any coin controlled
phonograph, music box or other coin controlled musical instrument within the
city unless the person in charge of operating the machine shall have first paid
to the city clerk an annual license fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for each
device. (1983 Code § 9-101)
      2.   In addition to the tax levied in subsection A1 of this section, any
person or business who shall rent, loan, or lease the same shall pay a license
fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per year, payable annually in advance on
July 1 of each year. (1983 Code § 9-101; amd. 2005 Code)
   B.   Enforcement:
      1.   The police department or other designee of the city administrator
shall have the power each month, as soon after the first day of each month as
possible, to inspect each coin operated music machine for which a license has
been issued by the city clerk.
      2.   The inspecting official shall make a report which shall be submitted
to the city administrator, which report shall contain a list of the locations
of any of the machines which are so situated as to constitute a public
nuisance. In the event that any machine is so situated as to constitute a
hazard to the public or a public nuisance, the city clerk shall notify the
licensee and the licensee shall be required to move the machine to a location
which meets the approval of the police department or designee of the city
administrator. Failure to comply with the above requirements shall be grounds
for revocation of the license. (1983 Code § 9-102)
3-6-2: VENDING MACHINES AND AMUSEMENT DEVICES:
   A.   License Required; Fees; Regulations:
      1.   It is unlawful to operate, maintain, or install any vending machine,
or automatic sales machine, which machine stores merchandise or other
commodities and delivers a definite amount of merchandise, or any device
commonly known as a video game, or other amusement game, which is operated by
the insertion of a coin, unless the person in charge of operating the machine
shall have first paid to the city treasurer a license fee therefor, and
received from the city clerk a license as provided by this section.
      2.   Any applicant may be refused a license, or any license may be
revoked, for any violation by the applicant, or his employees, of any of the
provisions of this section.
      3.   The license tax on each machine shall be the sum of twenty five
dollars ($25.00) per annum. (1983 Code § 9-103)
      4.   Nothing in this section shall apply to any machine used exclusively
for vending postage stamps; machines owned by and located in a public or
private school, a church, or a governmental entity; and devices which dispense
only newspapers or periodicals. Nothing in this section shall authorize the
operation of any vending machine which is prohibited by state law, or by any
other provision of the city ordinances. (1983 Code § 9-103; amd. 2005 Code)
      5.   It is unlawful and an offense for any licensee hereunder to permit
any violation of any of the ordinances of the city, or the laws of the state
relating to gambling on the premises of the licensee. No licensee shall permit
persons who have congregated on the premises of the licensee to use violent,
abusive, vile or profane language, or make unnecessary noise so as to annoy the
people residing, or carrying on business, in the immediate neighborhood of the
licensee, or to disturb the peace.
      6.   For the purpose of this section, the taxable year shall begin on May
1 and end on the following April 30. The city clerk shall in each instance
issue a license for the remainder of the taxable year upon the payment of the
tax regardless of the remaining time in the taxable year. (1983 Code § 9-103)
   B.   Location Of Machines: None of the amusement devices or machines
licensed under this section shall be allowed to be placed or operated at any
point within six hundred feet (600') of the property line of any of the city
schools. (1983 Code § 9-104)
3-6-3: AMUSEMENT SHOWS; LICENSE REQUIRED, FEES:
   A.   License Required: It is unlawful and an offense for any person, firm,
corporation or association to conduct, operate or exhibit any show as defined
in subsection B of this section, unless he shall have first procured a license
and paid all license fees.
   B.   Fees Enumerated: Any person, firm, association or corporation operating
a show or circus or carnival shall pay a license fee as follows:
      1.   Circus: For any circus exhibiting or to exhibit in the city, fifty
dollars ($50.00) per day;
      2.   Carnival: For any carnival and street show held or to be held in the
city, two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per week; and
      3.   Tent Show Or Gathering: For any tent show or gathering of every kind
given in a tent or in the open air in the city not otherwise provided for in
this section, twenty dollars ($20.00) per day. This subsection B3 shall include
religious gatherings or revivals.
   C.   Waiver Of Fees: The fees herein fixed are waived when the show,
carnival, circus, or public entertainment is conducted by any board or
association created by the statutes of the state or the charter of the city
upon condition that the profits received from the entertainment shall be
retained by the board or association and used by it in furtherance of its
objectives. (1983 Code § 9-105)
3-6-4: PARADES; PERMIT REQUIRED, FEE:
   A.   Permit Required: It is unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or
organization to engage in a parade on the city streets without obtaining from
the city a parade permit and making payment in full of all fees.
   B.   Application For Permit; Denial:
      1.   Application for a parade permit shall be made forty eight (48) hours
prior to the parade.
      2.   The city reserves the right to deny any application when it is
determined to be for the health, safety and welfare of the community. The
applicant may appeal a denial to the city council.
   C.   Fee; Waiver:
      1.   Fee for one parade shall be twenty dollars ($20.00) paid to the city
treasurer, before a permit may be issued.
      2.   The city council may waive the fee, if it determines that the parade
is for the betterment of the public, or for a recognized civic organization.
(1983 Code § 9-106)
3-6-5: PLACES OF AMUSEMENT; PUBLIC VIEW:
   A.   Definitions: For the purpose of this section, the following terms shall
have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this subsection:
    BILLIARD HALL: Any place where people congregate and where billiards, pool,
snooker or any similar game is played and the game is permitted or operated for
a commercial purpose.
   DOMINO PARLOR: Any place where people congregate and where the game of
dominoes, hearts, moon or any similar game is played and the game is permitted
or operated for commercial purpose.
   PUBLIC DANCE HALL: Any place where the public is permitted to congregate and
dance.
   TAVERN: Any place where people congregate where beer and soft drinks are
sold for a commercial purpose.
   B.   Obstructing Public View Prohibited: It is unlawful for any person
within the city operating or hereafter to operate a billiard hall, domino
parlor, tavern, or public dance hall to erect or cause to be erected any
obstruction preventing the public to view from the street or alley; or to place
any curtain or screen over the openings, doors or windows to obstruct the
public view; or to paint, whitewash or otherwise cover the openings, doors, or
windows, to a height greater than four and one-half feet (41/2') from the floor
of the room or building where such businesses, as herein defined, are operated
or conducted. (1983 Code § 9-501)
   C.   Violation; Penalty:
      1.   Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be
deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished
as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code.
      2.   If such obstructions, screens, blinds, paint or other obstructions
are not removed within five (5) days after the institution of a prosecution
therefor, the continuance of such obstructions shall be deemed a second
offense. (1983 Code § 9-502)
3-6-6: SKATING RINKS OR PAVILIONS:
   A.   Definition: A "skating pavilion" or "skating rink", as herein used,
means and includes any and all persons, firms, corporations, and associations
who shall buy or construct or have under their management and control a floor
or place in which to skate and who shall charge on admission to skate upon the
floor or place.
   B.   License Required; Payment Of Fee: It is unlawful to operate and
maintain a skating rink, or skating pavilion, unless the person in charge of
the skating pavilion or skating rink shall first pay to the city treasurer a
license tax therefor, and receive from the city clerk a license. Any person, or
applicant, may be refused a license, or any license may be revoked for any
violation by the applicant, or his employees, of any of the provisions of this
section.
   C.   Fee Established: There is hereby levied upon each skating pavilion or
skating rink a municipal license fee in the sum of twenty five dollars ($25.00)
per month, payable in advance.
   D.   Compliance With State And Local Regulations: Nothing in this section
shall authorize the operation of any skating pavilion or skating rink which is
prohibited by state law, or by any other provision of this code. (1983 Code §
9-503)
3-6-7: PENALTY:
Any person, firm, association or corporation, or agent thereof, violating any
of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and,
upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1983 Code §§ 9-107, 9-504)
CHAPTER 7
PAWNBROKERS AND SECONDHAND DEALERS
SECTION:
3-7-1: Definition
3-7-2: License Required
3-7-3: Bond Requirements
3-7-4: Register Of Transactions
3-7-5: Certain Purchases Prohibited
3-7-6: Revocation Of License
3-7-7: Penalty
3-7-8: Secondhand Dealers
3-7-1: DEFINITION:
For the purpose of this chapter, a "pawnbroker" means any person who loans
money in the City on deposit of personal property, or who deals in the purchase
of personal property on condition of selling the same back again at a
stipulated price, or who makes a public display at his place of business of the
sign generally used by pawnbrokers. (1983 Code § 9-201)
3-7-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
   A.   License Required: No person shall carry on or engage in business as a
pawnbroker in the City without having first obtained a license therefor from
the City. The license shall conform to those now provided for, or that may be
hereafter provided for, by this chapter. (1983 Code § 9-202)
   B.   License For Each Place Of Business: A license shall be and is hereby
required of every pawnbroker for each and every place where such business is
transacted and it is unlawful for anyone to act as agent or solicit for any
pawnbroker while such pawnbroker is engaged in such business at a place other
than that specified in the license. (1983 Code § 9-208)
3-7-3: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Bond Required: Every person applying for a license to engage in or
carry on a business of pawnbroker shall, before such license is issued, enter
into bond to the City with some surety company licensed to do business in the
State, in the sum of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) conditioned that:
      1.   The applicant will strictly and faithfully observe all ordinances,
regulations, and requirements of the City in relation to pawnbrokers, or their
business, and will pay all costs, fines and penalties incurred on account of
his failure or neglect in that behalf; and
      2.   The applicant will pay for all damages resulting to any person by
reason of his wrongfully purchasing, taking or receiving in pledge, or on
deposit, any stolen property, or the property of any minor.
   B.   Approval; Liability: Said bond shall be approved by the City Council
and filed with the City Clerk. The bond may be sued upon by any person damaged
as aforesaid in the name of the City to the use of such person, but in no event
shall the City be liable for any costs in such suit. (1983 Code § 9-203)
3-7-4: REGISTER OF TRANSACTIONS:
   A.   Register Required; Exception:
      1.   Every pawnbroker shall keep at his place of business a register in
which he shall enter in writing a minute description of all property taken,
purchased or received. The register shall include any and all numbers that may
be in or upon any article, together with the name, address and license number
of the pawnbroker; the name, address, weight, height and date of birth of the
person leaving the property; and either identification number of the seller as
verified by either a State issued identification card, driver's license or
Federal government issued identification card, or by readable fingerprint of
right or left index finger on the back of the pawn or buy transaction copy to
be retained for the pawnbroker's record. In addition, the register shall
reflect the date and time of the transaction, the amount of any sum lent to the
borrower and the due date thereof.
      2.   The register shall be kept clean and legible. Every entry shall be
made in ink, and shall not in any manner be erased, obliterated or defaced.
      3.   It is the duty of every pawnbroker to make out and deliver to the
Chief of Police, within three (3) days, a legible and correct copy from the
register of all personal property or other valuable things received or
deposited or purchased, together with the time when received or purchased and
the description of the person or persons by whom left in pledge, or from whom
the same were purchased.
      4.   No person shall be required to furnish such description of any
property purchased from manufacturers or wholesale dealers having an
established place of business, or of any goods purchased at open sale from any
bankrupt stock, but such goods must be accompanied by a bill of sale or other
evidence of open and legitimate purchase, and must be shown to any member of
the Police Department when demanded. (1983 Code § 9-204)
   B.   Register Open For Inspection:
      1.   The register shall at all times be kept open to the inspection of
the Chief of Police, and the Sheriff of the County, or his Deputy, or any other
officer of the police force of the City, the City Attorney, the District
Attorney, and anyone authorized in writing for that purpose by the Chief of
Police, which authority shall be exhibited to the pawnbroker.
      2.   The pawnbroker shall also, upon request, show and exhibit to any
such person or officer, for inspection, any article or articles purchased,
taken or received by him. (1983 Code § 9-205)
   C.   Record Of All Purchases Of Property: Every pawnbroker shall, on the
absolute purchase of any personal property, enter the same in the register
required by subsection A of this section in the same manner as property
received on pledge. Such property shall be exhibited to inspection of the
officers and persons, and to the same extent as goods received on pledge. (1983
Code § 9-206)
3-7-5: CERTAIN PURCHASES PROHIBITED:
No pawnbroker shall purchase, take or receive any pledge or deposit, any
article of property of or from a minor, or any stolen property, or property
which from any cause he may have reason to believe or suspect cannot be
lawfully or rightfully sold, pawned or pledged by the person offering it. (1983
Code § 9-207)
3-7-6: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
If any pawnbroker or his agent, servants or employees shall violate any of the
provisions in this chapter, or any of the Statutes of the State, and be finally
convicted in any court in the City or State, or in the Municipal Court of the
City, or become a person of bad moral character in the conduct of pawnbroker's
business, it shall be sufficient to authorize the City Administrator or City
Clerk to revoke his license, and sufficient grounds for refusal to issue a new
license. (1983 Code § 9-209)
3-7-7: PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate, fail, neglect or refuse to comply with any of the
provisions, regulations or requirements of this chapter, or who shall fail to
procure a license, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction
thereof, be punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1983 Code § 9-210)
3-7-8: SECONDHAND DEALERS:
   A.   Definition:
    SECONDHAND DEALERS: Any person operating a business in the City, who
purchases and/or sells goods of any kind or description having once been used
or transferred from the manufacturer to the dealer and then received into the
possession of third parties whether the same consists of iron or other metals,
electronics, firearms, jewelry, tools, lawn equipment items with vehicle
identification numbers or serial numbers, or items made in whole or part of
gold, silver, or precious metals or gemstones including bullion or coins shall
be a secondhand dealer.
   B.   False Identification: Any person selling property to a secondhand
dealer who uses false or altered identification or a false declaration of
ownership as related to the provision of this title shall, if the value of the
property is less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) be guilty of a
misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished as provided in this Code.
   C.   Stolen Goods: Any person who fails to repay a secondhand dealer the
full amount received from a buy transaction after being officially notified by
a peace officer that the goods he sold in that transaction were stolen or
embezzled shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be
punished as provided in this Code. (Ord. 510, 8-14-2018)
CHAPTER 8
PEDDLERS, HAWKERS AND SOLICITORS
SECTION:
3-8-1: License Required; Exceptions; Fee
3-8-2: Bond Required
3-8-3: City Clerk As Agent Of Applicant
3-8-4: Orders Taken In Writing; Copy To Clerk
3-8-5: Private Residences; Invitation Required
3-8-6: Penalty
3-8-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS; FEE:
   A.   License Required; Exceptions:
      1.   No person, group of persons, company or organization, private or
governmental, shall engage in the business of hawking or other peddling or
soliciting in the streets or other public places, or from door to door, or in
the selling of any type or class of telephone, article of trade or commerce
whatsoever from any street, automobile, cart, wagon, pack, basket or in any
other manner, in the City without first having obtained a license therefor.
      2.   However, nothing herein shall prohibit any person selling the
product from his own farm or garden, grown by such person, or any school,
church, civic group or nonprofit organization from hawking, peddling or
soliciting without a license.
   B.   License Fee: A license shall be issued by the City Clerk upon
application and the rates therefor shall be as follows: twenty five dollars
($25.00) per day or five hundred dollars ($500.00) per year.
   C.   Fee Paid In Advance; Renewal: All such license fees herein provided
shall be paid in advance, and if any such licensee desires to continue in
business after expiration of such license, a new license shall be secured in
the same manner and on the same terms as the original license. (Ord. 503, 7-11-
2017)
3-8-2: BOND REQUIRED:
Before issuing such license, the City Clerk shall require such applicant to
furnish and deposit with the City Clerk a bond in the penal sum of one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00), executed by a surety company, which bond shall be first
approved by the City Clerk and shall be conditioned that all items of trade or
commerce, cell phones, packed, peddled, hawked or any other article of trade or
commerce for the purpose of indemnifying and reimbursing any person dealing
with such hawker or peddler in the event of defective merchandise or orders
taken for merchandise which are not as represented. The bond shall also be
conditioned for the further purpose of ensuring that the peddler or hawker will
refund any money or purchase price paid for items of trade or commerce, which
are not as represented, by reason of any person purchasing such item of trade
or commerce through misrepresentation as to the kind, character and nature of
such items of trade or commerce. Any person so misled or aggrieved by the
representation of the licensee hereunder, shall have a right of action on the
bond for the recovery of the amount of his or her payment or damages suffered,
or both. (Ord. 503, 7-11-2017)
3-8-3: CITY CLERK AS AGENT OF APPLICANT:
The City Clerk shall require and file an instrument signed by the applicant for
such license, which instrument nominates and appoints the City Clerk as his
true and lawful agent for the service of process for and on behalf of the
applicant, and service of summons in any action brought upon the bond shall be
deemed made with service upon the City Clerk. (Ord. 503, 7-11-2017)
3-8-4: ORDERS TAKEN IN WRITING; COPY TO CLERK:
All orders taken by any licensee under the provisions of this chapter shall be
in writing, stating the terms fully together with the amount paid in advance,
and the balance remaining due, and one copy of such order shall be delivered to
the purchaser at the time the order is taken. One copy of such order shall be
delivered to the City Clerk within twenty four (24) hours after the taking of
such order. (Ord. 503, 7-11-2017)
3-8-5: PRIVATE RESIDENCES; INVITATION REQUIRED:
The practice of going in and upon private residences in the City by solicitors,
peddlers, itinerant merchants, itinerant vendors and sellers of cell phones,
trade or commerce, without having been requested or invited to do so by the
owners or occupants of such private residences for the purpose of soliciting
orders for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise, cell phones, or for the
purpose of disposing of or peddling or hawking the same is hereby declared to
be a nuisance and punishable as a misdemeanor. However, nothing contained
herein shall prohibit any person from selling products from his own farm or
garden grown by that person. (Ord. 503, 7-11-2017)
3-8-6: PENALTY:
Any person, firm, corporation or association who shall violate any of the
provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined as provided
in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 503, 7-11-2017)
CHAPTER 9
CLOSING OUT SALES
SECTION:
3-9-1: Definitions
3-9-2: License Required; Fee
3-9-3: Application For License
3-9-4: False Statements
3-9-5: Inapplicable To Judicial Sales
3-9-6: Penalty
3-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings
respectively ascribed to them in this chapter:
DISTRESSED GOODS, WARES OR MERCHANDISE: All goods, wares and merchandise
advertised as an insurance, bankruptcy, mortgage, insolvent, assignee's,
executor's, administrator's, creditor's, receiver's or trustee's sale of goods,
wares and merchandise; or a sale of goods, wares and merchandise advertised as
damaged by fire, smoke, water or otherwise; or a sale of goods, wares and
merchandise advertised as obtained by, through, as the result of, or by reason
of, any of the above mentioned situations or contingents.
PERSON: Any person, firm or corporation in the city. The manager of any firm or
corporation shall be deemed responsible for the obtaining of such license as
well as such person, firm or corporation. (1983 Code § 9-402)
3-9-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE:
   A.   License Required: No person shall advertise, represent or hold out that
any sale of goods, wares or merchandise is a sale of distressed goods, wares,
or merchandise removal or closing out sale in the city unless he shall have
first obtained a license to conduct such sale from the city clerk and
treasurer. (1983 Code § 9-401)
   B.   License Fee: There is hereby levied a fee of twenty five dollars
($25.00) on each sale. Each license shall be issued for a period of time of
sixty (60) days only, unless an extension is applied for as hereinafter
provided. The above amount shall be paid to the city clerk and treasurer before
he shall issue any license. (1983 Code § 9-403)
3-9-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
   A.   Contents Of Application; Supplemental Licenses: Each application for
license hereunder shall specify the period of time during which the sale may
continue. This time shall not exceed sixty (60) days, but if at any time during
sixty (60) days, a sworn application is filed with the city clerk making it
appear that all goods, wares and merchandise have not been sold, accompanied by
an inventory of what remains, a supplemental license shall be issued by the
city clerk and treasurer upon compliance by the applicant with the requirements
of the original license and upon the payment of an additional license fee of
two dollars ($2.00) per day, which license shall continue in effect only as
long as the daily license fee shall be paid and the licensee shall comply with
the provisions hereof.
   B.   Application For Renewal: Any application for a license covering any
goods, wares or merchandise previously inventoried or licensed shall be deemed
to be an application for a renewal under this section, whether presented by the
original applicant or by any other person.
   C.   Filing Application; Date Of Granting Or Refusal: The clerk shall file
such application and shall endorse on each application the date a license is
granted or refused. (1983 Code § 9-404)
3-9-4: FALSE STATEMENTS:
It is unlawful and an offense to make false statements in any such application.
(1983 Code § 9-405)
3-9-5: INAPPLICABLE TO JUDICIAL SALES:
The provisions hereof shall not apply to public or court officers or to any
person acting under the direction of state or federal courts in the course of
their official duties. (1983 Code § 9-406)
3-9-6: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation, either for himself or as agent, servant, or
employee, who shall violate any provision of this chapter or who shall be
engaged in conducting any sale which shall be in violation of any provision
thereof, upon conviction thereof, shall be deemed guilty of an offense and
punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1983 Code § 9-407)
CHAPTER 10
GARAGE AND YARD SALES
SECTION:
3-10-1: Permit Required; Exceptions; Fee
3-10-2: Permit Requirements
3-10-3: Signs
3-10-1: PERMIT REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS; FEE:
   A.   Permit Required: No person shall conduct or permit a garage sale, patio
sale, porch or yard sale, or other similar sales upon the grounds of or within
any dwelling or premises located within the city limits without having
previously obtained a permit for such sale from the city clerk.
   B.   Exceptions: The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to or affect
the following:
      1.   Persons acting pursuant to an order or process of a court of
competent jurisdiction;
      2.   Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public
officials;
      3.   Persons duly licensed as auctioneers selling at auctions; or
      4.   Persons acting in a charitable or nonprofit capacity. (1983 Code §
9-701)
   C.   Fee: The fee for garage, patio, yard or porch sale permits is five
dollars ($5.00) per permit. (1983 Code § 9-702)
3-10-2: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
The permit required for the garage or similar sale shall:
   A.   Contain the location of such sale, the name of the person holding the
sale, the dates of the sale, and a signed statement by the applicant that the
goods to be sold have not been purchased for resale;
   B.   Be valid for a period not to exceed three (3) consecutive days in
length;
   C.   Not be issued more than twice to the same applicant during a calendar
year; and
   D.   Not be issued where the sale location has been subject to two (2)
previous sales during the calendar year. (1983 Code § 9-703)
3-10-3: SIGNS:
Such sale may be advertised by the use of three (3) temporary signs placed in
the general sale location, and all such signs shall be removed within twenty
four (24) hours after the close of the sale. (1983 Code § 9-704)
CHAPTER 11
TAXICABS
SECTION:
3-11-1: Definition
3-11-2: License Required; Fee
3-11-3: City Register Of Licenses Issued
3-11-4: Regulation Of Taxicabs
3-11-5: Driver Qualifications
3-11-6: Insurance Required
3-11-7: Street Stands Regulated
3-11-8: Misrepresentation; License Revocation
3-11-9: Penalty
3-11-1: DEFINITION:
A "taxicab", as the term is used in this chapter, is any automobile or other
self-propelled vehicle operating within the corporate limits of the city for
the purpose of carrying passengers for hire. (1983 Code § 16-201)
3-11-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE:
   A.   License Required; Fee; Application:
      1.   Every person who, for wages or hire in the service of another, shall
drive or operate any vehicle for hire in the transportation of persons or
baggage shall first obtain a license therefor. For each license, such person
shall pay a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) per vehicle per annum therefor to
the city clerk.
      2.   No license shall be issued until an application shall have been made
in writing accompanied by a certificate of character and competency.
   B.   Certificate Of Character And Competency: The certificate of character
and competency, as required in subsection A2 of this section, shall set forth
the following information:
      1.   Occupations and employments pursued over the preceding five (5) year
period;
      2.   Whether or not the applicant has had any collision or accident in
which any person or property was injured or damaged and a description of the
same, in each case showing party neglect;
      3.   Whether or not the applicant has been charged with or convicted of
any crime, and if so, the nature of the crime;
      4.   Whether or not the applicant has ever had a driver's or other
license revoked or cancelled and for what purpose;
      5.   Whether or not the applicant drinks any intoxicating liquors or has
been under the influence of the same within the past year; and
      6.   Whether or not the applicant has been convicted of violating any
city ordinance within the past year.
   C.   Findings In Favor Of Applicant: If, upon any examination of the
certificate of character and competency, the clerk shall find, that:
      1.   From his occupation and employment during the past five (5) years,
the applicant shall be competent to serve as a driver;
      2.   The representations made in the certificate relating to other
matters are answered in the negative;
      3.   The applicant shall be a person of good moral character; and
      4.   The applicant certifies the truth of his answers to the certificate;
the clerk shall issue to the applicant a driver's license authorizing him to
drive or operate a vehicle for hire upon:
Payment of the required fee; and
The making of an affidavit to the effect that he shall in all respects comply
with the ordinances relating to the drivers of, or operators of, vehicles for
hire.
   D.   Authority Of License: Such license shall be authority to drive any
vehicle within the city, but if used as authority to drive any other motor
vehicle except a vehicle for hire, shall be subject to the same provisions and
rules relating to permits for drivers of motor vehicles. (1983 Code § 16-209)
3-11-3: CITY REGISTER OF LICENSES ISSUED:
The city clerk shall provide a book in which he shall keep a duplicate of each
license issued for a vehicle for hire which shall show the ownership of each
vehicle, the kind of vehicle, the city license number, the date license was
issued, the receipt number and the street or business address of the owner of
such vehicle and, if the license shall be for a motor vehicle, the record shall
show the additional information as follows:
   A.   Engine number; and
   B.   The state license number;
for the year for which license is issued and for the preceding year. (1983 Code
§ 16-210)
3-11-4: REGULATION OF TAXICABS:
   A.   Compliance With Chapter: It is unlawful for any person, firm or
corporation, either as a principal, agent or employee, to operate in the city a
taxicab without complying with the provisions of this chapter. (1983 Code § 16-
202)
   B.   Maximum Legal Speed: Taxicabs shall not be operated upon any of the
public thoroughfares of the city at a speed in excess of the maximum rates of
speed fixed by ordinance for the operation of automobiles generally. (1983 Code
§ 16-203)
   C.   Taxicabs Kept Clean And Safe: All taxicabs shall be kept in a clean and
sanitary condition; all taxicabs shall be kept in safe mechanical condition and
shall not be operated on the streets of the city in an unsafe condition, so as
to endanger the limbs or lives of passengers riding therein, or the public.
(1983 Code § 16-204)
   D.   Operation Controlled: Specific enumeration of regulations herein shall
in no manner relieve taxicabs from general regulation of vehicles as the same
may now exist or may hereafter be provided in other ordinances or state laws
regulating the same. (1983 Code § 16-205)
3-11-5: DRIVER QUALIFICATIONS:
It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of
operating taxicabs to permit such automobiles to be driven by any person under
the age of twenty one (21) years, or by any person who is not fully qualified
to act as a driver of taxicab. (1983 Code § 16-206)
3-11-6: INSURANCE REQUIRED:
   A.   Policy Of Insurance On File: It is unlawful for any person, firm or
corporation to operate a taxicab on the thoroughfares of the city until a good
and sufficient policy of insurance covering each vehicle to be so used or
operated by such person, firm or corporation and executed by some insurance and
indemnity company authorized to do business in the state as surety, running in
the name of the city, conditioned that the person, firm or corporation will pay
and discharge any liability imposed by law for damages on account of injury to
property, or bodily injury, including death, resulting at any time therefrom
suffered by any person as a result of the operation of such vehicle or
vehicles, is on file with the city clerk.
   B.   Liability Amounts: The maximum liability under the insurance policy for
loss or damages from any accident resulting in bodily injury to, or the death
of, not more than one person, shall be twenty five thousand dollars
($25,000.00) and subject to the same limit for each person; the total liability
for loss from any one accident resulting in bodily injury to, or the death of,
more than one person shall be limited to fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00);
and the maximum liability for the damage to property shall be limited to ten
thousand dollars ($10,000.00).
   C.   Policy Term; Renewal: No renewal of the policy of insurance shall be
required by reason of the substitution of one vehicle for another in service,
provided such substitution does not invalidate the policy of insurance. The
policy of insurance shall be made for a period of not less than one year, and a
new policy shall be furnished at the expiration of any existing policy, if the
operation of the taxicab covered thereby is to be continued. (1983 Code § 16-
207)
3-11-7: STREET STANDS REGULATED:
   A.   Stands, Signs Prohibited On Public Streets:
      1.   No owner or driver of an automobile, taxicab, truck, or dray, jitney
or other conveyance engaged in the business or occupation of conveying
passengers or merchandise for hire to or from any place within or without the
city shall maintain a stand on the streets or avenues or on the parkings or
sidewalks contiguous thereto, within the city.
      2.   No sign, advertisement, or other marking, indicating or concerning
the business or occupation, shall be made, placed or maintained on or above any
street or avenue or the curbing thereof, or any parking or sidewalk within the
city.
   B.   Location Of Stands Or Telephones On Private Property:
      1.   All stands for such business or occupation shall be located wholly
upon private property. A "stand", within the terms of this chapter, is declared
and defined to be an actual place of business where a telephone or office is
maintained. Such a telephone must be located wholly within and upon private
property, and there must be sufficient private property available about the
telephone for the proper use thereof. The use of a telephone on a pole or on
the side of a building where a part of a street, avenue, alley, parking,
sidewalk or other public property must be used in properly using the telephone
is prohibited.
      2.   The owner or operator of any stand in violation hereof, upon the
effective date hereof, shall have thirty (30) days from the said effective date
within which to comply with the provisions hereof relative to the proper
location of such a stand.
   C.   Parking Within Congested District:
      1.   No owner or driver of an automobile, taxicab, truck, or dray, jitney
