and the costs of acquiring, establishing, improving, maintaining and operating
public off street parking facilities. In addition revenue generated from the
operation of city meters shall be used for downtown beautification. (Ord. 482,
4-11-2013)
CHAPTER 6
VEHICLE EQUIPMENT AND CONDITION
SECTION:
6-6-1: Compliance With State Law; Use Of Equipment Required
6-6-2: Vehicle Size And Weight; Truck Routes
6-6-3: Loads On Vehicles
6-6-4: Inspection Of Vehicles By Officers
6-6-1: COMPLIANCE WITH STATE LAW; USE OF EQUIPMENT REQUIRED:
Every vehicle operated upon the streets of the city shall be equipped as
required by law. It is unlawful for any person to:
   A.   Operate a vehicle upon a street of the city which is not equipped as
required by law.
   B.   Fail to use such equipment in the manner required by law, or to use it
in a manner prohibited by law.
   C.   Operate a vehicle which has equipment prohibited by law upon a street
in the city.
   D.   Operate a vehicle which has an internal combustion engine without a
suitable and sufficient muffler. No muffler cutout or exhaust or vacuum whistle
shall be used on any motor vehicle while operating in the city. (1983 Code §
15-103)
6-6-2: VEHICLE SIZE AND WEIGHT; TRUCK ROUTES:
   A.   General Requirements: No person shall drive on or convey through any
street any vehicle the width, height, length, weight, or load of which exceeds
that authorized by state law, except in accordance with a permit issued by
state authority or by the chief of police.
   B.   Limitation For Crossing Wewoka Lake Dam: No vehicle shall be driven,
operated or otherwise transported across the Wewoka Lake dam if the weight of
such vehicle, with or without load, exceeds ten thousand (10,000) pounds. (1983
Code § 15-104)
   C.   Truck Route: Except for purposes of actual deliveries to points within
the city, no truck or other vehicle with a gross vehicle weight exceeding
twelve thousand (12,000) pounds shall be driven on any street or alley within
the city, except the following designated "truck route":
      1.   Highway 270, city route, from the western boundary of the city
limits east to Mekusukey, then north or south on Mekusukey;
      2.   Mekusukey from the northern city limit to the southern city limit;
      3.   Park Street between Mekusukey and Wewoka Avenue;
      4.   Wewoka Avenue from the northern city limit to Park Street. (Ord.
420, 6-11-1996)
6-6-3: LOADS ON VEHICLES:
   A.   Materials Leaking Or Dropping: No vehicle shall be driven or moved on
any street or alley unless the vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to
prevent any of its load from dropping, sifting, leaking or otherwise escaping
therefrom, except that sand or salt may be dropped for the purpose of securing
traction, or water or other substances may be sprinkled on a roadway in
cleaning or maintaining the roadway.
   B.   Load Or Covering Securely Fastened: No person shall operate on any
street or alley any vehicle with any load unless the load, and any covering
thereon, is securely fastened so as to prevent the covering or load from
becoming loose, detached or in any manner a hazard to other users of the
streets or alleys.
   C.   Livestock, Agricultural Products: This section shall not apply to
trucks loaded only with livestock, poultry or agricultural products except
baled agricultural products, but any such truck shall be constructed or loaded
as to prevent the livestock or poultry from escaping therefrom. (1983 Code §
15-105)
6-6-4: INSPECTION OF VEHICLES BY OFFICERS:
   A.   Inspection And Testing Of Equipment: Police officers have authority to
inspect and test any vehicle upon the streets of the city at any time to
determine whether it is safe, whether it is properly equipped, and whether its
equipment is in proper adjustment or repair.
   B.   Weighing Of Vehicles: Any officer of the city police department is
authorized to stop any vehicle in order to weigh such vehicle by means of
portable or stationary scales, or cause the same to be weighed by any official
weigher, or upon any privately owned scales and may require that such vehicles
be driven to the nearest or most convenient available scales for the purpose of
weighing. (1983 Code § 15-106)
CHAPTER 7
BICYCLES AND MOTORCYCLES
SECTION:
6-7-1: Applicability Of Provisions; Compliance
6-7-2: State Traffic Laws Apply
6-7-3: Obedience To Traffic Control Devices
6-7-4: Rules Of Operation
6-7-5: Lights And Reflectors
6-7-6: Motorcycles, Bicycles And Motor Scooters
6-7-1: APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS; COMPLIANCE:
   A.   Applicability Of Provisions: The provisions of this chapter are
applicable to bicycles operated upon any street or highway or upon any path set
aside for the exclusive use of bicycles.
   B.   Compliance With Provisions: It is unlawful for any person to do any act
or fail to perform any act required by the provisions of this chapter.
   C.   Responsibility Of Parent Or Guardian: The parent of any child or the
guardian of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or
ward to violate any of the provisions of this chapter. (1983 Code § 15-401)
6-7-2: STATE TRAFFIC LAWS APPLY:
Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be granted all of the rights
and shall be subject to all the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle by
the laws of this state declaring rules of the road applicable to vehicles or by
the traffic ordinances of the city applicable to the driver of a vehicle,
except as to special regulations in this chapter and except as to those
provisions of law and ordinances which by their nature can have no application.
(1983 Code § 15-402)
6-7-3: OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES:
   A.   Any person operating a bicycle shall obey the instructions of official
traffic control signals, signs and other control devices applicable to
vehicles, unless otherwise directed by a police officer.
   B.   Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right or left
or U-turn is permitted, no person operating a bicycle shall disobey the
direction of any such sign, except where such person dismounts from the bicycle
to make any such turn, in which event such person shall then obey the
regulations applicable to pedestrians.
   C.   Any person may walk a bicycle and shall then be subject to all laws
applicable to pedestrians. (1983 Code § 15-403)
6-7-4: RULES OF OPERATION:
   A.   Riding On Bicycles:
      1.   A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other than astride a
permanent and regular seat attached thereto.
      2.   No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one time than the
number for which it is designed and equipped. (1983 Code § 15-404)
   B.   Riding On Roadways:
      1.   Riding On Right: Every person operating a bicycle upon a roadway
shall ride as near to the right side of the roadway as practicable, exercising
due care when passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same
direction. (1983 Code § 15-405)
      2.   Riding Abreast: Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not
ride more than two (2) abreast, except on paths or parts of roadways set aside
for the exclusive use of bicycles. (1983 Code § 15-406)
      3.   Speed Limit: No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater
than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing. (1983 Code §
15-407)
      4.   Riding On Sidewalks: Bicycles may not be ridden upon any sidewalk
within the city. (1983 Code § 15-408)
6-7-5: LIGHTS AND REFLECTORS:
Every bicycle, when in use at nighttime, shall be equipped with a lamp on the
frame which shall emit a white light visible from a distance of at least five
hundred feet (500') to the front and with a red reflector on the rear of a type
approved by the state department of public safety, which shall be visible from
all distances from fifty feet (50') to three hundred feet (300') to the rear
when directly in front of lawful upper beams of headlamps of a motor vehicle.
(1983 Code § 15-409; amd. 2005 Code)
6-7-6: MOTORCYCLES, BICYCLES AND MOTOR SCOOTERS:
   A.   Use Limitations:
      1.   Carrying Passengers: No driver of a two (2) wheel or three (3) wheel
motor vehicle or bicycle shall carry any other person upon or within such
vehicle on any street or highway, except as provided in this subsection:
         a.   If any two (2) wheel or three (3) wheel motor vehicle with a
wheel diameter of twelve inches (12") or greater or any bicycle shall have
either a double seating device with double foot rests or a side car attachment
providing a separate seat space within such sidecar attachment for each person
riding therein so that such person shall be seated entirely within the body of
the side car, then it shall be permissible for an operator who has attained the
age of sixteen (16) or older to carry a passenger; and
         b.   A demonstration ride by a licensed dealer or his employee is
permissible.
      2.   Prohibited On Sidewalks: No motorcycle or motor scooter shall be
ridden upon any sidewalk of the city.
      3.   Attaching To Moving Vehicles: No rider of a motorcycle, bicycle, or
motor scooter shall hold on to any moving vehicle for the purpose of being
propelled.
      4.   Riding On Seat: A person operating a motor scooter, motorcycle,
motor driven cycle, or motor bicycle shall ride only on the permanent and
regular seat attached thereto.
      5.   Passing Vehicles Between Lanes Of Traffic: No driver of a motorcycle
or motor scooter shall pass other vehicles in between lanes of traffic
traveling in the same direction. Authorized emergency vehicles are excepted
from the provisions of this subsection A5. (1983 Code § 15-215)
   B.   Motorcycle Equipment; Headgear:
      1.   Required Equipment: In addition to all other requirements,
motorcycles and motor scooters shall be equipped with the following:
         a.   Handlebars which do not exceed twelve inches (12") in height,
measured from the crown or point of attachment.
         b.   Two (2) mirrors, containing a reflection surface of not less than
three inches (3") in diameter, mounted one on each side of the vehicle and
positioned so as to enable the operator to clearly view the roadway for a
distance of two hundred feet (200') to the rear of his vehicle.
         c.   Brakes adequate to control the movement of the vehicle, to stop
and hold the vehicle, including two (2) separate means of applying the brakes.
One means for applying the brakes shall be to effectively apply the brakes to
the front wheel, and one means shall be to effectively apply the brakes to the
rear wheels. All such vehicles shall be equipped with a stop lamp on the rear
of the vehicle which shall display a red or amber light, or any shade of color
between red and amber, visible from a distance of not less than one hundred
feet (100') to the rear in normal sunlight, and which shall be activated upon
application of the service brake.
         d.   A properly operating speedometer capable of registering at least
the maximum legal speed limit for that vehicle shall be provided.
         e.   A fender over each wheel. All fenders shall be of the type
provided by the manufacturer. (1983 Code § 15-216)
         f.   One lighted headlamp capable of showing a white light visible at
least three hundred feet (300') in the direction in which the vehicle is
proceeding, and one tail lamp mounted on the rear which, when lighted, shall
emit a red light plainly visible from at least three hundred feet (300') to the
rear. The lights required by this subsection shall be burning whenever the
vehicle is in motion.
         g.   A windshield of sufficient quality, size and thickness to protect
the operator from foreign objects. In lieu of the windshield, the operator
shall wear goggles or face shield of material and design to protect him from
foreign objects.
      2.   Headgear: No person under twenty one (21) years of age shall operate
or ride upon any vehicle covered under this subsection unless the person is
equipped with and wearing on the head a crash helmet of a type which complies
with standards established by 59 CFR section 571.218. All crash helmets shall
consist of lining, padding and chinstraps and be of the type as not to distort
the view of the driver. While operating or riding on a vehicle covered
hereunder, the chinstraps shall be fastened.
      3.   Exhaust System: No person may operate a motorcycle or motor scooter
with the exhaust system modified so that motor noise is increased greater than
that of the original muffler equipment provided by the manufacturers of the
vehicle. (1983 Code § 15-216; amd. 2005 Code)
   C.   Speed Limit: No person shall operate any motorcycle or any motor
scooter at a speed greater than the speed limit legally posted. In no event nor
at any time may an operator under the age of sixteen (16) years operate a
motorcycle or motor scooter, including a motor driven bicycle, at a speed
greater than thirty five (35) miles per hour, or at any time or any speed when
prohibited by state law. (1983 Code § 15-217)
CHAPTER 8
VEHICLE IMPOUNDMENT
SECTION:
6-8-1: Purpose And Effect Of Provisions
6-8-2: Place Of Impoundment; Rotating List Of Wrecker Services
6-8-3: Duration Of Impoundment; Redemption
6-8-4: Police Authority To Impound Vehicles
6-8-5: Notice To Owner
6-8-6: Proof Of Parking Violations
6-8-7: Disabled Vehicles
6-8-8: Vehicles On Bridge
6-8-9: Arrest And Detention Of Driver
6-8-10: Illegal Trespass By Vehicle
6-8-11: Impoundment Of Illegally Parked Vehicles
6-8-12: Vehicles Blocking Fire Exits Or Hydrants
6-8-13: Stolen Vehicles; Recovery By Police
6-8-14: Vehicles With Outstanding Traffic Citations
6-8-1: PURPOSE AND EFFECT OF PROVISIONS:
The impoundment of vehicles under authority of the provisions of this chapter
shall be construed as an enforcement procedure for protection of the public
peace, safety and welfare, and the safeguarding of property, and shall be used
generally for the prevention and removal of traffic hazards, prevention and
abatement of public nuisances arising from traffic law violations, protection
of the public rights in the use of streets and thoroughfares from obstructions
placed and left in derogation of those rights, and for safeguarding and
protecting recovered stolen vehicles. (1983 Code § 15-501)
6-8-2: PLACE OF IMPOUNDMENT; ROTATING LIST OF WRECKER SERVICES:
   A.   Designation Of Impoundment Place: Every vehicle that is impounded under
the provisions of this chapter, or any other provision of the ordinances of the
city, shall be removed to a garage or place of safekeeping designated by the
police chief, such place to be determined in accordance with the provisions of
this section.
   B.   List Of Wrecker Services:
      1.   The police chief shall establish a list of wrecker services located
within one mile of the city limits, to be used for purposes of removal of
abandoned vehicles or vehicles parked in violation of any ordinances of the
city or the laws of the state of Oklahoma authorizing removal of such vehicle.
      2.   The wrecker services or towing services included on the list shall
be contacted on a rotating basis for purposes of carrying out the duties of the
chief of police under this section and other applicable law. If the services of
licensed wreckers or towing vehicles included on the list are unavailable, the
chief of police may contact the licensed wrecker or towing service whose
location is nearest to the vehicle to be towed. (Ord. 438, 7-10-2001)
6-8-3: DURATION OF IMPOUNDMENT; REDEMPTION:
   A.   Order For Release: Except as otherwise provided, any vehicle impounded
under the authority of this chapter shall be stored and held safely until an
order for its release is signed and received from a police officer. (1983 Code
§ 15-503; amd. 2005 Code)
   B.   Payment Of Costs: The order of release of an impounded vehicle shall be
conditioned upon the payment by the person to whom the release is issued of all
impoundment costs and accrued storage charges assessed against the vehicle.
   C.   Payment Of Fines And Costs: No order of release of an impounded vehicle
shall be issued until all fines and costs due the city because of traffic law
or other law violations involving the vehicle have been paid. (1983 Code § 15-
503)
   D.   Impound Fee: Any vehicle impounded under the authority of this section
shall be stored and held until a written order for its release, signed by an
authorized officer of the city, has been issued. Such order of release shall be
conditioned upon the payment to the city by the person to whom the release is
issued of an impound fee in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
   E.   Impound Fees Account: There is hereby created within the police fund a
special account into which all impound fees shall be deposited. Expenditures
out of which shall be used only to pay for police equipment.
   F.   Obtaining Possession Of Impounded Vehicle: Presentation of the order of
release herein provided at the place of impoundment, together with payment or
tender of payment of all impoundment costs and accrued storage charge due,
shall entitle the person presenting such release to obtain possession of the
vehicle. (Ord. 463, 3-11-2008)
6-8-4: POLICE AUTHORITY TO IMPOUND VEHICLES:
   A.   Circumstances Causing Impoundment: Members of the police department are
hereby authorized within the limits set forth in this chapter to impound
vehicles under the circumstances hereinafter enumerated:
      1.   When any vehicle is left unattended upon a street or highway and is
so parked as to constitute a hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of
traffic or parked where parking is prohibited.
      2.   When a vehicle upon a street or highway is stopped, standing, or
parked as to constitute an obstruction to traffic, and the person in charge of
the vehicle is by reason of physical condition incapacitated to such an extent
as to be unable to provide for its custody or safe removal.
      3.   When any vehicle is left abandoned upon a street or highway in
excess of seven (7) days from the date it was first abandoned and reported or
observed by officers.
      4.   When officers recover a vehicle reported stolen; provided, that the
registered owner thereof cannot be located within a reasonable time. In the
event the registered owner is located and notified of the recovery of the
stolen vehicle, the owner shall be permitted to make arrangements for the
removal of the vehicle. If the owner is unable or unwilling to effect the
removal of the vehicle, then it shall be impounded by the officer effecting the
recovery.
      5.   An unattended vehicle found to be in violation of any ordinance of
the city may be impounded when the required complaint thereof has been properly
made and filed as provided in this code. (1983 Code § 15-504)
      6.   Derelict vehicles having been parked upon public right of way for a
period of seventy two (72) hours may be impounded in accordance with the
ordinances of the city.
      7.   When a vehicle is of evidentiary value or involved in the commission
of a crime.
      8.   When a police officer effects the arrest of the owner or operator of
a vehicle out of said vehicle, and no person present can lawfully or reasonably
be given custody of such vehicle.
      9.   When in accordance with 47 Oklahoma Statutes, after ninety (90) days
from the expiration date for annual registration of a vehicle, the vehicle is
not bearing or displaying a proper license plate required by the Oklahoma
vehicle license and registration act 1 .
      10.   Members of the police department shall remove a vehicle from any
street, highway or public property to a storage facility as provided for in
this code when the person operating said vehicle fails to produce valid
security verification in addition to committing any one of the following
violations: reckless driving, careless driving, driving under the influence,
driving while impaired, driving under a suspended license, driving with no
state driver's license, or driving with an expired license, improper or no tag
displayed. (Ord. 463, 3-11-2008)
   B.   Validity Of Impoundment: No impoundment shall be valid unless made
under order of an authorized police officer and in strict adherence with the
procedures required in this chapter. (1983 Code § 15-504)
 
Notes
1 1. 47 OS § 1109 et seq.
6-8-5: NOTICE TO OWNER:
Whenever an officer removes an unattended vehicle from a street or highway as
authorized in this chapter, and the officer has knowledge of or is able to
ascertain from the motor vehicle registration the name and address of the last
registered owner thereof, the officer shall give or cause to be given notice in
writing to the owner of the fact of removal and the reasons therefor and of the
place to which the vehicle has been removed. (1983 Code § 15-505)
6-8-6: PROOF OF PARKING VIOLATIONS:
In any prosecution for parking a vehicle in violation of any provision of this
title, proof of registration of a motor vehicle and proof of the violation
shall be construed as prima facie proof that the registered owner of such motor
vehicle was the user or operator thereof at the time of the violation charged.
(1983 Code § 15-511)
6-8-7: DISABLED VEHICLES:
A disabled vehicle upon a street or highway may be impounded under the
following circumstances:
   A.   If left unattended and improperly parked on a street or highway and
constitutes a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic;
or
   B.   If the person in charge of the vehicle is physically incapacitated to
such extent as to be unable to provide for its custody or removal and the
vehicle is so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic or a hazard.
(1983 Code § 15-506)
6-8-8: VEHICLES ON BRIDGE:
An unattended vehicle left upon any bridge, viaduct or causeway or in any tube
or tunnel, where the vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic or hazard,
may be impounded. (1983 Code § 15-507)
6-8-9: ARREST AND DETENTION OF DRIVER:
Whenever the driver or person in charge of any vehicle is placed under arrest
and taken into custody and detained by police under circumstances which leave
or will leave a vehicle unattended on any street or highway, the vehicle may be
impounded. (1983 Code § 15-508)
6-8-10: ILLEGAL TRESPASS BY VEHICLE:
   A.   Filing Of Complaint: An unattended vehicle found to be parked in
violation of this title may be impounded when the required complaint has been
properly made and filed as provided in this section.
   B.   Contents Of Complaint: If a violation of the provisions of this title
occurs, the owner or legal occupant who complains shall sign a complaint
against the person parking the vehicle on the owner's or legal occupant's
property, or, if the identity of the person parking the vehicle is unknown,
then the complaint may be filed against the registered owner of the vehicle.
The complaint shall be verified and shall allege that the complaining party is
the owner or legal occupant of the property upon which the vehicle is parked or
standing.
   C.   Impoundment Of Vehicle: Upon filing of the complaint by the property
owner or legal occupant, and if there appears to be proper cause to believe the
provisions of this title have been violated, the police department shall cause
the vehicle to be impounded from the property and placed in storage. (1983 Code
§ 15-509)
6-8-11: IMPOUNDMENT OF ILLEGALLY PARKED VEHICLES:
   A.   Authority To Impound: Any police officer may impound any motor vehicle
parked at a place where parking is prohibited by this title or which has been
parked for more than one hour in excess of the time allowed for parking in any
parking meter zone.
   B.   Redemption; Payment Of Fine And Costs: Any person desiring to redeem
such impounded vehicle shall first pay such fine as may be assessed by the
municipal judge for the violation for which the vehicle was impounded and such
costs as are incurred in impounding and storing such vehicle. (1983 Code § 15-
510; amd. 2005 Code)
6-8-12: VEHICLES BLOCKING FIRE EXITS OR HYDRANTS:
Any vehicle illegally parked in such a manner that it blocks a fire escape
ladder, device or exit or blocks ready access to a fire hydrant shall be
impounded. (1983 Code § 15-512)
6-8-13: STOLEN VEHICLES; RECOVERY BY POLICE:
   A.   Removal By Police: Whenever a stolen vehicle is located by police and
the registered owner cannot be found within a reasonable time not exceeding one
hour, or cannot be determined from the registration papers or other identifying
media in the vehicle or from records or information available from reports of
stolen cars, the vehicle may be removed to the nearest authorized place of
impoundment, and the registered owner of the vehicle shall be notified of the
location of the place of impoundment as soon as possible by the police
department.
   B.   Owner Responsibility: If the registered owner is identified, located
and notified of the recovery of the stolen vehicle, the owner shall be given
the right to make his own arrangement for the removal of the vehicle within the
period of one hour from the time he is actually notified of its recovery, and
if the owner is unable or unwilling to effect the removal within the time
specified, the vehicle may be impounded. (1983 Code § 15-513)
6-8-14: VEHICLES WITH OUTSTANDING TRAFFIC CITATIONS:
Any vehicle for which two (2) or more citations have been issued for violation
of an ordinance and have not been presented as required, may be impounded if
parked in violation of any provision of this title. Any person desiring to
redeem such impounded vehicle shall first pay such fine as may be assessed by
the municipal judge for the violation for which the vehicle was impounded and
such costs as are incurred in impounding and storing such vehicle. (1983 Code §
15-514; amd. 2005 Code)
CHAPTER 9
GOLF CARTS
SECTION:
6-9-1: Applicability; Compliance; Responsibility Of Parent Or Guardian
6-9-2: State Traffic Laws Apply
6-9-3: Equipment Requirements
6-9-4: Permit And Insurance Required, Exception; Inspection; Annual Fee
6-9-5: Rules Of Operation; Restrictions
6-9-6: Parking Regulations And Violations
6-9-7: Prohibited Areas Of Operation
6-9-8: Permitted Crossings
6-9-1: APPLICABILITY; COMPLIANCE; RESPONSIBILITY OF PARENT OR GUARDIAN:
   A.   Applicability Of Provisions: The provisions of this chapter are
applicable to golf carts operated upon any street or highway or upon any path
set aside for the exclusive use of golf carts.
   B.   Compliance With Provisions: It is unlawful for any person to do any act
or fail to perform any act required by the provisions of this chapter.
   C.   Responsibility Of Parent Or Guardian: The parent of any child or the
guardian of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or
ward to violate any of the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 465, 8-5-2008)
6-9-2: STATE TRAFFIC LAWS APPLY:
Every person riding a golf cart upon a roadway shall be granted all of the
rights and shall be subject to all the duties applicable to the driver of a
vehicle by the laws of this state declaring rules of the road applicable to
vehicles or by the traffic ordinances of the city applicable to the driver of a
vehicle, except as to special regulations in this chapter and except as to
those provisions of law and ordinances which by their nature can have no
application. (Ord. 465, 8-5-2008)
6-9-3: EQUIPMENT REQUIREMENTS:
Every golf cart shall be equipped with a mirror, brakes, and when in use at
nighttime, shall be equipped with a lamp on the frame which shall emit a white
light visible from a distance of at least five hundred feet (500') to the front
and with a red reflector on the rear of a type approved by the state department
of public safety, which shall be visible from all distances from fifty feet
(50') to three hundred feet (300') to the rear when directly in front of lawful
upper beams of headlamps of a motor vehicle. (Ord. 465, 8-5-2008)
6-9-4: PERMIT AND INSURANCE REQUIRED, EXCEPTION; INSPECTION; ANNUAL FEE:
   A.   A permit for operation of a golf cart may be issued by the city of
Wewoka if the golf cart is equipped as required by section
6-9-3 of this chapter and evidence of insurance as required for the
registration of a motor vehicle is submitted when application for the permit is
made.
   B.   A permit shall not be required for the operation of a golf cart during
daylight, by a person holding a current driver's license if the golf cart is
used for travel to and from the municipal golf course and operated solely upon
the portion of a city street/highway designated by the city of Wewoka.
   C.   An annual permit for the operation of a golf cart as provided herein
will be issued after the golf cart has been inspected for the first time by an
officer of the Wewoka police department and an annual permit fee of fifty
dollars ($50.00) has been paid. The permit will be for one year expiring on
December 31 of each year. Subsequent annual golf cart permits may be renewed by
mail after the first time registration and inspection as provided above. (Ord.
465, 8-5-2008)
6-9-5: RULES OF OPERATION; RESTRICTIONS:
Golf carts must not impede or interfere with normal pedestrian or vehicular
flow on roadways. Golf cart travel shall be with the flow of traffic and follow
the same protocols as a motor vehicle. Golf carts shall not be modified in any
manner that affects the recommended mode of operation, speed or safety of the
cart. Passengers are restricted to ride only in designated golf cart seats and
shall not exceed the passenger limit or load for the cart. (Ord. 465, 8-5-2008)
6-9-6: PARKING REGULATIONS AND VIOLATIONS:
   A.   Parking of golf carts shall be on hard, covered surfaces such as
asphalt and concrete. The following areas are prohibited: fire lanes; entrances
to buildings, stairways, disability ramps, or main thoroughfares. Parking of a
gas golf cart must be at least ten feet (10') from any building.
   B.   Parking citations will be issued for parking violations in fire lanes,
reserved parking or handicapped parking spaces. Citations will be issued to the
driver of the vehicle who is responsible for paying or appealing the citation.
Improperly parked golf carts will be towed by the Wewoka police department.
(Ord. 465, 8-5-2008)
6-9-7: PROHIBITED AREAS OF OPERATION:
Golf carts are prohibited on Mekusukey from First Street to Fourteenth Street;
Fourteenth Street (from City Limits Road to Dog Pound Road); Seran Avenue (from
Fourteenth Street to 270 bypass); and 270 Business (also known as First Street)
from Mekusukey to City Limits Road. (Ord. 465, 8-5-2008)
6-9-8: PERMITTED CROSSINGS:
Golf carts may cross at the following intersection crossings: Fourth Street and
Mekusukey; Seventh Street and Mekusukey; Eighth Street and Mekusukey; Twelfth
Street and Mekusukey; Fourteenth Street and Ocheese Street and Fourteenth
Street and Okfuskee Street. (Ord. 465, 8-5-2008)
TITLE 7
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS
SECTION:
7-1-1: Street Addresses; Numbering Structures
7-1-2: Crowds Obstructing Public Ways, Buildings
7-1-3: Sidewalk Obstructions; Display Of Merchandise
7-1-4: Trees; Location And Pruning
7-1-5: Refuse On Sidewalks; Sweeping Trash
7-1-6: Building Or Waste Materials On Streets And Sidewalks
7-1-7: Mixing Concrete
7-1-8: Fires Or Furnaces On Pavement
7-1-9: Spilling Oil On Pavement
7-1-10: Placement Of Telephone Poles
7-1-11: Skating, Coasting Or Playing Ball
7-1-12: Stone Throwing
7-1-13: Placing Glass, Tacks Or Nails On Streets
7-1-14: Street Signs, Mutilation
7-1-15: Deposits Of Ashes, Trash Or Dirt
7-1-16: Penalty
7-1-1: STREET ADDRESSES; NUMBERING STRUCTURES:
   A.   Street Number Addresses Assigned: All lots and parcels of land within
the city shall be assigned a street number address by the building inspector.
Structures existing at the time of adoption of this chapter shall be designated
using the number heretofore assigned or used for that structure.
   B.   Owner Responsibility For Placement Of Numbers On Structures:
      1.   It shall be the duty of all persons owning, occupying or using any
structure or building in the city to place in a conspicuous location on the
building the number so assigned by the building inspector.
      2.   Any such number that is not visible and legible from the street
passing in front of any structure shall not be in compliance with this section.
   C.   Application To All Structures: The provisions of this section shall
apply to all structures within the city limits as of the effective date hereof,
without regard to the date of construction of such structure. (Ord. 414, 12-12-
1995; amd. 2005 Code)
7-1-2: CROWDS OBSTRUCTING PUBLIC WAYS, BUILDINGS:
It is unlawful for any person or collection of persons to walk or stand in or
upon any street, sidewalk or street crossing so as to prevent, interrupt or
obstruct the travel or free passage over the same, or to stand or loiter on the
sidewalk in front of or at the side of any business or house of any kind in the
city, to the detriment or annoyance of the occupants of such building or other
persons, or for any reason to fail, refuse or neglect to disperse or move on
when directed to do so by any police officer. (Ord. 406, 9-14-1993)
7-1-3: SIDEWALK OBSTRUCTIONS; DISPLAY OF MERCHANDISE:
   A.   Obstructing Sidewalks: No person shall leave or deposit or cause to be
left or deposited in or upon any sidewalk, any article or thing whatsoever that
will obstruct or otherwise encumber the same, except as expressly provided by
ordinance.
   B.   Display Of Merchandise By Businesses:
      1.   Businesses in the city may display merchandise for sale on the
sidewalks in front of the businesses. Such displays shall be arranged so that
an area of passage of not less than seventy two inches (72") in width shall
remain unobstructed and shall be taken in at the close of the business day.
      2.   No displays of merchandise shall be placed on sidewalks other than
as permitted in this subsection. (Ord. 418, 4-9-1996)
7-1-4: TREES; LOCATION AND PRUNING:
   A.   Location In Parking: Trees that are grown in the parking of the streets
of the city shall be set out in the parking halfway between the sidewalk and
the curb of the street. (1983 Code § 14-118)
   B.   Pruning:
      1.   Impeding Traffic Or Pedestrians: All persons or firms owning
property, having trees growing in their yards or in the parking or in close
proximity to the street or sidewalk in the city, shall prune or cause to be
pruned all limbs which impede the traffic or view of traffic of the street, or
the walking along the sidewalks in a normal manner. (1983 Code § 14-119)
      2.   Abatement By City; Assessment Of Costs: If any person or owner fails
to prune the trees, the city may cause the same to be pruned and charge the
owner thereof the necessary cost of pruning. (1983 Code § 14-120)
7-1-5: REFUSE ON SIDEWALKS; SWEEPING TRASH:
   A.   Refuse Accumulations Prohibited: It is unlawful for any property owner,
occupant or agent of any property that abuts or adjoins any street or avenue in
the city to allow or permit any animal or vegetable substance, or any tin,
glass or pieces of iron, or any trash, mud, snow, ice, dirt, slop, or refuse
matter or filth of any kind or description whatsoever to accumulate or remain
on any part of the sidewalk abutting or adjacent to the premises owned or
occupied by such person. (1983 Code § 14-115)
   B.   Sweeping Trash: It is unlawful for any person to sweep out or deposit
on any of the sidewalks or streets of the city any dirt or trash of any kind,
or sweep from the sidewalks into the street any dirt or trash of any kind
whatsoever. (1983 Code § 14-116)
7-1-6: BUILDING OR WASTE MATERIALS ON STREETS AND SIDEWALKS:
   A.   Piling Or Storing:
      1.   No person, firm or corporation shall use or occupy more than one-
third (1/3) of the roadway nor more than one-half (1/2) of the sidewalk space
or alley for the piling or storing of building or construction material of any
kind or character, or for the piling of earth excavated. Such use or occupancy
shall be continued to the roadway, sidewalk space or alley immediately abutting
upon the property, where the building or improvements is to be erected or
constructed. (1983 Code § 14-214)
      2.   No person, firm or corporation shall deposit, or cause to be
deposited upon any portion of any paved street, sidewalk, alley or other public
ground, any kind of building material, earth or any other substance without
first covering such pavement with a good and substantial plank floor. The
planking shall be laid with closed joints and shall project for not less than
one foot (1') beyond the edges of the piles or stacks of such material on all
sides except next to the curb. Ample provision for free and uninterrupted flow
of water in the gutter shall be made. (1983 Code § 14-217)
   B.   Wasting Or Spilling:
      1.   The wasting, spilling or distributing of construction material,
refuse, paper, dirt, manure, shavings, cinders, ashes or any other substance on
or along any of the streets, alleys, sidewalks, or other public grounds is
absolutely prohibited. The driver or operator of any wagon, cart or other
conveyance from which these prohibited substances has been, or is being, wasted
or spilled shall be guilty of an offense and subject to arrest and the
penalties of this chapter. (1983 Code § 14-215)
      2.   All such materials or dirt wasted shall be immediately removed by
either such driver or the person, firm or corporation by whom he is employed.
The failure immediately to remove all of the material or earth so wasted shall
render both the driver and the person, firm or corporation by whom he is
employed subject to arrest and to the penalties prescribed in this chapter.
Each day that such material or dirt so wasted remains on such pavements shall
constitute a separate and distinct offense. (1983 Code § 14-216)
7-1-7: MIXING CONCRETE:
No person, firm or corporation shall mix or cause to be mixed any mortar or
concrete on any of the pavements. (1983 Code § 14-218)
7-1-8: FIRES OR FURNACES ON PAVEMENT:
   A.   Fires: No person, firm or corporation shall burn or cause to be burned
any rubbish, oil or other combustible material upon any pavement. (1983 Code §
14-219)
   B.   Furnaces: No person, firm or corporation shall place on or over, or
cause to be placed on or over any of the pavements of the city any tar heating
furnace, or any other furnace or vessel containing fire without properly
protecting the pavement against the heat therefrom with suitable materials and
thoroughly cleaning the pavement when such furnace is removed, leaving the
pavement free from any kind of debris or building material. (1983 Code § 14-
220)
7-1-9: SPILLING OIL ON PAVEMENT:
No person, firm or corporation owning or operating automobiles, garages, oil
wagons, oil depots or any other place or thing at or from which oil is bought,
sold or used shall spill, allow or cause to be spilled upon the pavements of
any of the streets, alleys or other public grounds of the city oils of any
character or any other fluid that would cause injury to the pavement. Upon
conviction, those guilty of so doing shall be liable to the penalties
prescribed in this chapter, and either the person, firm or corporation,
employee or employer, or all of them, shall be responsible for the damage
thereby caused to the pavement. (1983 Code § 14-221)
7-1-10: PLACEMENT OF TELEPHONE POLES:
   A.   Within Sidewalk Curbstone: Any telephone, telegraph or electric light
pole standing outside of the curbstone of any sidewalk in the city shall be
removed and placed in a position immediately within the sidewalk curbstone, and
all telephone, telegraph, or electric light poles hereafter to be erected shall
be placed immediately within the sidewalk curbstone. (1983 Code § 14-222)
   B.   Corners: The curbstone of every sidewalk corner shall be circular in
form, one foot (1') radius, and any telephone, telegraph, or electric light
poles located at the corner, or at any corner of any sidewalk, shall be placed
immediately within the corner of such circular curbstone. (1983 Code § 14-223)
7-1-11: SKATING, COASTING OR PLAYING BALL:
   A.   Skating And Coasting Upon Sidewalks: It is unlawful and an offense to
skate with either ice or roller skates, or a skateboard, or coast with any sled
or roller coaster, upon any crosswalk or sidewalk upon the public thoroughfares
of the city.
   B.   Ball Playing On Streets: It is unlawful and an offense for any person
to play at any game of ball or to throw or bat any ball across or upon any
street, avenue or alley in the city.
   C.   Portable Basketball Goals:
      1.   Placement Of Portable Basketball Goal: Portable basketball goals may
be placed in front of a home as long as the base of the goal is no closer than
ten (10) feet from the edge of the pavement or back of curb of the abutting
street.
      2.   Prohibited Act: It is unlawful and constitutes a misdemeanor to
erect or install a portable basketball goal outside the perimeters set forth
above.
         a.   Any person who knowingly violates this paragraph C. is guilty of
a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof for the first offense shall be
punished by a fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). Upon conviction thereof for
the second offense shall be punished by a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00)
and confiscation of the portable goal. (1983 Code § 14-207; amd. Ord. 461, 9-
11-2007; Ord. 519, 9-8-2020)
7-1-12: STONE THROWING:
It is unlawful and an offense for any person in the city to throw any stone,
brick, or any other missile, on or across any street, avenue, alley or public
place, or at any person, house, building, or other structure or across or upon
any private property without the consent or permission of the person lawfully
in possession thereof. (1983 Code § 14-208)
7-1-13: PLACING GLASS, TACKS OR NAILS ON STREETS:
It is unlawful and an offense for any person purposely or wantonly to place,
throw or cause to be placed or thrown, in or upon any thoroughfare in the city
any broken glass, tacks, nails, pieces of iron, wire, bottles, or other
substances. (1983 Code § 14-210)
7-1-14: STREET SIGNS, MUTILATION:
Any person who shall destroy, deface or remove any sign set or located on any
of the public streets, avenues, alleys, boulevards, parks or parkings, which
sign has been so set or located by or under the direction or authority of the
city shall be guilty of an offense. (1983 Code § 14-211)
7-1-15: DEPOSITS OF ASHES, TRASH OR DIRT:
   A.   No person shall place or cause to be placed in or upon any street,
alley, sidewalk, or other public grounds of the city any ashes, glass, trash,
dirt, crockery, scrap iron, paper, refuse from kitchens, or other kind of
rubbish, unless the same is in suitable receptacles and disposed of in a
regular and proper manner by the garbage department in accordance with rules
and regulations thereof.
   B.   No person doing work or making excavations in any parking shall place
or cause to be placed any dirt or refuse therefrom on any paved street or
sidewalk. (1983 Code § 14-212)
7-1-16: PENALTY:
Any person, company or corporation violating the provisions of this chapter
shall be punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1983 Code § 14-224)
ARTICLE A. SIDEWALK AND CURB CONSTRUCTION 1
SECTION:
7-1A-1: Materials For Construction Of Sidewalks
7-1A-2: Construction Of Curbs
7-1A-3: Sidewalk Construction; Railings; Areaways
7-1A-4: Improperly Constructed Sidewalks; Remedial Action
7-1A-5: Plans Furnished By City
7-1A-6: Construction Where Permanent Sidewalks Not Required
7-1A-7: Grade For Walks
7-1A-8: Sidewalk Slope And Elevation
7-1A-9: Condemnation Of Sidewalks
7-1A-10: Failure Of Owner To Comply; Construction By City
7-1A-11: Removal Of Curbing
7-1A-12: Penalty
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  9-2-5 of this code for excavation permit requirements.
7-1A-1: MATERIALS FOR CONSTRUCTION OF SIDEWALKS:
All sidewalks constructed upon the streets or avenues of the city shall be
brick or Portland cement. If brick is used, the same shall be of the best
quality of semivitrified brick and laid in broken joints, and where the walk
does not extend to the curb line, bricks shall be set on edge on the inner and
outer edge of the walk, to retain the same in place. If cement is used, the
same shall be mixed and laid in conformity with the specifications to be
furnished by the city, which specifications shall require such ingredients and
proportions thereof as will secure a hard and durable sidewalk, constructed
according to the most approved methods. (1983 Code § 14-101)
7-1A-2: CONSTRUCTION OF CURBS:
All sidewalks extending to the curb line, heretofore designated, shall be
curbed on the outer edge with stone cement. The curbstone shall be not less in
size than five inches (5") on top, and beveled one inch (1") to the foot in
height, and shall not be less than one foot (1') in the ground from the bottom
of the gutter; and in no case less than one foot (1') in width, with all joints
cut square, the top of the curb to be beveled at the outer edge, one-fourth
inch (1/4"). All sidewalks on corner lots shall continue to the curb lines.
(1983 Code § 14-102)
7-1A-3: SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION; RAILINGS; AREAWAYS:
   A.   Railings, Size: All railings around areas shall be of one and one-
fourth inch (11/4") gas pipe with posts not less than three feet (3') high, and
not more than five feet (5') apart, with two (2) rails. (1983 Code § 14-103)
   B.   Sidewalks Over Areas: All sidewalks built over areas or open spaces
shall be constructed with suitable supports by walls, arches, or iron beams
according to specifications to be approved by the city engineer; all such work
to be under his supervision, and the quality and proportion of the material and
workmanship used in all the foregoing shall be subject to the approval,
direction, and control of the city. (1983 Code § 14-104)
   C.   Gratings For Areaways: All areaways in sidewalks, not otherwise
provided for by this chapter, shall be protected by iron gratings securely
fastened in a workmanlike manner. (1983 Code § 14-105)
   D.   Areaways; Construction, Railings: All areaways containing stairways
leading from streets or alleys into basements shall be protected by railings,
as described by subsection A of this section. The entrance from the street or
alley shall be perpendicular to the building, and that portion of the areaway
which is immediately in front of the entrance shall be of durable material and
safely constructed. The space along the width of the entrance and from the
entrance to the building shall be level with the sidewalk. (1983 Code § 14-106)
   E.   Permanent Sidewalks: Whenever the city council shall have provided by
ordinance for the erection of permanent sidewalks upon any street or avenue or
part thereof, within the city, the same shall be built according to the terms
and subject to the provisions of this chapter. (1983 Code § 14-107)
7-1A-4: IMPROPERLY CONSTRUCTED SIDEWALKS; REMEDIAL ACTION:
Any sidewalks heretofore constructed or which hereafter are constructed
contrary to any of the ordinances of the city may be required by the city
council to be taken up by the building inspector and a proper sidewalk
constructed to conform to the requirements of this chapter, under the
supervision and direction of the building inspector, and the costs thereof
taxed against the abutting lot or lots. In case any person or corporation shall
fail, neglect, or refuse to comply with the provisions of this chapter, then,
and in that event, the city shall cause sidewalks to be constructed as herein
provided, and the costs of the same shall be taxed to and become a lien upon
the abutting lot or lots. (1983 Code § 14-108)
7-1A-5: PLANS FURNISHED BY CITY:
In any and all cases where this chapter fails to provide proper plans and
specifications for sidewalks, areas, coal chutes and curbs, then, in that
event, the city shall furnish plans and specifications, which shall be approved
by the city council, and upon such approval be binding. (1983 Code § 14-109)
7-1A-6: CONSTRUCTION WHERE PERMANENT SIDEWALKS NOT REQUIRED:
   A.   Construction Materials: Upon all streets or portions of streets,
avenues, and portions of avenues, where permanent sidewalks are not, or may not
be, required by ordinance, the sidewalks may be constructed either of the
materials named in this chapter, or of cinders or gravel, and shall be of such
width as the city council may direct.
   B.   Plank Or Board Walks: It is unlawful for any person to construct any
plank or board walks within the incorporated limits of the city, except across
ravines, draws, and gullies, when the same shall be constructed according to
the plans and specifications furnished by the city engineer. No plank or board
sidewalk that is now or may hereafter become unsafe or out of repair shall be
repaired, except in accordance with the requirements herein stated.
   C.   Consent Required: Any person desiring to repair any sidewalk which has
become unsafe or out of repair shall first obtain the consent of the city
council to make such repairs, and any repairs so made shall be under the
direction and supervision of the building inspector. (1983 Code § 14-110)
7-1A-7: GRADE FOR WALKS:
All walks to be constructed within the city shall be constructed upon the grade
to be furnished by the city. (1983 Code § 14-111)
7-1A-8: SIDEWALK SLOPE AND ELEVATION:
The slope of all sidewalks in the city upon all streets, where the grade and
curb lines have been established, or may hereafter be established, shall be as
provided by this section. The elevation of the sidewalk shall in all cases be a
rise from any point on the line of the curb which is next to the line of the
center of the street to a point on the property line directly opposite the
point on the same side of the street, and shall be at the uniform rate of three
one-hundredths of a foot (3/100') vertical height per one foot (1') horizontal
distance of the walk. (1983 Code § 14-114)
7-1A-9: CONDEMNATION OF SIDEWALKS:
The city council may at any time, by resolution, condemn any portion of any
defective sidewalk, whenever in its judgment it shall be deemed necessary, and
provide for the construction of a new sidewalk in accordance with the
provisions of this chapter. (1983 Code § 14-112)
7-1A-10: FAILURE OF OWNER TO COMPLY; CONSTRUCTION BY CITY:
In case any person, company or corporation shall fail, neglect, or refuse to
comply with any of the provisions of this chapter within twenty (20) days after
being served with notice by the building inspector that his or its walks have
been condemned and a new walk ordered built, then, and in that event, the city
council shall cause sidewalks to be constructed as above provided, and the
costs of the same shall be taxed and become a lien upon each separate abutting
lot, and collected as special assessments are by statute in such case made and
provided. (1983 Code § 14-113)
7-1A-11: REMOVAL OF CURBING:
   A.   Permit Required; Fee:
      1.   Any person, firm or corporation desiring to tear out or remove the
curbing, or any part hereof, along the sides of any street in the city for any
purpose whatsoever shall make application and receive from the city a permit
therefor. Such permit shall contain the information required by the city and
shall be made on a form to be supplied by the city. (1983 Code § 14-202)
      2.   A fee shall be charged for each permit issued to remove curbing for
the construction of driveways or for other purposes, which fee and permit shall
be paid and reported in the manner provided for other permits in this chapter.
The fee shall be set by resolution or motion of the city council. (1983 Code §
14-203)
   B.   Manner Of Removal: The base after the curbing is removed for such
driveways or other purposes shall be left in a good and workmanlike condition,
and the ends of the curbing at the sides of the driveway left in a finished and
sightly condition. (1983 Code § 14-204)
   C.   Disposal Of Broken Curbing: The old or broken curbing and all other
material so removed shall not be left on the parking or surface of the street,
but shall be hauled away and properly disposed of and the premises left
perfectly clean. (1983 Code § 14-205)
   D.   Approval Of Work; Inspection: The removing of such curbing, the
construction of the driveway and all other parts of the work in connection
therewith shall be subject to the inspection and approval of the city building
inspector. (1983 Code § 14-206)
7-1A-12: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter, upon conviction
thereof, shall be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1983 Code § 14-121)
ARTICLE B. STREET NAMES
SECTION:
7-1B-1: Names Of City Streets
7-1B-1: NAMES OF CITY STREETS:
The names of certain streets in the city shall be named and/or changed as
follows:

point on Industrial Road beginning approximately nine hundred feet (900') west
of the city sewage treatment facility is hereby named Coacoehee Road.
Anderson Street shall be named Seventeenth Street.
Apple Street shall be named Third Street.
Apricot Street shall be named Thirteenth Street.
Brady Street shall be named Sixteenth Street.

Church Street shall be named Fifth Street.

CHAPTER 2
BOATS AND BOATING ON MUNICIPAL LAKE
SECTION:
7-2-1: Boating Permit Requirements
7-2-2: Boat Dealers; Permit And Fee
7-2-3: Boating Rules And Regulations
7-2-4: Park And Lake Area Regulations
7-2-5: Fishing
7-2-6: Firearms Restrictions
7-2-7: Alcoholic Beverages And Low Point Beer Prohibited
7-2-8: Permit Forfeited For Reckless Acts
7-2-9: Nonliability Of City For Accidents
7-2-10: Applicability Of City Ordinances
7-2-11: Penalty
7-2-1: BOATING PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Required: No motorboat shall be operated, used or placed upon
the municipal lake by any person without the owner or operator of such boat
having first obtained a permit for the operation of the boat upon the lake as
herein provided. (1983 Code § 11-101)
   B.   Application For City License; Proof Of State License: Any person,
before placing, using or operating a motorboat upon the municipal lake, shall
make application to the city for a permit. The application shall be in such
form as the city may require. The applicant shall show proof of a current state
boat license issued by the state. (1983 Code § 11-102)
   C.   Annual Permit, Decal: Boating permits provided for herein shall be
issued on a yearly basis only, beginning upon January 1, with all permits
expiring December 31 of each year. Permit decals shall be placed on the left
front (port side) of each boat. (1983 Code § 11-103)
   D.   Permit Fee: There is hereby levied an annual fee chargeable to, and
which must be paid in advance by, the applicant before receiving a permit. The
fee shall be set from time to time by motion or resolution of the city council.
(1983 Code § 11-104)
7-2-2: BOAT DEALERS; PERMIT AND FEE:
Any person or firm in the business of buying, selling or dealing in motorboats
shall be charged a fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for a boating permit,
but such permit obtained by a dealer or person engaged in buying and selling of
boats may be transferred from one boat to another owned by such dealer. Any
boat being operated upon the municipal lake by a dealer shall have exhibited
thereon the regular boating permit, and in addition thereto shall have thereon
a tag or lettering "Boat Dealer". (1983 Code § 11-105)
7-2-3: BOATING RULES AND REGULATIONS:
   A.   Compliance With Regulations; Life Preservers:
      1.   All boats must observe the applicable regulations stated in this
chapter.
      2.   All persons both operating and riding in boats upon the lake shall
at all times have upon their person a life preserver. (1983 Code § 11-110)
   B.   Rules For Operation: For the protection and safety of all persons using
the municipal lake in any manner, the following rules for the operation of
boats upon the lake are hereby enacted:
      1.   All safety rules provided by the state for the use and operation of
boats are hereby adopted by reference.
      2.   No boat shall tow or pull more than two (2) skiers at one time.
      3.   A counterclockwise traffic pattern shall be maintained by all boat
operators.
      4.   There shall be no competitive racing of boats, either formally or
informally, without the approval of the city council. Boat races may be
approved by the city council after due process.
      5.   There shall be recreational swimming or wading in the lake at
designated areas only.
      6.   All boats shall be equipped with such a motor that terminates with
exhaust being discharged under water. (1983 Code § 11-107)
7-2-4: PARK AND LAKE AREA REGULATIONS:
   A.   General Operating Rules For Lake Park:
      1.   The city council, by recommendation of the recreational advisory
board, shall from time to time set certain general and specific rules and
regulations governing the operation of the lake park.
      2.   Regulations shall be posted at a point clearly visible to persons
entering the lake park. (1983 Code § 11-114)
   B.   Glass Containers Prohibited: All glass containers shall be prohibited
from the lake, lake park and lake area. (1983 Code § 11-113)
   C.   Licensed Vehicles Only: Licensed notarized vehicles are allowed only on
the existing roadways and no dune buggies, dirt bikes, three (3) wheelers or
four (4) wheelers shall be allowed at the lake. (1983 Code § 11-115)
7-2-5: FISHING:
   A.   Permit Required: The holder of a boating permit upon the municipal lake
shall be entitled to use the lake for fishing while such permit is in force and
effect. (1983 Code § 11-106)
   B.   Rules And Regulations:
      1.   Compliance With State Laws: All fishermen shall comply with the
fishing laws of the state.
      2.   Trotline Or Jug Line Fishing:
         a.   Trotline fishing shall be permitted only in the area north of
section two (2), for a maximum of forty eight (48) hours, outside of any boat
pattern.
         b.   All lines must have a name tag attached.
         c.   Jug line fishing shall be permitted at any location on the lake
between October 1 and April 1 and shall be permitted year round at all areas
north of the rock building; provided, that the lines shall be within fifty feet
(50') of the shore.
         d.   No more than five (5) jugs per person with two (2) fishing hooks
per jug shall be permitted.
      3.   Large Mouth Bass: It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his
possession any large mouth bass less than fourteen inches (14") in length.
(1983 Code § 11-117)
7-2-6: FIREARMS RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Prohibited In Boats: Firearms of any type shall be prohibited from
being transported or carried in boats upon the lake at any time. (1983 Code §
11-111)
   B.   Use During Hunting Seasons: Only during recognized hunting seasons
shall firearms be permitted around the lake and for hunting purposes only.
(1983 Code § 11-112)
7-2-7: ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES AND LOW POINT BEER PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person, regardless of age, to drink any alcoholic
beverage or low point beer, or to have in his or her possession an opened
container of such beverages, regardless of whether or not the same be the
original container in which such beverage was purchased, while such person is
upon any property owned or maintained by the city lying adjacent to the
municipal lake known as Wewoka Lake or while in or upon any boat, raft, or
other craft, or while swimming or wading in Wewoka Lake. (1983 Code § 11-118;
amd. 2005 Code)
7-2-8: PERMIT FORFEITED FOR RECKLESS ACTS:
Any person holding a boating permit as herein provided who violates any of the
provisions of this chapter or who by reason of the operating of his boat in a
reckless, dangerous or careless manner so as to endanger the life and safety of
others, or who by reason of any physical or emotional disability or incapacity
cannot or does not operate his boat consistent with this chapter and with care
and caution, shall forfeit all rights to use the lake, and his permit may be
revoked by the issuing officer without rebate for any fee paid. (1983 Code §
11-108)
7-2-9: NONLIABILITY OF CITY FOR ACCIDENTS:
The boating and skiing privileges provided for and designated in this chapter
shall be deemed a privilege granted to the persons operating boats and using
the municipal lake for the purposes herein designated and the city shall not be
liable nor responsible in any manner for any accidents resulting in injuries or
damages that may occur or result by reason of such use, operation and
activities. (1983 Code § 11-109)
7-2-10: APPLICABILITY OF CITY ORDINANCES:
All ordinances of the city now in effect within the city are hereby extended to
all real property owned by the city at Lake Wewoka, as they may be applicable.
(1983 Code § 11-116)
7-2-11: PENALTY:
The violation of any of the provisions of this chapter and the rules herein
provided for the operation of motorboats upon the municipal lake shall
constitute a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, such operator or
offender shall be punished as provided by section
1-4-1 of this code. If violations continue to excess, then boat permits may be
revoked. (Ord. 423, 7-8-1997)
CHAPTER 3
MUNICIPAL CEMETERIES
SECTION:
7-3-1: Boundaries Of Cemeteries; Names
7-3-2: Supervision By Cemetery Department
7-3-3: Cemetery Care Committee
7-3-4: Police Power Over Cemeteries
7-3-5: Burial Spaces; Services; Lots And Prices
7-3-6: Cemetery Care Fund; Disposition Of Monies
7-3-7: Administering Sale Of Lots; Deeds
7-3-8: Application For Purchase Of Lots; Record Of Sales
7-3-9: Approval Of Monument Plans, Other Improvements
7-3-10: Monuments And Markers
7-3-11: Concrete Or Metal Outside Burial Containers
7-3-12: Rules And Regulations
7-3-13: Restrictions On Sundays, Legal Holidays
7-3-14: Burial Of Paupers
7-3-15: Injuring Or Removing Cemetery Property
7-3-16: Indemnification Of City
7-3-1: BOUNDARIES OF CEMETERIES; NAMES:
   A.   Oakwood Cemetery:
      1.   The boundaries of Oakwood cemetery shall be as follows:
Brown Township; Beginning Southwest corner; Lot 3, North 311 yards by East 311
yards, by South 311 yards by West 311 yards to beginning 32-8-8;
Parts of Lots Three (3) and Six (6), being located in part of the Northwest
Quarter (NW1/4) and part of the Southwest Quarter (SW1/4) of section 32,
Township 8 North, Range 8 East, Seminole County, Oklahoma, and described by
metes and bounds as follows: Beginning at the Northwest Corner of the Southwest
quarter (SW1/4) of 32-8N-8E, thence North One Hundred Sixty-five (165) feet to
the point of beginning, thence East Nine Hundred and Twenty-one (921) feet,
thence South Four Hundred Sixty-six (466) feet, thence West Nine Hundred and
Twenty-one (921) feet, thence North Four Hundred and Sixty-six (466) feet to
the point of beginning, containing ten (10) acres, more or less;
A tract of land in Lot 6, Section 32-8N-8E, described as commencing at the NW
Corner of Lot 6; thence South 301.8' for a point of beginning; thence South
616'; thence East 662'; thence North 426'; thence East 404.7'; thence North
491.8'; thence West 133.7'; thence South 301.8'; thence West 933' to the point
of beginning, containing 11.911 acres more or less; and
A tract of land in Lot 3, section 32-8N-8E, described as commencing at a point
1155' South of the NW Corner of Lot 3; thence 933' East for a point of
beginning; thence South 165'; thence East 133.7'; thence North 165'; thence
West 133.7' to the point of beginning, containing .505 acres, more or less, all
in Seminole County, Oklahoma.
      2.   The above described tracts are officially named "Oakwood Cemetery".
(1983 Code § 11-301)
   B.   Westwood Cemetery:
      1.   The boundaries of Westwood Cemetery shall be as follows:
Beginning at the northwest corner of the northeast quarter of section 23-8N-7E,
thence south 420 feet to the point of beginning; thence east 210 feet; thence
south 210 feet; thence west 210 feet; thence north 210 feet to the point of
beginning, containing one acre more or less; and
The east half of the northeast quarter of the northeast quarter of the
northwest quarter (E/2 of NE/4 of NE/4 of NW/4) of section 23-8N-7E, containing
five (5) acres more or less; and
A tract of land lying in the northwest quarter of the northeast quarter (NW/
4 of NE/4) of section 23, Township 8 North, Range 7 East, being described as
beginning south 89°35'38" east 201.58 feet and south 00°16'12" west 41.46 feet
of the northwest corner of said NW/4 of NE/4, said point being on the south
right-of-way line of U.S. Highway No. 270; thence south 89°22'35" east along
said right-of-way line a distance of 111 feet; thence south 00°16'02" west a
distance of 596.45 feet; thence south 87°43'29" west a distance of 311.45 feet
to the west line of said NW/4 NE/4; thence north 00°06'41" east along said west
line a distance of 32.06 feet; thence north 87°43'29" east a distance of 200.44
feet; thence north 00°16'02" east a distance of 570.04 feet to the point of
beginning, containing 1.647 acres more or less.
      2.   The above described tracts are officially named "Westwood Cemetery".
(1983 Code § 11-302)
7-3-2: SUPERVISION BY CEMETERY DEPARTMENT:
The cemetery department, subject to the city administrator, shall have control
and supervision of the cemeteries belonging to the city, the same being what is
known as Oakwood Cemetery and Westwood Cemetery. (1983 Code § 11-303)
7-3-3: CEMETERY CARE COMMITTEE:
   A.   Appointments; Terms; Qualifications:
      1.   There is hereby established a cemetery care committee consisting of
not more than nine (9) members, to be appointed by the mayor, subject to
approval by the city council. Of the first nine (9) appointees, three (3) shall
serve an initial term of one year; three (3) shall serve an initial term of two
(2) years; and three (3) shall serve an additional term of three (3) years.
Thereafter appointments shall be for a term of three (3) years.
      2.   Only residents of the city, persons having family members buried
within the city's cemeteries or persons owning burial lots or spaces within the
city's cemeteries shall be eligible for appointment.
   B.   Duties; Implementation And Enforcement Of Rules: The committee may make
proposals concerning changes, additions or deletions in the rules and
regulations governing the operation and maintenance of the city's cemeteries.
The committee shall, with approval of the city council, assist in the
implementation, adoption and enforcement of rules and regulations governing the
city's cemeteries.
   C.   Council Approval Of Rules: No rules, regulations or other acts of the
committee shall be enforced unless approved by the city council. (1983 Code §
11-327)
7-3-4: POLICE POWER OVER CEMETERIES:
The city shall have police power and control of each of the city cemeteries.
The city administrator shall have the authority to direct and require the
removal of any marker, monument or other improvement in the cemetery which does
not comply with the provisions of this chapter and to require restoration of
the location from which such improvements are removed. (1983 Code § 11-306)
7-3-5: BURIAL SPACES; SERVICES; LOTS AND PRICES:
   A.   Fees Imposed: The prices for burial spaces and lots in Oakwood Cemetery
and Westwood Cemetery shall be determined by resolution adopted by a majority
of the city council. (1983 Code § 11-304; amd. 2005 Code)
   B.   Surcharge For Certain Funerals: There is hereby established a surcharge
per hour, as approved by the city council, for funerals entering city
cemeteries after three thirty o'clock (3:30) P.M. on weekdays. (1983 Code § 11-
305; amd. 2005 Code)
7-3-6: CEMETERY CARE FUND; DISPOSITION OF MONIES:
Not less than twenty five percent (25%) of all monies received from the sale of
lots and interments shall be segregated and set aside as a permanent fund to be
known as a "cemetery care fund". This fund or any part thereof may be invested
by the city council in certificates of deposit; and the interest received
therefrom may be used in improving, caring for and embellishing the roads,
walks, drives and parks and the necessary improvements on each respective
cemetery. (1983 Code § 11-307)
7-3-7: ADMINISTERING SALE OF LOTS; DEEDS:
   A.   Issuance Of Deed:
      1.   All lots in the city cemeteries will be under the administration of
the city administrator.
      2.   When a lot is sold by the city, a deed will be issued to the
purchaser granting to the purchaser the exclusive right and privilege of using
the lot or lots for the sole purpose of burying members of his or her family,
or any other person which the purchaser or owner may designate in writing.
      3.   The deed issued by the city for cemetery lots shall not be
assignable or transferable except by written instrument submitted to and noted
on the records of the city.
   B.   Redemption Or Repurchase Of Lots By City: The city may redeem or
repurchase any lots within the city cemeteries on presentation by the owner of
the deed describing the lot or lots, at a price equal to one-half (1/2) of the
original cost of the same when originally purchased from the city.
   C.   Commercial Sales Limited To City Only: The commercial sale of lots or
burial sites within the city cemeteries is hereby limited, exclusively, to
sales by the city, and no other person, firm, corporation or entity shall
engage in the commercial sale thereof.
   D.   Conveyance Of Lots; Fee:
      1.   When the record owner of any burial space or lot within the city
cemeteries desires to assign or transfer the same, such conveyance or
assignment must be submitted to the city clerk and noted on the city records.
      2.   No such transfer shall be made until a fee in the sum of ten dollars
($10.00) shall be paid to the city clerk for recording the transfer.
   E.   Authorization Required To Perform Work: No work to erect or install any
marker, monument or other improvement shall begin without written authorization
from the cemetery supervisor. (1983 Code § 11-308)
7-3-8: APPLICATION FOR PURCHASE OF LOTS; RECORD OF SALES:
Applicants interested in buying a lot shall contact the cemetery supervisor or
the city clerk to obtain a description of the lot and block desired, which lot
shall be purchased at the office of the city clerk. The city clerk shall keep a
file of all lots showing the same by plat together with the cost for which each
lot shall be sold. Such lots shall be sold on the same and equal terms to
applicants upon request to the city clerk and upon payment of the price for the
same without discrimination. (1983 Code § 11-309)
7-3-9: APPROVAL OF MONUMENT PLANS, OTHER IMPROVEMENTS:
   A.   Approval And Supervision:
      1.   No monument, marker, or other improvement shall be placed or erected
in the city cemeteries without the prior written approval of the cemetery
supervisor.
      2.   Plans for all markers, monuments or other improvements shall be
submitted to the city supervisor for approval before being contracted for by
the lot or space owner.
      3.   The actual erection and installation of all monuments, markers or
other improvements shall be under the supervision of the cemetery supervisor.
      4.   If the cemetery supervisor shall find that the proposed marker,
monument or other improvement complies with all rules and regulations of this
chapter, then the same may be approved. No approval shall be granted for any
monument, marker or other improvement which does not fully comply with all
regulations established by the city.
   B.   Construction Specifications: All monuments, markers or other
improvements shall be erected on a suitable foundation of solid masonry.
Markers are to be centered at the head or foot of the burial space and shall be
placed in line with the row of markers theretofore in existence. Flat markers
shall not exceed the following sizes:
 
Single burial space 3 feet
Double burial space 6 feet
Triple burial space 9 feet
 
   C.   Compliance With Rules And Regulations: Every person, firm, corporation
or other entity who sells, erects, installs or places markers, monuments or
other improvements upon burial spaces within the city cemeteries shall be bound
by and shall abide by all rules and regulations of the city.
   D.   Cessation Of Work During Funeral: All work of any description shall
cease during funeral or interment services being held within one hundred fifty
feet (150') from the work site.
   E.   Certificate Of Insurance Required: Any person, firm, corporation or
other entity hired or employed to erect, install or place any marker, monument
or other improvement shall furnish the cemetery supervisor a current
certificate of insurance evidencing coverage for worker's compensation,
employer's liability, manufacturer's and contractor's liability, and such other
insurance in such amounts as may be required by the city administrator. (1983
Code § 11-310)
7-3-10: MONUMENTS AND MARKERS:
   A.   Definitions: For the purpose of this section, the following terms shall
have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
    MARKER: a stone placed at the head of a grave to indicate the location
thereof.
   MONUMENT: Any memorial structure eighteen inches (18") or more in height.
(1983 Code § 11-312)
   B.   Supervision Of Lot Arrangements: All monuments, markers, trees and any
other articles placed permanently on a lot shall be set under the direction of
the cemetery supervisor. (1983 Code § 11-311)
   C.   Position Of Corner Stones: All corner stones (lot markers) must be set
in concrete flush with the ground. (1983 Code § 11-313)
   D.   Location And Specifications:
      1.   All lots shall be so arranged that in addition to the monument there
is room for one marker for each burial space.
      2.   Markers shall be not less than ten inches (10") or over twelve
inches (12") in width and not less than eighteen inches (18") or over twenty
four inches (24") in length surface measurement and set flush with surface of
ground.
      3.   Only one marker shall be allowed at each grave, and it shall be
placed at the head of the grave flush with the ground. (1983 Code § 11-314)
      4.   All monuments must have at least a six inch (6") extension concrete
base flush with the ground and be approved by the cemetery supervisor before
the monument is erected or placed thereon.
      5.   All monuments placed on one-fourth (1/4) or one-half (1/2) lots must
be placed at the rear of the lot, on all full lots at the center of the lot.
(1983 Code § 11-315)
7-3-11: CONCRETE OR METAL OUTSIDE BURIAL CONTAINERS:
   A.   All caskets at any city owned cemetery must be interred inside a
concrete outside burial container.
   B.   All concrete outside burial containers will be installed under the
supervision of the caretaker.
   C.   Nothing herein shall prohibit the installation of metal outside burial
containers, but wooden outside burial containers are prohibited.
   D.   Any person, firm or corporation who violates the provision of this
section doing that which is prohibited, or by failing or refusing that which is
required, is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be
punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. In addition, violators must remove violation and replace
with a legal container at his own expense. (1983 Code § 11-328)
7-3-12: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
   A.   Curbs And Fences Prohibited; Height Of Mounds; No curbs or fences shall
be constructed, installed or allowed and no mound shall ever be raised above
ground level. (1983 Code § 11-316)
   B.   Flowers: In city cemeteries, only one regulation flower vase may be
used, or flowers and decorations may be hung in "saddles" on the monument or
upon the end of the monument base. Decorations shall be removed as to the
convenience of mowing of the cemetery under the direction of the cemetery
supervisor, and may be removed by the city whenever they become unsightly or
deteriorated. (1983 Code § 11-318)
   C.   Speed Limit On Cemetery Roads: It is unlawful to ride or drive through
or park in any municipally owned cemetery, except on the roadways therein, and
then at a speed of not more than ten (10) miles per hour. (1983 Code § 11-323)
   D.   Hours Cemetery Open: The cemetery gates shall be opened every day at
eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and shall be closed every day at sundown. (1983 Code
§ 11-325)
7-3-13: RESTRICTIONS ON SUNDAYS, LEGAL HOLIDAYS:
   A.   Funerals Prohibited:
      1.   Funerals on Sundays and legal holidays are hereby prohibited.
      2.   Legal holidays include New Year's Day, Washington's Birthday,
Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Columbus Day, Veterans Day,
Thanksgiving Day, day after Thanksgiving and Christmas Day. (1983 Code § 11-
319)
   B.   Opening, Closing Graves On Sunday:
      1.   It is the policy of the city to prohibit the city and its employees
from opening and closing graves on Sunday or legal holidays for the burial of
the dead, except in an extreme emergency affecting the health and safety of the
community. (1983 Code § 11-320)
      2.   In cases where the mayor finds that it is an extreme emergency to
either open or close a grave on Sunday, or a legal holiday, the mayor or city
administrator shall have the power and the right to declare an emergency and
permit an exception to the above provision and permit a grave to be opened and
closed on Sunday. (1983 Code § 11-321)
7-3-14: BURIAL OF PAUPERS:
When any person shall hereafter die within the city limits leaving no funds or
other property out of which to pay the expense of a certificate for a cemetery
lot for the burial of such person, upon an affidavit stating such facts being
signed by the next of kin of such deceased person, or in lieu thereof, by the
person in charge of the burial of such deceased person, and the presentation
thereof to the city clerk, such city clerk shall, without charge, issue a
burial certificate authorizing the burial of such deceased person on a lot,
such lot to be designated by the city clerk. Provided, however, if thereafter
any assets of such deceased person be found sufficient to pay the customary
charge for such burial certificate, the city shall have a first and prior lien
upon any and all assets belonging to such deceased person until such charge is
paid. (1983 Code § 11-322)
7-3-15: INJURING OR REMOVING CEMETERY PROPERTY:
   A.   Prohibited Acts: It is unlawful for any person except the cemetery
supervisor or his employees to injure or remove any tree, shrub or plant; or to
pluck flowers from any lot; or to deface any monument, tombstone, ornament on
any grave, or any fence; move any ornament at any grave; or to damage anything
whatsoever in such cemetery.
   B.   Reimbursement To City For Damages: Any damage caused to cemetery
property due to persons or vehicles on the driveways and roads or off of the
prescribed passages anywhere on cemetery property will be paid or reimbursed to
the city under the direction of the city administrator and subject to penalties
under the municipal court of the city. (1983 Code § 11-324)
7-3-16: INDEMNIFICATION OF CITY:
The owner of any burial lot or space or other person requesting or instructing
the burial of any person within the city cemeteries hereby indemnifies and
agrees to hold harmless the city of and from any and all claim, damage or cause
of action, arising out of the burial or interment of the remains of any person
so designated by the lot or space owner. (1983 Code § 11-326)
CHAPTER 4
LIBRARY
SECTION:
7-4-1: Library Department
7-4-2: Library Board
7-4-3: Head Librarian
7-4-4: Use Of Library Facility
7-4-1: LIBRARY DEPARTMENT:
   A.   Department Created: There is hereby created in the city a library
department for the purpose of providing free library service of a general
