nature for the citizens of the city.
   B.   Appointment; Meetings:
      1.   There shall be a library board which shall be comprised of six (6)
members, appointed by the mayor, with the approval of the city council.
      2.   The library board shall meet at regularly specified times. Such
meetings shall be open to the public in conformity to the Oklahoma open meeting
act 1 .
   C.   Term; Replacement Of Members: Members of the library board shall serve
for a term of three (3) years. The replacement of library board members caused
by the end of a term or by unusual or emergency situations shall be made at the
recommendation of the existing library board members, and appointed by the
mayor with the approval of the city council.
   D.   Officers Of Board: The library board shall appoint from its membership
a chairman, vice chairman and secretary-treasurer to serve for a term set by
the library board.
   E.   Quorum: A quorum for the transaction of business shall consist of four
(4) members.
   F.   Hiring Of Librarian: A head librarian and an assistant librarian shall
be hired by the city manager, at the recommendation of the library board. (1983
Code § 11-401)
 
Notes
1 1. 25 OS § 301 et seq.
7-4-2: LIBRARY BOARD:
   A.   Board Created; Function: The library board shall formulate and set
forth bylaws and general policies for the operation of the library, and shall
act in an advisory capacity for the upkeep and improvement of the library
facility.
   B.   Selection Of Materials; Formation Of Policies: Such bylaws and policies
shall regard the selection of materials; borrower's policy; circulation,
damage, and replacement policy; library equipment loan policy; and general
rules governing the operation of the library to adequately serve the public and
protect and preserve the library.
   C.   Amendment Of Bylaws, Policies: These bylaws and policies may be amended
at any regular meeting of the library board with a quorum present, by a two-
thirds (2/3) vote of the members present, provided the amendment was stated in
the call of the meeting.
   D.   Council Approval Required: Such bylaws, policies, and amendments shall
be adopted with the approval of the city council. (1983 Code § 11-402)
7-4-3: HEAD LIBRARIAN:
   A.   Duties, Generally: The head librarian shall have charge of the
administration of the library under the direction and review of the library
board, and the city manager. Said librarian shall be responsible for the
library equipment, the direction of the staff, the efficiency of the library's
service to the public, and for the operation of the library under the financial
conditions set forth in the annual budget as allocated by the city manager with
the approval of the city council.
   B.   Attend Board Meetings: The head librarian shall attend all library
board meetings, but as he is not a member of the library board, he shall have
no vote.
   C.   Annual Report To State: The librarian shall prepare and file with the
Oklahoma department of libraries an annual statistical report and such other
reports as are required according to the provisions of the Oklahoma library
code and regulations established thereunder. (1983 Code § 11-403)
7-4-4: USE OF LIBRARY FACILITY:
   A.   Use By Public Groups Allowed: Under rules and regulations as set forth
by the library board and approved by the city council, the library facility may
be used by public groups whenever it does not interfere with the daily routine
of the library's operation. The public gatherings may only be of a civic,
cultural, or educational nature.
   B.   Use Prohibited: The library facility shall not be used for private
gatherings of a social nature, money raising projects, or commercial purposes.
(1983 Code § 11-404)
CHAPTER 5
RAILROADS
SECTION:
7-5-1: Improvement Of Streets And Alleys
7-5-2: Sidewalks Constructed By Railroads
7-5-3: Climbing On Trains
7-5-1: IMPROVEMENT OF STREETS AND ALLEYS:
   A.   Tracks Within Or Adjacent To Streets: When a railway occupies any
portion of a street with its tracks running in a general direction of such
street, either on or adjacent thereto, the railway company shall improve the
space between its tracks and two feet (2') on either side thereof in the same
manner that the remainder of the street is to be, or has been, improved, or
with such other satisfactory material as the city council by motion or
resolution may approve.
   B.   Tracks Within Or Adjacent To Alleys: In case any railway company shall
occupy an alley with its track or tracks, such company shall improve, gutter,
drain, and grade such alley, and shall surface or pave it with the same
material which is to be, or has been, used on the alley, or with such other
satisfactory material as the council by motion or resolution may approve.
   C.   Crossing Streets:
      1.   When the tracks of any railroad company cross any street that is
being, or has been paved, the company shall pave as much of the street as is
occupied by its track or tracks and two feet (2') on each side, using the same
material as is to be, or has been, used on the street, or such other
satisfactory material as the council by motion or resolution may approve.
      2.   When more than one track crosses a street within a distance of one
hundred feet (100'), measuring from inside rail to inside rail, the railroad
company shall grade, gutter, drain, and curb the street area between its
tracks, and surface or pave it with the same material which the city is to use
or has used, on the street.
   D.   Maintenance: Railroad companies shall keep all such improvements made
by them in a good state of repair at all times. (1983 Code § 16-101)
7-5-2: SIDEWALKS CONSTRUCTED BY RAILROADS:
Railway companies shall construct sidewalks crossing their rights of way, using
the same material as is used in adjacent sidewalks insofar as this is
practicable under the circumstances. They shall construct sidewalks on both
sides of the streets when both sides are used by pedestrians. The company shall
keep such sidewalks in a good state of repair at all times. (1983 Code § 16-
102)
7-5-3: CLIMBING ON TRAINS:
It is unlawful for any person to climb upon, hold to, or in any manner attach
himself to, any railway train, locomotive, or railway car, while such is in
motion within the city, unless such person is acting in line of duty, or to
board any train or railroad car, including a passenger, freight, or other car,
except with a proper ticket or the permission of the person in charge of the
train or car or in line of duty. (1983 Code § 16-103)
CHAPTER 6
WEWOKA MUNICIPAL LAKE
ARTICLE A. LAKE PROTECTION ZONE (LPZ)
SECTION:
7-6A-1: Purpose
7-6A-2: Applicability
7-6A-3: Definitions
7-6A-4: Permitted Uses
7-6A-5: Prohibited Uses
7-6A-6: Development Standards
7-6A-7: Lakeshore Buffer
7-6A-8: Impervious Surface Coverage
7-6A-9: Hazardous Materials
7-6A-10: Septic System Standards
7-6A-11: Erosion Control
7-6A-12: Shared Driveways
7-6A-13: Drawing Water From Lake
7-6A-14: Penalty
7-6A-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of the lake protection zone (LPZ) is to protect public health,
safety and welfare and to ensure orderly development along and near Wewoka
Lake. It is an overlay zone that is applied as specified below. An overlay zone
is a set of zoning standards and regulations that are applied in addition to
the existing standards of the base zone. A special zoning district is necessary
to ensure adequate environmental protection for the lake, which serves as a
municipal water source for the city of Wewoka. (Ord. 483, 5-14-2013)
7-6A-2: APPLICABILITY:
The LPZ overlay zone applies equally to all leased lake lots surrounding the
lake and to privately owned lake site property. These requirements shall
supplement existing zoning and code provisions and where two (2) or more
provisions conflict, the more stringent interpretation shall prevail as
determined by the Wewoka city manager. These regulations shall not be extended
to city property or other leases, if any, that are not along the shoreline of
Wewoka Municipal Lake as determined by the city of Wewoka. These regulations
shall apply to leased and/or privately owned property situated along the
shoreline of Wewoka Municipal Lake as determined by the city of Wewoka. (Ord.
483, 5-14-2013)
7-6A-3: DEFINITIONS:
LAKE LOT LEASE: Those lease areas established by the city of Wewoka, most of
which were created at the time the lake was established as the city's primary
water source and additionally for the purposes of private recreational and
residential use. In general, such areas are a minimum one acre in size and
include the right to construct a permanent residence on the subject area. A
"lake lot lease" shall also include any newly created or defined lots that will
be leased now or in the future.
ORDINARY HIGH WATER MARK (OHWM): The line on the shore established by the
fluctuations of water and indicated by physical characteristics such as clear,
natural line impressed on the bank, shelving, changes in the character of the
soil, destruction of terrestrial vegetation, the presence of vegetation and/or
debris, or other appropriate means that consider the characteristics of the
surrounding area. The city shall have final authority in determining the OHWM.
(Ord. 483, 5-14-2013)
7-6A-4: PERMITTED USES:
Permitted uses are as specified below and shall not be superseded by the uses
listed in the underlying district:
Accessory uses customarily incidental and secondary to the uses permitted by
right.
Bed and breakfast, subject to the granting of a conditional use permit 1 .
Community buildings, buildings associated with clubs/civic organizations and
associations and similar uses as determined by the Wewoka city manager and
confirmed by the city council.
Guest cottages may be approved as an accessory use to an existing single-family
residence with an approved conditional use permit 2 , provided that a guest
cottage shall not exceed six hundred (600) square feet, shall not be sublet,
and shall share a common driveway with the main residence.
Home occupation.
Overnight camping for personal use (not a commercial campground), provided that
it is done in a contained unit (e.g., motor home, fifth wheel, travel trailer,
etc.) and the use is temporary and the unit does not remain on the site between
uses. Temporary use is considered a use, which does not exceed sixty (60) days
in a calendar year and does not include any single stay greater than fourteen
(14) days.
Single-family detached residences.
   A.   Manufactured and mobile homes, provided that any mobile or manufactured
home placed on the lake after the effective date hereof shall be multisectioned
construction. No singlewide mobile or manufactured homes shall be allowed, with
the exception of an approved guest cottage. A new singlewide manufactured or
mobile home shall be allowed as a replacement to an existing singlewide unit
that existed prior to January 1, 2000.
Other uses specifically authorized by the city of Wewoka via an approved permit
provided that such use shall conform to the underlying zoning district created
herein. (Ord. 483, 5-14-2013)
 
Notes
  1. An application for a conditional use permit within the LPZ zone shall
  provide public notice in accordance with the applicable section of the Wewoka
1 zoning code, provided that the notice requirements are amended as follows:
  Notice shall be mailed to all holders of leased property within 300 feet of
  the exterior boundaries of the subject lease. Additional mailed notice is not
  required.
  2. An application for a conditional use permit within the LPZ zone shall
  provide public notice in accordance with the applicable section of the Wewoka
2 zoning code, provided that the notice requirements are amended as follows:
  Notice shall be mailed to all holders of leased property within 300 feet of
  the exterior boundaries of the subject lease. Additional mailed notice is not
  required.
7-6A-5: PROHIBITED USES:
The following uses are expressly prohibited:
All uses not specifically listed as "permitted" above. (Ord. 483, 5-14-2013)
7-6A-6: DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS:
   A.   Lake Board Criteria For Permits On Docks And Ramps:
      1.   All uses specified herein shall require a permit.
      2.   Cement used in construction of ramp shall be three thousand (3,000)
psi, a minimum of four inches (4") thick and include sixteen inch (16") centers
with rebar.
      3.   All existing ramps will be capped with cement to meet the above
listed standards.
      4.   Construction of ramps shall be not less than fifteen to twenty feet
(15 - 20') from high water mark (HWM).
      5.   All dock construction will require a permit and meet required
construction specifications.
      6.   Building boat ramp or dock permit fee is one hundred dollars
($100.00).
      7.   New boat ramp construction must first obtain approval of construct
plans from the Wewoka park board before a construction permit will issue.
      8.   Existing boat ramps and docks must meet city standards within one
year from the effective date hereof.
      9.   All ramps will be required to be locked with chain or cable.
      10.   Annual boat ramp and dock fee permits are twenty five dollars
($25.00) per year.
      11.   Unauthorized use of permits shall subject the permit to revocation.
Individuals are responsible for their ramps and docks in this manner.
      12.   Permit holders shall obtain and post authorized signs and stickers
as required by these provisions.
         a.   Violation of any provisions set forth above shall constitute a
misdemeanor subjecting the offender to a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00)
plus costs.
         b.   Responsible for placement and displaying permit sign in visible
area to the lake ranger or city official.
   B.   Standards: The following development standards apply:
      1.   Setbacks, Other Standards: Building setbacks, area, density and
height standards are as follows:
Rear/lake front setback    15-20 feet from OHWM (residence)
Boat docks and boathouses:  
 Front/road setback       25 feet
 Side yard setback        15 feet
 Lot area                 As per lease no set standard
 Lot width                As per lease no set standard
 Frontage                 As per lease no set standard
 Building height          35 feet
Residential density        1 residential structure per lease area, with the
                           exception of 1 or more approved guest cottages
 
Existing structures that do not meet the above standards shall be considered
conforming uses and shall not be required to meet the new setback standards in
cases where more than fifty percent (50%) of the structure is damaged by fire,
flood, or other disaster.
      2.   Docks: Boat/fishing docks may be constructed, for the purposes of
this section, all lease and privately owned areas are assumed to have the right
to use the abutting shoreline to construct a single floating dock. The city of
Wewoka may charge an additional annual fee for dock area leases as provided
herein.
      3.   Requirements: Boat docks shall be governed by the following
requirements:
         a.   The placing, building, construction, demolition or removal of
boat docks on Wewoka Lake by a certified professional must first obtain from
the city of Wewoka a dock installer's permit and pay the required one hundred
dollar ($100.00) permit fee.
         b.   Permission to construct must be obtained from the city manager
before any boat dock work is initiated.
         c.   No chemical drums of either plastic or metal material shall be
used in the construction or repair of boat docks.
         d.   Permits with full identification shall be maintained in full view
while utilizing the permit.
         e.   All existing boat docks shall be required to conform to and be in
compliance with current state safety minimum requirements.
         f.   No living quarters will be allowed on boat docks and walkways.
         g.   No business will be permitted to be conducted on boat docks and
walkways.
         h.   No prolonged storage of chemicals or fuel will be permitted on
boat docks and walkways.
         i.   All boat docks shall be registered with the city of Wewoka and
said registration permit must be exhibited for public view.
         j.   No person will be permitted to maintain a floating residence upon
the lake. (Ord. 490, 4-8-2014)
7-6A-7: LAKESHORE BUFFER:
A twenty five foot (25') buffer is hereby established landward of the ordinary
high water mark on all leased lots for the purpose of watershed protection. The
general public shall not use this area, except during an emergency situation.
Within this buffer, leaseholders are encouraged to preserve existing native
vegetation. The area within the lakeshore buffer shall not be fenced.
Fertilizers and other chemicals shall not be used within the buffer area. (Ord.
483, 5-14-2013)
7-6A-8: IMPERVIOUS SURFACE COVERAGE:
The maximum coverage ratio shall be twenty percent (20%) inclusive of all
primary and secondary structures. Total impervious area shall not exceed thirty
percent (30%) of the leased area. Runoff from impervious surfaces, such as
rooftops and paved driveways, shall be directed to maximize infiltration.
Runoff water shall be maintained in sheet flow (not channelized flow) to the
maximum extent practicable. (Ord. 483, 5-14-2013)
7-6A-9: HAZARDOUS MATERIALS:
Hazardous materials including, but not limited to, solvents, oil, fertilizer,
gasoline and other materials shall be stored in an enclosed shed, garage or
other approved structure. New accessory structures other than boat docks shall
be set back from the OHWM a minimum of twenty five feet (25'). (Ord. 483, 5-14-
2013)
7-6A-10: SEPTIC SYSTEM STANDARDS:
Septic tanks shall be installed and inspected in accordance with the standards
set forth in section
7-6B-3 of this chapter. (Ord. 483, 5-14-2013)
7-6A-11: EROSION CONTROL:
All new residential construction shall employ erosion control and utilize best
management practices (BMPs) to control erosion and sedimentation during
construction. All exposed soil must be mulched. A temporary seeding or cover
crop must be used on sites where permanent ground cover will not be established
until the following years. A site will not be allowed to remain as bare ground
with the intention of planting the following growing season. Required erosion
control best management practices shall be in place prior to all land
disturbing activities. (Ord. 483, 5-14-2013)
7-6A-12: SHARED DRIVEWAYS:
Shared driveways may be utilized to prevent unnecessary disturbance of the
lakeside area. Residential leased and/or individually owned areas need not
front upon a dedicated public street. (Ord. 483, 5-14-2013)
7-6A-13: DRAWING WATER FROM LAKE:
Private landowners and those leasing property as defined herein shall be
permitted to the drawing of water from Wewoka Lake as provided herein: Private
landowners who desire to draw water from Wewoka Lake for private consumption
must first obtain a use permit from the city of Wewoka and pay the required use
fee as determined by the city manager.
   A.   A fifty dollar ($50.00) monthly permit shall be required for the
drawing of water from Wewoka Lake. Usage shall be subject to weather related
conditions and water usage shall be under the control and direction of the city
manager.
   B.   No commercial irrigation shall be allowed if said usage is directed for
the purpose of raising and selling products, filling of ponds or for oil and
water well drilling.
   C.   The permit allows usage of lake water for use upon the permittee's
premises for sprinkling or lawn watering. (Ord. 483, 5-14-2013)
7-6A-14: PENALTY:
Violation of any provisions set forth in this article shall constitute a
misdemeanor subjecting the offender to a fine of five hundred dollars
($500.00), plus costs. (Ord. 483, 5-14-2013)
ARTICLE B. BOATHOUSE/DOCK FACILITIES AND LOTS ON MUNICIPAL LAKE
SECTION:
7-6B-1: Use Of Property
7-6B-2: Boathouse/Dock Facilities; Liability Of City
7-6B-3: Inspection Of Lake Lot Septic/Waste Disposal Systems
7-6B-1: USE OF PROPERTY:
All lots individually owned and/or leased pursuant to this article and the
cabins or buildings constructed thereon, may be used for recreational or
residential purposes when in total compliance with all city codes and
ordinances. The lessee and/or private landowner shall at all times keep
premises clean and maintained in a sanitary condition. (Ord. 483, 5-14-2013)
7-6B-2: BOATHOUSE/DOCK FACILITIES; LIABILITY OF CITY:
   A.   In addition to the possession of the property privately owned or
leased, every lessee or private landowner under this article or under a lease
and/or permit from the city of Wewoka, shall have the right and privilege of a
site for a boathouse and boat dock on the land owned by the city adjoining and
immediately in front of the lot leased. The boathouse shall be erected and
maintained by and at the cost of the lessee and shall not exceed thirty feet by
thirty feet (30' x 30'). The boathouse shall never be used as a place of human
habitation and shall be the private property of the lessee, who shall have the
right of ingress and egress to and from the boathouse, subject to the rights of
the public as set forth in this section. Boathouses and docks shall be
maintained in good working order and shall not present a hazard to the general
public or create a nuisance.
   B.   All docks and boathouses located on arms or coves of Wewoka Municipal
Lake, shall not extend from the high water line into the lake more than one
hundred feet (100'). Docks and boathouses on Wewoka Municipal Lake leased lots,
which are adjacent to skiing and watercraft areas, shall not extend from the
high water line into the lake more than seventy five feet (75').
   C.   Flotation devices for docks and/or boathouses shall be constructed of
materials that are not corrosive and are environmentally safe for Wewoka
Municipal Lake.
   D.   Docks and/or boathouses shall not be anchored to or cross over side lot
lines of abutting lots. The connections of the dock or boathouse to the shore
shall be constructed in such a way as to allow the dock and/or boathouse to
float level on the lake during the lake's fluctuating water elevations.
   E.   Any person wishing to construct and/or alter a dock and/or boathouse on
Wewoka Municipal Lake exclusive of routine maintenance must obtain a building
permit from the city of Wewoka. Failure to obtain a building permit will be
considered grounds for the city to terminate the lease or take proper action
against the private landowner as necessary.
   F.   The lessee or private landowner shall agree to keep such lot and
boathouse and dock in a clean and sanitary condition and to maintain the lot
and boathouse and dock in a safe condition. The city as lessor shall in no
manner be liable to the lessee or private landowner for any damages suffered by
the lessee to such lot or boathouse or dock or the improvements thereon on
account of the rise and fall of the water line of the lake or for the
enlargement or decrease by the city of the size of the lake or on account of
any rule or regulation that may be adopted by the lessor governing the
regulations of the lake.
   G.   The private landowner and/or lessee shall agree to hold the city/lessor
free and harmless from all damages suffered by him or by any other person on
account of personal injuries or loss of property that may incur upon such lot,
boathouse or boat dock. (Ord. 483, 5-14-2013)
7-6B-3: INSPECTION OF LAKE LOT SEPTIC/WASTE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS:
City staff shall inspect each septic system or waste disposal system on all
leased lake lots or private land at Wewoka Municipal Lake once every five (5)
years. City staff will determine whether such system is safe and in good
working order in accordance with the appropriate city/state code requirements.
The inspection fee shall be seventy five dollars ($75.00). If the city staff
determines that such system is defective, the city will notify the landowner or
leaseholder that the system requires an inspection by representatives of the
state department of environmental quality and/or a certified sanitarian or
septic installer, to be paid for by the leaseholder. The private landowner or
leaseholder shall have sixty (60) days to have the department of environmental
quality inspect and correct any defects found in the system. The private
landowner or leaseholder must then supply the city with a certificate of
compliance from the department of environmental quality. Failure to correct the
defects in the system within the allotted time shall be grounds for the city to
cancel the lease of the leaseholder and/or take proper action against private
property owners as necessary. (Ord. 483, 5-14-2013)
TITLE 8
UTILITIES
CHAPTER 1
UTILITY SERVICES
SECTION:
8-1-1: Utility Department And Director
8-1-2: Authorized Inspections
8-1-3: Utility Fees And Billings
8-1-4: Utility Taps And Connections; Fees; Deposits
8-1-5: Failure To Pay Bills; Penalty, Services Disconnection And Application Of
Administrative Fees
8-1-1: UTILITY DEPARTMENT AND DIRECTOR:
A Utility Department is established for the City with responsibility for the
management, maintenance, care and operation of the City utilities. The head of
the Utility Department is the City Administrator. (1983 Code § 17-101)
8-1-2: AUTHORIZED INSPECTIONS:
The City Administrator and other personnel in the service of any Municipal
utility system may enter any private premises served by the Municipal utility
system at any reasonable times, and inspect the pipes and fixtures on the
premises. The consumer must answer fully, to the extent of his knowledge, all
reasonable questions relating to the service on his premises. (1983 Code § 17-
101)
8-1-3: UTILITY FEES AND BILLINGS:
   A.   Rates Set By Council:
      1.   All fees and charges in connection with any customer's use of the
City sanitary sewer system, the City water facility system, or the operation of
the City collection and disposal of refuse and garbage are billed in accordance
with applicable rates set by the City Council. (1983 Code § 17-102)
      2.   The City Council from time to time by ordinance or resolution shall
have the power to establish rates and charges governing all aspects of the City
utility services, including monthly service fees, connection fees and charges,
and deposits. (1983 Code § 17-105)
   B.   Monthly Billing: All fees and charges owing for any of these utility
services shall be billed on one monthly bill submitted to the customer each
month.
   C.   Due Date For Payment: The utility bills submitted under the terms of
this section shall be payable on or before the past due date which is printed
on the bill. (1983 Code § 17-102)
8-1-4: UTILITY TAPS AND CONNECTIONS; FEES; DEPOSITS:
   A.   Approval And Payment Of Tap Charge; Deposit:
      1.   The City Administrator shall approve any request for a water tap and
connection, a sewer tap on an existing line, or a sewer tap on a new line.
Prior to granting approval by the City Administrator, the customer shall have
paid the connection or tap charge as applicable and shall have made a utility
deposit as set by ordinance or resolution of the City Council.
      2.   The deposit shall serve as a guarantee for the payment of charges
for utility service and other amounts owed to the City in connection with the
utility service. It shall be held in trust by the City for the benefit of the
customer. When a customer's utility service is disconnected, the deposit, or
any part of such amount deposited which remains after all such charges and
amounts due the City have been satisfied, shall be returned to the customer.
      3.   Where the request for a water tap and connection, sewer tap on an
existing line or on a new line shall be made by an existing customer of the
City who has a favorable payment history with the City, the City Administrator
may waive the utility deposit for such subsequent or additional tap and
connection. (Ord. 402, 12-8-1992)
   B.   Fee For Reconnection Of Utility Service: A fee for reconnection of
utility service where the service has been turned off or a meter has been
disconnected by the City for any reason shall be set by the City Council. (1983
Code § 17-104)
8-1-5: FAILURE TO PAY BILLS; PENALTY, SERVICES DISCONNECTION AND APPLICATION OF
ADMINISTRATIVE FEES:
   A.   Failure To Pay; City Actions: Upon failure of any customer to pay any
part of a utility bill submitted by the City for any utility services pursuant
to section
8-1-3 of this chapter by the past due date which is printed on the bill, the
following actions and penalties may result:
      1.   A ten percent (10%) penalty of all amounts owing on a utility bill
may be added to any utility bill which is not paid by the past due date printed
on the bill.
      2.   The authorized agents of the City may disconnect or discontinue any
or all utility services to the customer after mailing or posting written notice
to the customer of the intent of the City to disconnect or discontinue at least
twenty four (24) hours prior to the discontinuance of any or all of the utility
services.
      3.   The authorized agents of the City may discontinue to furnish water
to any customer refusing or neglecting to pay all or any part of a utility bill
submitted after mailing or posting written notice to the customer at property
where the service will be discontinued of the intent of the City to disconnect
the water service.
   B.   Payment Of Charges And Administrative Fees Prior To Reconnection: If
any utility service is discontinued or disconnected pursuant to this section,
the City, or its agents, shall not reconnect or establish the services until
the full amount of any outstanding utility service bill is paid plus the
penalty provided in this section provided however, should a customer elect to
make arrangements for an installment payment plan for the amount due under this
section, a fifty dollar ($50.00) administrative fee shall be added to the
utility bill plus any other applicable charges or expenses in reconnecting or
reestablishing the service. (Ord. 507, 2-12-2018)
ARTICLE A. INFRASTRUCTURE IMPROVEMENTS; WATER AND SEWER HOOKUPS
SECTION:
8-1A-1: Infrastructure Improvement Grant
8-1A-2: Responsibilities Of Developers
8-1A-3: Employment Creation And Beneficiary Information
8-1A-4: Low And Moderate Income Households
8-1A-1: INFRASTRUCTURE IMPROVEMENT GRANT:
The city is a recipient of a CDBG-EDF infrastructure improvement grant from
ODOC and, therefore, is required to collect, maintain and report to ODOC
project employment creation and beneficiary information for both existing and
future entities that receive benefit from the new infrastructure improvements.
(Ord. 401, 8-11-1992)
8-1A-2: RESPONSIBILITIES OF DEVELOPERS:
All non-low and moderate income developers, landowners, commercial and
manufacturing businesses that will receive benefit from the new infrastructure
improvements either located in the industrial park area, the nursing home or
are adjacent to the improvements, shall be required to pay for their own water
and sewer yard lines and hookups to the city water and sewer systems in the
area served by the improvements, and to provide employment creation and
beneficiary information. (Ord. 401, 8-11-1992)
8-1A-3: EMPLOYMENT CREATION AND BENEFICIARY INFORMATION:
   A.   Information Required: Each entity hooking up to the city water and
sewer service shall provide employment creation and beneficiary information to
the city on a quarterly basis for a period of at least two (2) years after the
original CDBG-EDF project (ODOC contract #5051 CDBG-EDF 91) achieves final
close out.
   B.   Employment Creation Information: Employment creation information shall
consist of the following:
      1.   A listing, by job title, of the permanent full time equivalent jobs
to be filled and actually filled; a listing, by job title of which jobs were
made available to low and moderate income persons; and a description of how
first consideration was given to low and moderate income persons for those jobs
which address the hiring process used; the number of low and moderate income
persons interviewed or considered for each job, and the number of low and
moderate income persons actually hired.
      2.   A description of how the low and moderate income status of those
hired was determined.
      3.   A job tracking log on every job resulting from the CDBG-EDF
assistance and the characteristics of the individuals in such form as
prescribed by ODOC.
   C.   Beneficiary Information: Beneficiary information shall consist of the
following:
      1.   The total number of individuals that will receive benefit from the
project improvements;
      2.   The total number and percent of individuals that are defined as low
and moderate income households that will receive benefit from the project
improvements; and
      3.   A brief description of how the improvements benefit the individual.
(Ord. 401, 8-11-1992)
8-1A-4: LOW AND MODERATE INCOME HOUSEHOLDS:
   A.   Description: For purposes of this article, the definition of "low and
moderate income households" is as follows:
FY 1991 Median Family Income Income Limits
FY 1991 Median Family Income Income Limits
   1 person               $14,650.00
   2 persons              16,750.00
   3 persons              18,850.00
   4 persons              20,950.00
   5 persons              22,650.00
   6 persons              24,300.00
   7 persons              26,000.00
   8 persons              27,650.00
 
   B.   Consideration Of Full Combined Household Income: Potential entities
(businesses)/individuals that propose to create employment or benefit should
consider a potential job applicant's or benefiting household's full combined
household income from all possible sources from their previous twelve (12)
months' wages, dividends, interest, salary, commissions, tips, cash bonuses
earned and persons. Potential hookup entities must be aware that any given
household can have more than one family residing within it. (Ord. 401, 8-11-
1992)
CHAPTER 2
WATER SYSTEM
SECTION:
8-2-1: Water System As Public Utility
8-2-2: Water Rates
8-2-3: Turning On Water
8-2-4: Separate Connections; Cross Connection Prohibited
8-2-5: Fluoride Content In Water
8-2-6: Water Shortages; Emergency Declaration
8-2-1: WATER SYSTEM AS PUBLIC UTILITY:
The water system of the city is hereby declared to be a public utility and a
proper source of city revenues and expenditures for the upkeep and maintenance
of the water system. (1983 Code § 17-201)
8-2-2: WATER RATES:
The city council shall from time to time by ordinance or resolution set or
amend the fees and charges for water use by customers of the city water system.
A copy of the current fees or charges shall be kept on file in the city clerk's
office. (1983 Code § 17-202)
8-2-3: TURNING ON WATER:
   A.   Permission Required: It is unlawful for any person to turn the water on
to any premises from the municipal water system, except by permission of the
city administrator.
   B.   Plumbing Installations; Deposits And Charges Paid: Water shall not be
turned on until the plumbing has been installed and is in operation as provided
by ordinance and until any and all deposits and charges have been paid. The
city administrator will see that the water is turned on when all requirements
for service have been complied with. Licensed plumbers shall be permitted to
turn water on and off.
   C.   Special Turn On Or Off Fee: For turning water on and off by city crews
between the hours of five o'clock (5:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.,
Monday through Friday and at any time Saturday or Sunday, a special fee shall
be assessed as set by the city. (1983 Code § 17-205)
8-2-4: SEPARATE CONNECTIONS; CROSS CONNECTION PROHIBITED:
Not more than one premises may be connected to any one tap. No customer shall
make or permit to be made any subsidiary connection of another's premises with
his water service, except for those existing as of January 1, 1983. A cross
connection with another water supply shall not be permitted. (1983 Code § 17-
204)
8-2-5: FLUORIDE CONTENT IN WATER:
In order to protect the health and welfare of the citizens of the city, the
quantity of fluoride in the public water supply shall be controlled in such a
manner that the amount present in the water served to the public shall be in
conformity with the policy, and subsequent changes thereto, established by the
Oklahoma state board of health. (1983 Code § 17-203)
8-2-6: WATER SHORTAGES; EMERGENCY DECLARATION:
   A.   Declaration Of Emergency:
      1.   Whenever an emergency exists by reason of a shortage of water due to
inadequate supply, limited treatment or distribution capacity or failure of
equipment or materials, the city administrator is hereby authorized to restrict
or prohibit the use of water from the city water system.
      2.   An emergency exists whenever the city administrator reasonably
determines that the city water system is unable, or will within sixty (60) days
become unable, to supply the full commercial and domestic needs of the users
thereof, including adequate fire protection. (1983 Code § 17-206)
   B.   Restriction On Water Use:
      1.   Upon the determination that such an emergency exists, the city
administrator shall issue a proclamation declaring the emergency and setting
out with particularity an order restricting use of water from the city system.
The order may:
         a.   Restrict water usage during certain periods of the day or week or
according to any orderly and nondiscriminatory scheme; and
         b.   Prohibit usages not essential to public health and safety. The
order may be revised from time to time as the city administrator deems
necessary.
      2.   A duly proclaimed emergency shall continue and the terms of the
proclamation shall be in force for thirty (30) days or until such time as the
city administrator shall cause to be published a proclamation that the
emergency has ended, whichever is shorter; unless the city council, by
resolution approved by a majority of all its members, votes to terminate the
emergency and proclamation upon a different date. (1983 Code § 17-207)
   C.   Proclamation And Notice Of Emergency:
      1.   The proclamation required by the preceding subsection shall be
published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city or, if there is no
such newspaper in which the proclamation may be published within twenty four
(24) hours after the emergency arises, publication shall be by posting a copy
of the proclamation in ten (10) prominent places in the city. The emergency
shall be in full force and effect upon publication. Substantial compliance with
this subsection is sufficient to effect the emergency.
      2.   Whenever a sudden or unexpected event so reduces the availability of
water or water pressure as to create an immediate threat to public health or
safety, the notice of the proclamation may be given by any reasonable means,
including electronic means. The emergency shall be in full force and effect
upon such notice. However, if any means other than that required in subsection
C1 of this section is used, the proclamation shall be republished in accordance
with subsection C1 of this section within twenty four (24) hours of the first
notice. (1983 Code § 17-208)
   D.   Grievances With Water Restrictions: Any person feeling aggrieved by a
proclamation of the city administrator shall have the right to present the
matter to the next regular or special meeting of the city council or to any
emergency session called to discuss the water emergency. The council may exempt
such aggrieved person, wholly or in part, from compliance with the proclamation
order upon a showing that compliance creates an immediate threat to the
person's health or safety. The ruling of the council by a majority vote of all
its members shall be final and binding as to the continuance of any terms of
the proclamation. Until and unless the action of the city administrator is
modified or revoked by action of the council, all water users shall be bound by
the proclamation. (1983 Code § 17-209)
   E.   Penalty: Any person who in any manner directly or indirectly violates
or permits others under his supervision, custody or control to violate any term
of a duly published proclamation shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Any
violation of the provisions of the city administrator's proclamation or action
of the council shall be punishable by a fine or imprisonment as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this code. (1983 Code § 17-210)
CHAPTER 3
SEWER SYSTEM
SECTION:
8-3-1: Sewer System As Public Utility
8-3-2: Connection To Sewer System
8-3-3: Sewer Rates And Charges
8-3-1: SEWER SYSTEM AS PUBLIC UTILITY:
The operation of the city sanitary sewer system is hereby declared to be a
public utility and a proper source of city revenues and expenditures for the
upkeep and maintenance of the sewer system. (Ord. 399, 7-14-1992)
8-3-2: CONNECTION TO SEWER SYSTEM:
Each residential unit, mobile home unit, apartment unit, single- family
dwelling, business, industrial or commercial user of the sewer system shall be
connected to the city water system before the connection for sewer service is
made; provided, that nothing in this section shall require any existing water
customer who is not also a user of the sewer system to make such connection
unless and until the current disposal system of such resident is terminated or
abandoned. (Ord. 399, 7-14-1992)
8-3-3: SEWER RATES AND CHARGES:
   A.   Fees Set By Council: The city council shall, from time to time by
ordinance or resolution, set or amend the fees and charges for sewer use by
customers of the city sewer system. A copy of the current fees or charges shall
be kept on file in the city clerk's office. (1983 Code § 17-302)
   B.   Monthly Charges:
      1.   Each residential unit, mobile home unit, apartment unit or other
single-family dwelling unit in the city for which the sewer system is made
available by the city, its agents, servants, employees or contractors, shall be
assessed a minimum monthly charge each month for use of the sewer system and an
additional charge for volume of gallons of water used.
      2.   Each respective business, industrial or commercial user thereof,
regardless of structural arrangement, shall be assessed a monthly charge for
use of the sanitary sewer system based upon the volume of sewage discharged
into the city system. The minimum monthly charge shall be based upon metered
and/or unmetered water consumption, with a minimum monthly charge and an
additional charge per unit for volume of gallons of water used. (1983 Code §
17-303)
   C.   Industrial Cost Recovery System: At the time that an industry locates
in the city that will be generating any sewage waste other than domestic waste,
the city will develop an industrial cost recovery system. (1983 Code § 17-304)
   D.   Certain Wastes Subject To Surcharge:
      1.   Where industrial wastes having excessive concentrations of suspended
solids or biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) are permitted to be discharged into
the city sewer system, a surcharge shall be levied in addition to the charges
established under the rate schedule. The surcharge shall be five-tenths percent
(0.5%) for each ppm of suspended solids in excess of the normal concentration
of two hundred (200) parts per million, and five- tenths percent (0.5%) for
each ppm of BOD in excess of the normal concentration of two hundred twenty two
(222) parts per million. (1983 Code § 17-305)
      2.   The code enforcement officer shall determine the quantity and
strength of the waste, or the user may install measuring devices and perform
tests satisfactory to the code enforcement officer, and the results thereof may
be used to compute the amount of the surcharge. (1983 Code § 17-305; amd. 2005
Code)
ARTICLE A. WASTEWATER COLLECTION AND TREATMENT
SECTION:
8-3A-1: Purpose And Policy
8-3A-2: Abbreviations
8-3A-3: Definitions
8-3A-4: Prohibited Discharge Standards
8-3A-5: Emergency Suspensions
8-3A-6: Monitoring
8-3A-1: PURPOSE AND POLICY:
   A.   This article sets forth uniform requirements for direct or indirect
contributors into the wastewater collection and treatment system for the city
and enables the city to comply with all applicable state and federal laws
required by the clean water act of 1977 and the general pretreatment
regulations (40 CFR part 403.5).
   B.   The objectives of this article are:
      1.   To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the publicly owned
treatment works that will interfere with its operation;
      2.   To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the publicly owned
treatment works that will pass through the publicly owned treatment works,
inadequately treated, into receiving waters, or otherwise be incompatible with
the publicly owned treatment works;
      3.   To protect both publicly owned treatment works personnel, who may be
affected by the wastewater and sludge in the course of their employment, and
the general public;
      4.   To promote reuse and recycling of industrial wastewater and sludge
from the publicly owned treatment works; and
      5.   To enable the city to comply with its national pollutant discharge
elimination system permit conditions, sludge use and disposal requirements, and
any other state and federal laws to which the publicly owned treatment works is
subject.
   C.   This article shall apply to all users of the publicly owned treatment
works. (Ord. 426, 12-9-1997)
8-3A-2: ABBREVIATIONS:
The following abbreviations, when used in this article, shall have the
designated meanings:
BOD   Biochemical oxygen demand
CFR   Code of federal regulations
COD   Chemical oxygen demand
EPA   U.S. environmental protection agency
mg/l  Milligrams per liter
NPDES National pollutant discharge elimination system
POTW  Publicly owned treatment works
USC   United States Code
 
(Ord. 426, 12-9-1997)
8-3A-3: DEFINITIONS:
Unless a provision explicitly states otherwise, the following terms and
phrases, as used in this article, shall have the meanings hereinafter
designated:
ACT OR THE ACT: The federal water pollution control act, also known as the
clean water act, as amended, 33 USC section 1251 et seq.
BIOCHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND OR BOD: The quantity of oxygen utilized in the
biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedures
for five (5) days at twenty degrees centigrade (20°C), usually expressed as a
concentration (e.g., mg/l).
CITY: The city of Wewoka.
ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY OR EPA: The U.S. environmental protection
agency or, where appropriate, the regional water management division director,
or other duly authorized official of said agency.
INTERFERENCE: A discharge, which alone or in conjunction with a discharge or
discharges from other sources, inhibits or disrupts the POTW, its treatment
processes or operation or the sludge processes, use or disposal and, therefore,
is the cause of a violation of the city NPDES permit (including an increase in
magnitude or duration of the violation) or of the prevention of sewage sludge
use or disposal in compliance with any of the following statutory/regulatory
provisions, or any more stringent state or local regulations: section 405 of
the act; the solid waste disposal act, including title II commonly referred to
as the resource conservation and recovery act (RCRA); any state regulations
contained in any state sludge management plan prepared pursuant to subtitle D
of the solid waste disposal act; the clean air act; the toxic substances
control act; and the marine protection, research, and sanctuaries act.
PASS THROUGH: A discharge which exits the POTW into the waters of the United
States in quantities or concentrations which, alone or in conjunction with a
discharge or discharges from other sources, is a cause of a violation of any
requirement of the city NPDES permit, including an increase in the magnitude or
duration of a violation.
pH: The logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the concentration of hydrogen
ions measured in grams per liter of solution and expressed in standard units
(SU).
POLLUTANT: Dredged soil, solid waste, incinerator residue, filter backwash,
sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, medical wastes, chemical wastes,
biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discarded
equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt, municipal, agricultural, and industrial
wastes, and certain characteristics of wastewater (e.g., pH, temperature, TSS,
turbidity, color, BOD, COD, toxicity, or odor).
PRETREATMENT STANDARDS OR STANDARDS: Prohibited discharge standards,
categorical pretreatment standards, and local limits.
PROHIBITED DISCHARGE STANDARDS OR PROHIBITED DISCHARGES: Absolute prohibitions
against the discharge of certain substances; those prohibited in section
8-3A-4 of this article.
PUBLICLY OWNED TREATMENT WORKS OR POTW: A "treatment works" as defined by
section 212 of the act (33 USC section 1292) which is owned by the city. This
definition includes any devices or systems used in the collection, storage,
treatment, recycling, and reclamation of sewage or industrial wastes of a
liquid nature and any conveyances, which convey wastewater to a treatment
plant.
SEWAGE: Human excrement and gray water (household showers, dishwashing
operations, etc.).
SUPERINTENDENT: The person designated by the city to supervise the operation of
the POTW, and who is charged with certain duties and responsibilities by this
article or a duly authorized representative.
USER OR INDUSTRIAL USER: A source of indirect discharge. (Ord. 426, 12-9-1997)
8-3A-4: PROHIBITED DISCHARGE STANDARDS:
   A.   General Prohibitions: No user shall introduce or cause to be introduced
into the POTW any pollutant or wastewater which causes pass through or
interference. These general prohibitions apply to all users of the POTW whether
or not they are subject to categorical pretreatment standards or any other
national, state or local pretreatment standards or requirements.
   B.   Specific Prohibitions: No user shall introduce or cause to be
introduced into the POTW the following pollutants, substances or wastewater:
      1.   Pollutants which create fire or explosion hazard in the POTW,
including, but not limited to, wastestreams with a closed cup flashpoint of
less than one hundred forty degrees Fahrenheit (140°F) (60°C) using test
methods specified in 40 CFR 261.21.
      2.   Pollutants which will cause corrosive structural damage to the POTW
or equipment, but in no case discharges with a pH lower than 5.0.
      3.   Solid or viscous pollutants in amounts which will cause obstruction
to the flow in the POTW resulting in interference.
      4.   Any pollutant, including oxygen demanding pollutants (BOD, etc.)
released in a discharge at a flow rate and/or pollutant concentration which
will cause interference with the POTW.
      5.   Heat in amounts which will inhibit biological activity in the POTW
resulting in interference, but in no case heat in such quantities that the
temperature at the POTW exceeds one hundred four degrees Fahrenheit (104°F)
(40°C).
      6.   Petroleum oil, nonbiodegradable cutting oil or products of mineral
oil origin, in amounts that will cause interference or pass through.
      7.   Pollutants which result in the presence of toxic gases, vapors or
fumes within the POTW in a quantity that may cause worker health and safety
problems.
      8.   Any trucked or hauled pollutants, except at discharge points
designated by the POTW. (Ord. 426, 12-9-1997)
8-3A-5: EMERGENCY SUSPENSIONS:
   A.   Authority To Suspend; Notice: The superintendent may immediately
suspend a user's discharge, after informal notice to the user, whenever such
suspension is necessary to stop an actual or threatened discharge which
reasonably appears to present or cause an imminent or substantial endangerment
to the health or welfare of persons. The superintendent may also immediately
suspend a user's discharge, after notice and opportunity to respond, that
threatens to interfere with operation of the POTW, or which presents or may
present, an endangerment to the environment.
   B.   Compliance With Suspension Order:
      1.   Any user notified of a suspension of its discharge shall immediately
stop or eliminate its contribution.
      2.   In the event of the user's failure to immediately comply voluntarily
with the suspension order, the superintendent may take such steps as deemed
necessary, including immediate severance of the sewer connection, to prevent or
minimize damage to the POTW, its receiving stream or endangerment to any
individuals.
      3.   The superintendent may allow the user to recommence its discharge
when the user has demonstrated to the satisfaction of the superintendent that
the period of endangerment has passed. (Ord. 426, 12-9-1997)
8-3A-6: MONITORING:
   A.   Inspections; Sampling: The superintendent shall have the right to enter
the premises of any user to determine whether the user is complying with all
the requirements of this article. Users shall allow the superintendent ready
access to all parts of the premises for the purposes of inspection, sampling,
record examination and copying, and the performance of any additional duties.
      1.   Where a user has security measures in force which require proper
identification and clearance before entry into the premises, the user shall
make necessary arrangements with the security so that, upon presentation of
suitable identification, the superintendent will be permitted to enter without
delay for the purpose of performing specific duties.
      2.   The superintendent shall have the right to set up on the user's
property such devices as are necessary to conduct sampling and/or metering of
the user's operation.
      3.   Unreasonable delays in allowing the superintendent access to the
user's premises shall be a violation of this article.
   B.   Search Warrants: If the superintendent has been refused access to the
building, structure, or property, or any part thereof, and is able to
demonstrate probable cause to believe that there may be a violation of this
article, or that there is a need to inspect to verify compliance with this
article, or protect the overall public health, safety and welfare of the
community, then the superintendent may seek issuance of a search warrant from
the Seminole County district court. (Ord. 426, 12-9-1997)
ARTICLE B. GREASE INTERCEPTORS FOR COMMERCIAL FACILITIES
SECTION:
8-3B-1: Purpose
8-3B-2: Scope And Applicability
8-3B-3: Definitions
8-3B-4: New Facilities
8-3B-5: Existing Facilities
8-3B-6: Permit Requirements; Administration
8-3B-7: Interceptors
8-3B-8: Generators
8-3B-9: Transporters
8-3B-10: Fees, Charges And Enforcement
8-3B-1: PURPOSE:
This article will set forth the standards and requirements concerning the
installation of grease interceptors for all commercial facilities, which
prepare or serve food, that may potentially discharge any solid or viscous
pollutants into the POTW (public owned treatment works). The purpose of this
article is to control the discharge of "solid or viscous pollutants in amounts
which will cause obstruction to the flow in the POTW resulting in interference"
[CFR 403.5(b)(3)]. A violation of this article does not require a criminal
mental state nor is ignorance an excuse. (Ord. 445, 8-13-2002)
8-3B-2: SCOPE AND APPLICABILITY:
This article will be towards all generators of FOGs who are connected to the
POTW and the transporters of the wastes that are created that must comply with
all local, state and federal regulations. (Ord. 445, 8-13-2002)
8-3B-3: DEFINITIONS:
Unless otherwise stated in the context of this article, the following terms and
abbreviations will have the meanings given hereafter:
FOGs: Fats, oils and greases.
FACILITY: A commercial business that generates FOGs. May also be referred to as
a generator.
FISCAL YEAR: The accounting period for twelve (12) months, which begins July 1
and ends June 30 for the city of Wewoka.
GENERATOR: Any facility that produces FOGs. May also be referred to as a
facility.
GREASE INTERCEPTOR: A device that separates, traps, and holds FOGs from the
wastewater discharge from a facility to prevent the FOGs from entering the
POTW. May also be referred to as a grease trap.
POTW: Publicly owned treatment works. (Ord. 445, 8-13-2002)
8-3B-4: NEW FACILITIES:
On or after the effective date hereof, all newly constructed facilities will be
required to install and properly maintain an underground grease interceptor
with a five hundred (500) gallon minimum. The first department shall have a
detention time of not less than fifteen (15) minutes at peak flow. The second
department shall have a detention time of not less than five (5) minutes at
peak flow. The code enforcement officer will determine sizing, installation,
retrofitting, and if the grease interceptor needs to be over five hundred (500)
gallons. All new facilities shall install a sampling port that is accessible to
the code enforcement officer to obtain samples. All fees accumulated due to the
installation of a grease interceptor will not be the responsibility of the
city. (Ord. 445, 8-13-2002; amd. 2005 Code)
8-3B-5: EXISTING FACILITIES:
   A.   Conditions For Requiring Interceptor:
      1.   On or after the effective date hereof, all existing facilities will
be required to install, operate, and maintain an underground "grease
interceptor" (when practicable) as defined in this article when any of the
following conditions occur:
         a.   The facility changes ownership.
         b.   When a permit is issued by the code enforcement officer for the
remodeling of the plumbing fixtures in the kitchen and/or food preparation area
and for the expansion or renovation of the facility.
         c.   The facility has been responsible for more than one sanitary
sewer overflow (bypass) in the period of one fiscal year.
      2.   The code enforcement officer or his designee will set a compliance
date when one of these condition occurs.
   B.   Time Limit For Installation: On or after the effective date hereof, all
existing facilities will be required to install, operate, and maintain a grease
interceptor in compliance with the international plumbing code. All existing
facilities are required to install a sampling port accessible to the code
enforcement officer to obtain samples within one hundred eighty (180) days of
the adoption of this article. (Ord. 445, 8-13-2002; amd. 2005 Code)
8-3B-6: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS; ADMINISTRATION:
   A.   Permit Required; Application: All facilities that prepare or serve food
that may potentially introduce FOGs into the POTW will be required to obtain a
grease discharge permit. Under this section, it will be considered unlawful for
any facility to knowingly discharge FOGs in amounts that may cause obstruction
to the flow in the POTW resulting in interference. False or misleading
information on an application will result in the termination of the application
permit, if it has been issued, or water and sewer service. (Ord. 445, 8-13-
2002)
   B.   Term Of Permit:
      1.   When an application has been reviewed and approved by the code
enforcement officer according to all rules in this article and all appropriate
fees are paid, all permits will be issued for a period of not more than five
(5) years from the date of an applicant's approval.
      2.   The permit holder will apply for a reissuance of such permit a
minimum of one hundred eighty (180) days prior to the permit's expiration date.
      3.   A permit may be terminated at any time when the code enforcement
officer finds that the permit holder has violated the permit conditions.
   C.   Permit Nontransferable: Permits are given to individual services and
facilities. No permit issued will be reassigned to anyone other than for whom
it was designed. No permit shall be sold or transferred due to a new owner or a
new facility location.
   D.   Modifications: The code enforcement officer has the authority to modify
or change any permits issued and includes, but is not limited to, the
following:
      1.   Revise standards to keep in compliance with changing local, state,
and federal regulations, requirements, and standards that may apply.
      2.   A violation of any terms of the permit.
      3.   A change in the permit holder's permit.
      4.   To reflect a change in ownership or facility location.
      5.   A request from the permit holder to have such permit modified,
reissued or terminated.
A request from a facility for modifications of its permit must be received in
writing by the code enforcement officer.
   E.   Compliance With Permit Conditions: The permit holder must comply with
all conditions of this permit. Failure to comply with the requirements of such
permit will be grounds for enforcement remedies described in this article or
any other ordinance dealing with the city sewer system.
   F.   Duty To Mitigate: The permit holder shall take the necessary steps to
minimize or correct any adverse impact to the POTW or the environment resulting
from noncompliance with the permit issued, including, but not limited to,
accelerated or additional monitoring as necessary to determine the nature and
impact of the noncompliance. All permit holders shall be subject to all
enforcement remedies.
   G.   Permit Termination:
      1.   An issued permit may be terminated for, but not limited to, the
following reasons:
         a.   Falsifying self-monitoring reports.
         b.   Refusing to allow timely access to the facility premises and
records.
         c.   Failure to pay fines.
         d.   Failure to pay fees.
         e.   Failure to meet compliance schedules.
      2.   An issued permit may be terminated at the discretion of the code
enforcement officer for any reason the code enforcement officer deems necessary
for causing harm to the POTW.
   H.   Property Rights: The issuance of a permit does not convey any property
rights of any sort, or any exclusive privileges, nor does it authorize any
injury to private property or any invasion of personal rights, nor any
violation of federal, state, or local laws or regulations.
   I.   Compliance With Applicable Pretreatment Standards: Compliance with an
issued permit does not relieve the permit holder from its obligations regarding
compliance with any and all applicable local, state and federal pretreatment
standards or requirements that may become effective during or after the term of
this permit.
   J.   Compliance Date: Every facility and generator will be in compliance
with all the standards and requirements of this article within one hundred
eighty (180) days of the effective date hereof. (Ord. 445, 8-13-2002; amd. 2005
Code)
8-3B-7: INTERCEPTORS:
The design, installation, retrofitting, and location of grease interceptors
will be in accordance with the code enforcement officer or his designee. Other
grease removal devices or remedies will not be permitted unless otherwise
approved by the code enforcement officer or his designee. Bacteria, enzymes,
and other additives will not be allowed for the treatment of FOGs in any form
or manner. (Ord. 445, 8-13-2002; amd. 2005 Code)
8-3B-8: GENERATORS:
   A.   Maintenance:
      1.   It will be the responsibility of the facilities to properly
maintain, operate, and clean their grease interceptors. This includes the
complete removal or pumping of all liquids, sludge, solids, and wastewater on
the surface and the bottom of the grease interceptor.
      2.   Generators will not be allowed to decant or pump the supernate or
liquefaction back into the grease interceptor for purposes of reducing the
volume of waste to be disposed.
      3.   The facility will only use the transporters that have been permitted
by the city. A list of these transporters may be received from the code
enforcement officer.
      4.   Grease interceptors will be pumped out a minimum of once every three
(3) months or as often as needed. If the code enforcement officer inspects the
generator, and their conclusion is that the grease interceptor or trap needs to
be cleaned, then the generator is to clean it.
   B.   Maintenance Log And Reporting:
      1.   It is mandatory that every year all facilities with a grease
interceptor maintain a current maintenance log for a period of twelve (12)
months. The facility will keep this log on file for a minimum time period of
three (3) years. This log will be kept in a conspicuous location for
inspections and will be immediately available to a representative of the city
who may be performing such inspections.
      2.   The reporting date will be from January 1 through December 31.
      3.   The facility will be required to send a copy of the maintenance log
to the code enforcement officer at the end of the reporting year. The code
enforcement officer must receive this copy no later than January 31, for the
previous year. (Ord. 445, 8-13-2002; amd. 2005 Code)
8-3B-9: TRANSPORTERS:
   A.   Pumping: It will be the responsibility of the transporters to properly
clean the grease interceptors as required by this article. The cleaning of the
grease interceptor will be complete pump out of the contents of the grease
interceptor. Decanting of the supernate back into the interceptor will not be
allowed. Discharging of the grease interceptor waste back into any part of the
POTW or any privately owned sewer collection system is prohibited. The
transporter will dispose of the grease interceptor waste in accordance with all
local, state and federal regulations.
   B.   Manifest:
      1.   The manifest will be used to track the grease interceptor waste from
the initial generation of the waste to the final disposal. It will be the
responsibility of the transporter to oversee the manifest. (Ord. 445, 8-13-
2002)
      2.   A book of manifests will be issued to each transporter, which has
been permitted, by the city. The transporter will ensure that all parts of the
form are completed entirely. The transporter will leave the appropriate copies
of the manifest with the generator, code enforcement officer and the disposal
site. All generators and transporters will keep their copies of manifests on
file for a period of three (3) years. (Ord. 445, 8-13-2002; amd. 2005 Code)
8-3B-10: FEES, CHARGES AND ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Purpose: It will be the sole purpose of this section to recover any
costs, incurred by the city, from the generators and transporters. All fees and
charges will be described in this section.
   B.   Permit Fees:
      1.   Permit fees will be established to recover any costs incurred by the
city to permit all generators and transporters. (Ord. 445, 8-13-2002)
      2.   The code enforcement officer will set the costs of the permit.
      3.   A permit will be due once every five (5) years from all generators
and transporters.
      4.   Permit fees will be reviewed at the end of each fifth year.
   C.   Surcharge Fee: A fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) will be charged
for any sample that is between two hundred milligrams per liter (200 mg/l) and
three hundred milligrams per liter (300 mg/l). A fee of five hundred dollars
($500.00) and one dollar ($1.00) per pound will be charged for any sample over
three hundred milligrams per liter (300 mg/l). The following formula will be
used to determine the pounds of FOGs: average monthly water usage x mg/l (over
300 mg/l) x 8.34 lbs/gal = lbs of FOGs x $1.00 per pound. This fee will be
established to recover the cost of the wastewater treatment plant to remove
FOGs from the wastewater. The amount of FOGs being discharged into the POTW by
a facility will be determined by sampling the discharge of the facility and
having the sample analyzed for the amounts of FOGs. Samples will be taken from
the facility at the discretion of the city code enforcement officer or his
designee. However, an additional sample may be requested by the facility, but
that facility will be responsible for the cost of any additional analysis and
sampling requested. (Ord. 445, 8-13-2002; amd. 2005 Code)
   D.   Sampling And Analysis Fees:
      1.   There will be no sampling or analysis fee for any generator that is
in compliance with all sewer ordinances or resolutions.
      2.   If any generator is out of compliance with any of the sewer
ordinances or resolutions, the generator will be charged a fee, as follows:
$50.00 for sampling
50.00 for FOGs
50.00 for BOD
50.00 for TSS
20.00 for pH
   E.   Enforcement; Payment Schedule:
      1.   Permit Fees: The payment schedule, late fees and enforcement for
permit fees will occur as listed:
         a.   A permit fee will be paid before the initial permit is issued.
         b.   A permit fee will be due every five (5) years on January 1, until
the expiration date of the permit.
         c.   A permit fee that has not been received by January 31, will
receive a notice of violation and a late fee of one-half (1/2) the amount of
the permit fee.
         d.   A permit fee that has not been received by February 28 will
receive a notice of violation and a late fee of one-half (1/2) the amount of
the permit fee. In this notice will be the final due date, which will be March
14.
         e.   If the permit fee has not been received by March 14, then the
permit will be terminated.
         f.   To receive a new permit, the generator or transporter will have
to reapply for a new permit.
         g.   A new permit will not be reissued until all pervious fees have
been paid.
         h.   A facility or transporter operating without a permit will be in
violation. This will be reason for termination of water and sewer service.
      2.   Surcharge Fee Due Date: The payment schedule, late fees, and
enforcement for surcharge fees will occur as listed:
         a.   The surcharge fee will be due on the fifteenth of each month.
         b.   If a surcharge fee has not been received by the fifteenth of the
next month, a notice of violation will be issued along with a late fee of
twenty five dollars ($25.00).
         c.   If a payment has not been received on the fifteenth of the second
month, a second notice of violation will be issued along with a late fee of
fifty dollars ($50.00) in addition to the first late fee.
         d.   If the payment has not been received within fifteen (15) days
after the second notice of violation, the permit will be terminated.
         e.   The facility will have to apply for a new permit at this point.
         f.   A new permit will not be issued until all pervious surcharge
fees, new permit fees, and late fees are paid.
         g.   A facility or transporter operating without a permit will be in
violation and will be fined up to five hundred dollars ($500.00).
      3.   Refusal To Pay Fines And Penalties: A refusal from a permit holder
to pay a fine or comply with any of the city sewer ordinances or resolutions
will be a violation and will be subject to termination of water and sewer
service.
   D.   Recovery Of Costs Incurred: Any permit holder violating any of the
provisions of an issued permit or any other city ordinances or resolutions,
causing damage to, or inhibiting the city wastewater disposal system shall be
liable to the city for any expense, loss, or damage caused by such violation
discharge; or for any cleaning, repair, or replacement work caused by the
violation. Refusal to pay the assessed costs is cause for service termination.
(Ord. 445, 8-13-2002)
   E.   Authority: The code enforcement officer or his designee has the
authority to refuse any wastewater from any generator that does not comply with
any of the city water and sewer ordinances and to terminate water and sewer
services. All generators are also subject to this article or any other
pretreatment ordinances or resolutions passed before or after this date. (Ord.
445, 8-13-2002; amd. 2005 Code)
CHAPTER 4
REFUSE COLLECTION; LANDFILL
SECTION:
8-4-1: Definitions
8-4-2: Sanitary Inspector
8-4-3: Garbage Service Required
8-4-4: License Or Contract For Collecting Or Transporting Refuse
8-4-5: Collection Schedules And Rates
8-4-6: Container And Dumpster Requirements; Placement
8-4-7: Special Pick Up Services
8-4-8: Brush And Trimmings, Bundles
8-4-9: Garbage Accumulations Prohibited
8-4-10: Unlawful Removal Of Garbage
8-4-11: City Landfill
8-4-12: Violation; Penalty
8-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms are defined as set out in
this section:
CARRY OUT SERVICE: A special category of service by the city for qualified
persons who are physically unable to move the mobile containers to the curb or
alleyway.
GARBAGE: Every accumulation of animal or vegetable matter, or both; that is,
the refuse matter from kitchens, pantries, dining rooms or other parts of
hotels, restaurants, dwelling houses, apartments, market houses and all animal
matter or refuse matter from butcher shops, poultry stores and fish stores.
MOBILE CONTAINERS: Any residential garbage container provided by or approved by
the city including, but not limited to, "poly-karts".
RUBBISH AND REFUSE: Ashes, cinders, paper, broken ware, discarded shoes, tin
cans and such refuse as may be termed the natural accumulation of resident
families. (1983 Code § 17-403; amd. 2005 Code)
8-4-2: SANITARY INSPECTOR:
   A.   Appointment; Duties: There shall be appointed a sanitary officer, known
as sanitary inspector, whose duties shall be such as are provided by law, and
by the ordinances and resolutions of the city council. He shall be appointed by
the city administrator. (1983 Code § 17-401)
   B.   Inspections; Report Nuisance Conditions: It is the duty of the sanitary
inspector to watch over and inspect the sanitary condition of all the territory
within the city, and to ascertain whether any nuisances exist within the
territory in violation of the ordinances of the city or the laws of the state.
In the event of the violation of any of the laws, he shall report the same to
the proper authorities and procure prosecutions to be instituted against the
parties guilty of such violation. (1983 Code § 17-402)
8-4-3: GARBAGE SERVICE REQUIRED:
All owners or occupants of all premises in the city limits that are connected
with the city water or sanitary sewer system shall be required to obtain
garbage service from the city and pay the monthly charges as hereinafter
prescribed. All other areas may be required to obtain city garbage service upon
procedures established by resolution of the city council based on location,
cost of furnishing such areas service, and density of population. (1983 Code §
17-404)
8-4-4: LICENSE OR CONTRACT FOR COLLECTING OR TRANSPORTING REFUSE:
It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of collecting,
transporting, hauling or conveying any refuse over the streets or alleys of the
city, or to dump or dispose of the same, unless and until such person is
licensed therefor or has a contract therefor as an authorized representative of
the city, or has the direct consent and permission of the city council. (1983
Code § 17-405)
8-4-5: COLLECTION SCHEDULES AND RATES:
   A.   Monthly User Charge: Each residential user, mobile home unit, apartment
unit or other family dwelling whether singly, in apartments, complexes or
trailer parks in the city service, shall be assessed a user charge per month
for collection from receptacles as described in this chapter. Service shall be
provided for curbside or alley pick up upon schedules as set by the city
council.
   B.   Council Determination: Each customer shall be assessed and serviced
according to need as defined in this chapter according to rates and schedules
adopted by the city council by motion or resolution. (1983 Code § 17-406)
   C.   Service Outside City Limits: The fees outside the corporate limits
shall be one and one-half (11/2) times the inside corporate limit rate. (1983
Code § 17-412)
8-4-6: CONTAINER AND DUMPSTER REQUIREMENTS; PLACEMENT:
   A.   Containers Provided By City; Placement: The city shall provide one
mobile container to each resident on designated container routes. Containers
are the property of the city and shall remain at the assigned location
regardless of changes in ownership or occupancy of the residence.
   B.   Carry Out Service: Carry out service shall be provided to residents who
are physically unable to place containers at curbside or alley. This service
will be provided by city employees at no additional fees. The city reserves the
right to require a doctor's certificate as proof of resident's inability to
place the container at curbside or alley.
   C.   Use By Residents: In areas where mobile containers are provided by the
city, residents shall use those containers as their first means of disposing of
garbage. Pick up service will be limited to the mobile container, except as to
the provisions of subsection G of this section.
   D.   Replacement Or Repair Of Containers:
      1.   Mobile containers that are stolen, destroyed, or damaged through
abuse, neglect, or improper usage by the resident shall be repaired or replaced
by the city at the expense of the resident or owner of the residence.
      2.   Mobile containers that are damaged through normal and reasonable
usage will be repaired by the city at the city's expense.
   E.   Containers Property Of City: The container or containers shall remain
the property of the city.
   F.   Businesses On Mobile Container Routes: Business collections on
designated mobile container routes shall not be provided mobile containers, but
shall use standard type containers as approved by the city code, unless use of
poly-kart is authorized by the city administrator.
   G.   Private Ownership: Private ownership of mobile containers is governed
by the following:
      1.   Residents may purchase one additional mobile container by placing a
purchase order with the city utility billing office; and
      2.   The city will bill the resident fifty dollars ($50.00) for the
costs, inclusive of assembly and delivery to residents. In the event payment is
not received within thirty (30) days of billing date, the cost of the mobile
container will be added to the garbage statement at the rate of ten dollars
($10.00) per month for a period of six (6) months. (1983 Code § 17-415)
   H.   Business Or Industrial Establishments; Dumpsters:
      1.   Owners or operators of business or industrial establishments shall
provide metallic or plastic containers commonly known as dumpsters, in sizes of
one, two (2) or three (3) cubic yards, or other type containers approved by the
city administrator. (1983 Code § 17-415; amd. 2005 Code)
      2.   The owner or operator of each business or industrial establishment
shall provide containers for sanitation purposes of adequate size to properly
provide for the accumulation of garbage, refuse and rubbish. The city, by and
through its city administrator, shall prescribe for an adequate size container
in the event the owner or operator of the business or industry fails to do so.
The failure of the owner or operator of such business or industrial
establishment to provide for containers of adequate size shall constitute an
offense.
      3.   Those business or industrial establishments generating an inordinate
amount of trash, or unable to provide proper container size, shall be assessed
the maximum user fee.
      4.   All such containers shall be placed in a location so as to be easily
accessible for collection. A solid hard surface shall be required for the
approach to and upon which such container shall be placed.
      5.   Business establishments are authorized to operate a dumpster in
conjunction with other users. All such businesses shall be assessed
individually a minimum rate.
      6.   The city, through and by the city administrator, shall determine the
