number of pick ups and, when necessary, the size and number of dumpsters per
business or industrial users. (1983 Code § 17-407)
   I.   Dumpsters Available For Rental Purposes: Any sanitation customer who
accumulates large amounts of garbage or refuse in the process of remodeling,
construction or other such activity may rent from the city a one yard dumpster
for a fee as set by the city council, plus a normal rate as set by the council.
Such customer shall be responsible and hold the city harmless for use of such
dumpster. (1983 Code § 17-415)
8-4-7: SPECIAL PICK UP SERVICES:
Any sanitation user, by special request, may have a special pickup for purposes
of collecting large amounts of yard trash, garbage, tree limbs, brush and large
items such as stoves, couches and chairs, for a fee per hour as set by the city
council for the combination of truck and manpower used. The minimum charge per
service call shall be as set by the council. (1983 Code § 17-408)
8-4-8: BRUSH AND TRIMMINGS, BUNDLES:
Brush and trimmings of thickness of no greater than two inches (2") will be cut
in lengths no greater than four feet (4'), tied together with approved rope or
twine in bundles of no more than seventy five (75) pounds and placed at the
curb so that the same may be collected during normal sanitation pick ups. (1983
Code § 17-409)
8-4-9: GARBAGE ACCUMULATIONS PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person to permit or to suffer to accumulate in or about
any yard, lot, place or premises, or upon any street, alley or sidewalk
adjacent to such lot, yard, place or premises, owned or occupied by such
person, any garbage or refuse. (1983 Code § 17-410)
8-4-10: UNLAWFUL REMOVAL OF GARBAGE:
It is unlawful for any person without a permit or license to remove or cause to
be removed any garbage, refuse or rubbish of any kind from any garbage can or
other container used for the deposit of same. (1983 Code § 17-411)
8-4-11: CITY LANDFILL:
   A.   Operation Under State Permit: This section shall be in effect and
effective in all respects as to any sanitary landfill operated at present by
the city under state of Oklahoma health department permit #3567006. (1983 Code
§ 17-501)
   B.   Hours Of Operation; Fees:
      1.   Landfill operation shall be confined to the hours between nine
thirty o'clock (9:30) A.M. and six thirty o'clock (6:30) P.M. daily.
      2.   The fee for use of the landfill shall be as set by the city
administrator to allow for effective operation of the landfill. (1983 Code §
17-502)
   C.   Unauthorized Person Prohibited: It is unlawful for any person to enter
upon the landfill for any purpose other than the dumping of trash, garbage or
other material in the designated areas of dumping. No person shall enter the
landfill with the purpose of removing trash, garbage or other material already
dumped there. (1983 Code § 17-503)
   D.   Removal Of Material From Landfill: It is unlawful to remove for any
purpose, any trash, garbage or other material from the landfill. (1983 Code §
17-504)
8-4-12: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
   A.   Violations: The owner, person having control, or occupant of any
premises in the city who fails, neglects or refuses to furnish the containers
described in this chapter or to deposit therein garbage, refuse and rubbish; or
who fails, refuses or neglects to pay any uncontested bills for services
rendered under this chapter for a period of ten (10) days after official notice
of such failure, neglect or refusal; or who violates any of the provisions of
this chapter, is guilty of an offense. (1983 Code § 17-414)
   B.   Penalty Imposed: The owner, person or establishment who violates any of
the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be guilty of an offense
and shall be subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1983 Code §§ 17-413, 17-505)
TITLE 9
BUILDING REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
BUILDING CODE
SECTION:
9-1-1: Building Code Adopted
9-1-2: Building Inspector, Official
9-1-3: Enforcement; Duties And Responsibilities
9-1-4: Nonliability Of Building Inspector
9-1-5: Cooperation Of Other Officials
9-1-6: Right Of Entry
9-1-7: Exemptions From Permit Requirements
9-1-8: Permit Fees
9-1-9: Fire Limits
9-1-10: Accessory Building Ordinance
9-1-1: BUILDING CODE ADOPTED:
   A.   Adoption: There is hereby adopted by reference the standard building
code, the latest edition thereof, issued by the Southern Building Code Congress
International, as the building code for the city. The standard building code
shall be fully applicable and enforceable in controlling the construction and
repair of all buildings and other structures in the city, save and except such
portions as are hereinafter deleted, modified or amended, as fully as if set
out at length herein.
   B.   Conflicting Provisions: If any provision of current ordinances of the
city are in conflict with the provisions of the building code, except as
provided in this chapter, the provisions of the building code shall prevail.
(1983 Code § 5-101)
   C.   Copy On File: At least one copy of the code adopted in subsection A of
this section shall be on file in the office of the city clerk and available for
inspection by the general public. (2005 Code)
9-1-2: BUILDING INSPECTOR, OFFICIAL:
   A.   Office Created: The office of building inspector is hereby created and
the executive official in charge shall be known as the building inspector.
   B.   Appointment Or Removal:
      1.   The building inspector shall be appointed by the city administrator.
His appointment shall continue during good behavior and satisfactory service.
      2.   He shall not be removed from office except for cause after full
opportunity has been given him to be heard on specific charges. (1983 Code § 5-
201)
   C.   Qualifications: The building inspector shall be physically capable of
making the necessary examinations and inspections. He shall not have any
interest whatever, directly or indirectly, in the sale or manufacture of any
material, process or device entering into or used in or in connection with
building construction, alterations, removal and demolition. (1983 Code § 5-202)
   D.   Acting Building Inspector: During temporary absence or disability of
the building inspector, the appointing authority shall designate an acting
building inspector. (1983 Code § 5-201)
9-1-3: ENFORCEMENT; DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
   A.   Duties And Responsibilities Of Building Inspector:
      1.   The building inspector shall receive applications required by this
code, issue permits and furnish the prescribed certificates. Prior to issuance
of any permit or certificate, the applicant shall furnish to the building
inspector such plans and specifications as required by the building inspector
to ensure that all provisions of this code will be followed.
      2.   He shall examine premises for which permits have been issued and
shall make necessary inspections to see that the provisions of law are complied
with and that construction is prosecuted safely.
      3.   He shall enforce all provisions of the building code.
      4.   He shall, when requested by proper authority, or when the public
interest so requires, make investigations in connection with matters referred
to in the building code and render written reports on the same.
      5.   To enforce compliance with law, to remove illegal or unsafe
conditions, to secure the necessary safeguards during construction, or to
require adequate exit facilities in buildings and structures, he shall issue
such notices or orders as may be necessary. (Ord. 412, 12-12-1995)
   B.   Inspections; Certificates:
      1.   Inspections required under the provisions of the building code shall
be made by the building inspector or his duly appointed assistant. The building
inspector may accept reports of inspectors of recognized inspection services,
after investigation of their qualifications and reliability.
      2.   No certificate called for by any provision of the building code
shall be issued on such reports unless the same are in writing and certified to
by a responsible officer of such service.
   C.   Records Required; Copies Of Plans:
      1.   The building inspector shall keep comprehensive records of
applications, of permits issued, of certificates issued, of inspections made,
of reports rendered, and of notices or orders issued.
      2.   He shall retain on file copies of required plans and all documents
relating to building work so long as any part of the building or structure to
which they relate may be in existence.
   D.   Records Open To Public Inspection: All such records shall be open to
public inspection for good and sufficient reasons at the stated office hours,
but shall not be removed from the office of the building inspector without his
written consent.
   E.   Monthly Reports: The building inspector shall make written reports once
each month, or more often if requested, including statements of permits and
certificates issued, and orders promulgated. (1983 Code § 5-203)
9-1-4: NONLIABILITY OF BUILDING INSPECTOR:
The building inspector or any employee charged with the enforcement of this
code, acting in good faith and without malice for the city in the discharge of
his duties, shall not thereby render himself liable personally and he is hereby
relieved from all personal liability for any damage that may accrue to persons
or property as a result of any act required or by reason of any act or omission
in the discharge of his duties. Any suit brought against the building inspector
or employee, because of such act or omission performed by him in the
enforcement of any provisions of this code, shall be defended by the legal
department of the city until final termination of the proceedings. (1983 Code §
5-204)
9-1-5: COOPERATION OF OTHER OFFICIALS:
The building inspector may request and shall receive so far as may be
necessary, in the discharge of his duties, the assistance and cooperation of
other officials of the city. (1983 Code § 5-205)
9-1-6: RIGHT OF ENTRY:
The building inspector, in the discharge of his official duties, and upon
proper identification, shall have authority to enter any building, structure or
premises at any reasonable hour. (1983 Code § 5-206)
9-1-7: EXEMPTIONS FROM PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
Construction for the erection, alteration, or repair of which the cost will not
exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) may be made without notice to the
building inspector. (1983 Code § 5-207)
9-1-8: PERMIT FEES:
   A.   Estimated Cost Defined: The term "estimated cost", as used in this
section, means the reasonable value of all services, labor, materials, and use
of scaffolding and other appliances, devices, or machinery, necessary or
expedient or convenient to the prosecution and completion of the work on the
premises ready for occupancy; or the value of all such services, labor,
materials and machinery used, necessary, expedient or convenient in completion
of the demolition; provided, that the cost of excavation and grading, and of
painting, decoration or other work that is merely for embellishment and not
necessary for the safe and lawful use of the building or structure, is not
deemed part of the estimated cost. (Ord. 403, 1-12-1993)
   B.   Payment Of Fee: No permit, as required by the building code, shall be
issued until the fee prescribed in this section shall have been paid. No
amendment to a permit may be approved until the additional fee, if any, due to
an increase in the estimated cost of the building or structure, shall have been
paid.
   C.   Building Construction Or Alteration; Permit Fees Enumerated: For a
permit for the construction or alteration of a building or structure, the fee
shall be based on the estimated cost of the building project as follows:
Total Valuation Fee
Total Valuation            Fee
$100.00 and less           No fee, unless inspection required, in which case a
                           $5.00 fee for each inspection shall be charged
$101.00 to $2,000.00       $5.00 per thousand or fraction thereof
                           $10.00 for the first $2,000.00, plus $3.00 for each
$2,001.00 to $15,000.00    additional thousand or fraction thereof, to and
                           including $15,000.00
                           $49.00 for the first $15,000.00, plus $2.50 for each
$15,001.00 to $50,000.00   additional thousand or fraction thereof, to and
                           including $50,000.00
                           $136.50 for the first $50,000.00, plus $2.00 for
$50,001.00 to $100,000.00  each additional thousand or fraction thereof, to and
                           including $ 100,000.00
                           $256.50 for the first $100,000.00, plus $1.25 for
$100,001.00 to $500,000.00 each additional thousand or fraction thereof, to and
                           including $500,000.00
$500,001.00 and up         $736.50 for the first $500,000.00, plus $0.75 for
                           each additional thousand or fraction thereof
 
   D.   Moving Building; Permit Fee: For a permit for the removal of a building
or structure from one lot to another, the fee shall be at the rate of twenty
dollars ($20.00). (1983 Code § 5-208)
   E.   Building Demolition; Permit Fee; Security; Requirements:
      1.   For a permit for the demolition of a building or structure, the fee
shall be at the rate of ten dollars ($10.00) for each building or structure.
      2.   In addition, the person seeking a demolition permit shall provide
security in the form of cash, cashier's check, certified check, certificate of
deposit, or corporate surety bond, in a sum not less than fifty percent (50%)
of the estimated cost of demolition including removal and disposal of all
debris. Such security shall be returned or refunded to the permit holder upon
completion of the demolition and removal of all debris and final acceptance of
the site by the building inspector as being in full compliance with all
applicable city ordinances.
      3.   In the event the permit holder shall fail or refuse to complete the
demolition project within the time period for which the permit was issued, or
fail or refuse to remove all debris resulting from the project, or fail or
refuse to place the premises in a condition determined by the building
inspector to be in compliance with all applicable city ordinances, then at the
expiration of ten (10) days' written notice to the permit holder, all such
security shall be forfeited to the city and the city may then proceed to
complete the demolition and remove all debris. In the event the cost to the
city to complete the project exceeds the amount of security, then the city
shall have the right to proceed against the permit holder for the difference.
Such permit shall be valid for a period not exceeding six (6) months prior to
the expiration date in which the demolition project must be completed. (Ord.
403, 1-12-1993)
   F.   Abandonment Or Discontinuance Of Work; Refund:
      1.   In case of abandonment or discontinuance, the cost of work performed
under a permit may be estimated, an adjustment of the fee made and the portion
of the fee for uncompleted work returned to the permit holder; provided, that
no refund of a prescribed minimum fee shall be made.
      2.   If such discontinuance is due to revocation of permit, a similar
adjustment and return may be made; provided, that no refund shall be made until
all penalties incurred or imposed by due authority have been collected.
      3.   After such a refund has been made, no work shall be resumed until a
new application has been made and a new permit has been issued. (1983 Code § 5-
208)
9-1-9: FIRE LIMITS:
   A.   Limits Established: A fire district for the incorporated city is hereby
established, fixed and designated as follows: commencing at the corner of Brown
Avenue, and Third Street, thence north along Brown Avenue to the Rock Island
railroad track; thence west along Park Street to the first alley west of
Mekusukey Avenue; thence south along the alley to Third Street; thence east on
Third Street to the first alley east of Mekusukey Avenue; thence south along
the alley to Fourth Street; thence east along Fourth Street to Muskogee Avenue;
thence north along Muskogee Avenue to Third Street; thence east to place of
beginning. (1983 Code § 5-102)
   B.   Property Removed From Fire Zone: The property hereinafter described
within the corporate boundaries of the city is hereby removed from the fire
zone of the city and all restrictions and regulations applicable to property
within this fire zone are hereby removed. The property being described as
follows:
      1.   The East Half (E1/2) of Block 2, East Side Addition;
      2.   The East Half (E1/2) of Block 3, East Side Addition;
      3.   The East Half (E1/2) of Block 4, East Side Addition;
      4.   The East Half (E1/2) of Block 5, Court House Addition;
      5.   The East Half (E1/2) of Block 5, Keith's Extension to Court House;
and
      6.   The East Half (E1/2) of Block 12, Keith's Extension to Court House.
(1983 Code § 5-103)
9-1-10: ACCESSORY BUILDING ORDINANCE:
Any detached building that is intended to be renovated and/or converted to
provide livable conditions therein must first obtain approval from the Wewoka
Board of Adjustment. (Ord. 515, 7-9-2019)
CHAPTER 2
PLUMBING CODE
SECTION:
9-2-1: Plumbing Code Adopted
9-2-2: Plumbing Inspector
9-2-3: Plumbing Registration; Certificate
9-2-4: Registration Fees
9-2-5: Excavation Permit Requirements; Fee
9-2-6: Application For Permit
9-2-7: Protection Of Trenches
9-2-8: Penalty
9-2-1: PLUMBING CODE ADOPTED:
   A.   Adoption: There is hereby adopted by reference the standard plumbing
code, the latest edition thereof, issued by the Southern Building Code Congress
International, as the plumbing code for the city. The standard plumbing code
shall be fully applicable and enforceable in governing plumbing and sewers in
the city, save and except such portions as are hereinafter deleted, modified or
amended, as fully as if set out at length herein.
   B.   Conflicting Provisions: If any provision of the ordinances of the city
are in conflict with the provisions of the plumbing code, except as provided in
this chapter, the provisions of the plumbing code shall prevail. (1983 Code §
5-301)
   C.   Copy On File: At least one copy of the code adopted in subsection A of
this section shall be on file in the office of the city clerk and available for
inspection by the general public. (2005 Code)
9-2-2: PLUMBING INSPECTOR:
   A.   Office Created; Appointment: There is created the office of plumbing
inspector, who shall be appointed by the city administrator.
   B.   Enforcement: He shall be charged with the enforcement of this chapter,
and shall have the duties herein provided.
   C.   Right Of Access; Inspections: He shall have access during all hours of
the day to all buildings in the city for the purpose of inspection of existing
systems of drainage, and shall be given every opportunity for a careful
examination of same. (1983 Code § 5-307)
9-2-3: PLUMBING REGISTRATION; CERTIFICATE:
   A.   State License Prerequisite: No person, firm or corporation, for doing
plumbing or house drainage or steam or gas fitting within the city, shall be
allowed to conduct business in the city until he shall first have obtained a
license so to do from the Oklahoma state health department as a journeyman,
master plumber or plumbing contractor and receives his certificate of
registration by the city.
   B.   City Certificate Of Registration:
      1.   No person, firm or corporation shall receive a city registration
certificate unless he shall have, at the time, furnished the authorities of the
city satisfactory evidence of his responsibility and skill to ply the trade.
      2.   No loan or transfer of a plumbing registration certificate shall be
permitted nor shall any person, firm or corporation be allowed to work under a
plumbing registration certificate held by another. (1983 Code § 5-302)
9-2-4: REGISTRATION FEES:
There shall be paid to the city, for such registration, the following fees:
   A.   For registration as a master plumber or plumbing contractor, the sum of
fifty dollars ($50.00) for one year, or any part thereof;
   B.   For registration as a journeyman plumber, the sum of ten dollars
($10.00) for one year, or any part thereof; and
   C.   For registration as an apprentice plumber, the sum of three dollars
($3.00) per year. (1983 Code § 5-303)
9-2-5: EXCAVATION PERMIT REQUIREMENTS; FEE:
   A.   Permit Required; Compliance Required:
      1.   No person, firm or corporation shall dig or excavate or cause to be
dug or excavated within, through or under any street, alley or sidewalk, or
public place in the city for any purpose under this code without obtaining a
permit from the plumbing inspector.
      2.   All permits issued hereafter to dig or excavate in any street,
avenue, alley or sidewalk, for the purpose of laying down or repairing any
sewer service pipe or any connection with any public or district sewer or
drain, shall authorize such work to be done only under the direction and
control of such person or persons as shall have complied with this section.
   B.   Inspection Fee: An inspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be
paid by the party seeking such permit prior to commencement of the work
authorized in the permit.
   C.   Performance Of Work; Responsibility:
      1.   All street cuts, paved alley cuts, pavement removal and replacement
will be the responsibility of the person, firm or corporation obtaining the
permit.
      2.   In addition, any damaged sidewalk or curb must be replaced.
      3.   All work must be done according to the requirements and
specifications set out in this section.
   D.   Backfilling: All unpaved alleys shall be backfilled and compacted to a
depth of one foot (1') of sand or sifted dirt above the top of the pipe and
graded level with existing street or alley.
   E.   Time Limit For Completion: All work must be completed within twenty
four (24) hours of excavating unless special permission is granted by the
plumbing inspector to extend such time under extraordinary circumstances.
   F.   Repair And Replacement Of Paving Cuts:
      1.   The repair and replacement of paving cuts required for utilities or
other ditch construction shall be accomplished as follows:
         a.   Upon completion of the excavation or slab removal required by the
new construction, the subgrade under the edge of the existing slab shall be
undercut for a distance and depth as shown on "street cut detail".
         b.   Where reinforcement is required, it shall be placed as shown on
the "street cut detail".
         c.   The cut shall be filled with concrete to the depth indicated on
the "street cut detail".
         d.   The edges of the new slab shall be vibrated sufficiently to
ensure flow of concrete into that undercut area.
   Street Cut Detail
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/20ddfb061afc345ffd117282d8e69a8fd4329a32/
IMAGES/0-0-0-1889.gif]
 
Notes:
            (1)   Existing paving shall be saw cut;
            (2)   Sand shall be compacted in six inch (6") layers;
            (3)   No reinforcement shall be required for minor street cuts;
            (4)   Concrete shall be class A, three thousand (3,000) pounds; and
            (5)   Streets shall be bored unless the engineering department
grants permission for a street to be cut.
      2.   The repair and replacement of cuts on brick streets and alleys
required for utilities or other ditch construction shall be accomplished as
follows:
Upon completion of the excavation or removal of paving brick required by the
new construction, such excavation shall be filled with concrete and compacted
sand in accordance with the brick street and alley detail shown below.
   Brick Street And Alley Detail
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/20ddfb061afc345ffd117282d8e69a8fd4329a32/
IMAGES/0-0-0-1891.gif]
 
(1983 Code § 5-304)
9-2-6: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
All plumbers or steam or gas fitters, before doing work of any kind mentioned
in this chapter, except in case of repairing leaks inside of the property line,
shall file in the office of the plumbing inspector upon blanks for that purpose
an application for a permit, and a plan or sketch of the work to be performed.
No such work shall be done in any building without a written permit from the
plumbing inspector. (1983 Code § 5-305)
9-2-7: PROTECTION OF TRENCHES:
All trenches in public streets and alleys shall be properly protected at night
with substantial barricades at least three feet (3') high, same to have
contractor's name and telephone number printed thereon, and red lights shall be
placed at each end of the trench, in cases where the trench is ten feet (10')
or more in length, or an obstruction, and same shall be kept brightly burning
from sunset until sunrise. The chief of the fire department shall be notified
of such obstruction prior to dark of same day that it is put in. The plumbing
inspector shall prescribe such rules and conditions to be followed and
performed as may be necessary for the safety of the street, alley, sidewalk or
sewer through which a permit may be issued to excavate or connect. (1983 Code §
5-306)
9-2-8: PENALTY:
   A.   Failure To Comply With Regulations: Any firm or corporation,
copartnership, or individual doing business within the limits of the city who
shall in any way fail to comply with or violate any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof,
shall be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1983 Code § 5-308)
   B.   Failure To Register; Payment Of Fine: Any plumber who shall proceed to
practice his trade as a plumber in the city without having first registered and
paid his registration fee shall be guilty of an offense and be subject to a
fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1983 Code § 5-309)
CHAPTER 3
ELECTRICAL CODE
SECTION:
9-3-1: Electrical Code Adopted
9-3-2: Electrical Inspector
9-3-3: Electric Wiring Defined; Permit Required
9-3-4: Electrical Contractor Registration; Fee
9-3-5: Bond Required
9-3-6: Journeyman And Apprentice Registration; Fees
9-3-7: Electrical Wiring Permit; Fee
9-3-8: Temporary Permits; Notice Of Defects
9-3-9: Inspection Of Work
9-3-10: Unsafe Or Defective Wiring Or Equipment
9-3-11: Alterations Or Changes In Wiring
9-3-12: Placement Of Wires On Poles
9-3-13: Electrical And Neon Signs
9-3-14: Service Entrance
9-3-15: Service Supports
9-3-16: Inside Wiring
9-3-17: Wire Requirements
9-3-18: Underground Service Wire
9-3-19: Service And Conduit Grounds
9-3-20: Wiring Identification Required
9-3-21: Meters And Associated Equipment
9-3-22: Lights In Openings
9-3-23: Penalty
9-3-1: ELECTRICAL CODE ADOPTED:
The latest issue of the rules and regulations of the National Board of Fire
Underwriters, known as the National Electrical Code, approved by the American
Standards Committee, is made a part of this chapter. The Underwriters
Laboratories, Inc., approval of electrical appliances will be the standard for
all electrical fittings and appliances. At least one copy of the code adopted
in this section shall be on file in the office of the city clerk and available
for inspection by the general public. (1983 Code § 5-401; amd. 2005 Code)
9-3-2: ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR:
There is created the office of city electrical inspector. The electrical
inspector shall be appointed by the city administrator and shall receive such
salary and fees as the city council may determine and shall hold office until
his successor has been appointed and confirmed by the council. (1983 Code § 5-
402)
9-3-3: ELECTRIC WIRING DEFINED; PERMIT REQUIRED:
   A.   Definition: "Electric wiring" means the installation of electrical
conductors or apparatus of any nature to be connected to light, heat or power
service, except lines and regulation of electricity and remaining the property
of the service company.
   B.   Permit Required: All persons, firms, partnerships or corporations who
desire to install electric wiring or to make any alterations or changes in
existing wiring in or on any buildings (except central stations, power houses
and substations belonging to the electric service company operating under a
franchise) shall first secure a permit from the city electrical inspector.
(1983 Code § 5-403)
9-3-4: ELECTRICAL CONTRACTOR REGISTRATION; FEE:
   A.   Registration Certificate Required:
      1.   All persons, firms, partnerships, corporations or individuals
engaged or hereafter engaging in the business of installing electric wiring,
lighting fixtures or electrical apparatus of any nature in or on any building
within the city limits shall procure from the city clerk a certificate of
registration, which certificate, so long as in force, shall entitle the holder
thereof to install electric wiring for the transmission of electric energy for
light, heat or power.
      2.   Before any such certificate is issued, the appropriate state license
must be obtained and a copy provided to the city by the applicant.
   B.   Fee:
      1.   The annual fee for such certificate to each person, firm or
corporation shall be in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) per year.
      2.   The entire amount is payable in advance on a yearly basis and shall
be issued for the fiscal year starting July 1 each year.
      3.   Such license shall be renewed within thirty (30) days before
expiration, upon payment of fifty dollars ($50.00).
      4.   A public service corporation operating under a regular franchise
shall be exempt from the requirement as above mentioned, insofar as the same
affects property owned or controlled by them. (1983 Code § 5-404)
9-3-5: BOND REQUIRED:
All registered contracting electricians who desire to do any electrical wiring
in or on any building (except central power stations and substations belonging
to the electric service company operating under a franchise) shall furnish the
city with proof that a state bond has been obtained by the registered
contracting electrician as a guarantee that the installation of electrical
wiring, fixtures and apparatus shall be in accordance with the requirements of
this chapter and the national electrical code. It is further conditioned that
such registered contracting electricians shall, without further cost to the
person from whom the work was done, remedy any defective or faulty work caused
by incompetent workmen, inferior or nonstandard material; and such bond as is
furnished is liable for the correction and any additional cost arising from the
above mentioned causes. (1983 Code § 5-405; amd. 2005 Code)
9-3-6: JOURNEYMAN AND APPRENTICE REGISTRATION; FEES:
   A.   Registration Required; Fees:
      1.   Any person desiring to do electrical wiring in the city and being
employed by a registered contractor shall make application to the electrical
inspector for a certificate of registration as a journeyman or apprentice.
      2.   The registration shall be on a yearly basis, the year starting each
July 1, for which the following fees shall be paid:
         a.   For registration as a journeyman electrician, the sum of ten
dollars ($10.00) per year; and
         b.   For registration as an apprentice electrician, the sum of three
dollars ($3.00) per year.
   B.   Employment Of Apprentice: Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to
prohibit the employment of any apprentice working under the direct supervision
of a duly registered wireman, journeyman or electrician. Such apprentice must
register with the electrical inspector, pay the certificate fee provided above,
give a history of his electrical experience and request his journeyman
examination within six (6) months from the date of such registration as an
apprentice.
   C.   State License Required: Before a certificate may be issued to any
apprentice or journeyman, the applicant shall procure the appropriate state
license from the state, with copy provided to the city. (1983 Code § 5-406)
9-3-7: ELECTRICAL WIRING PERMIT; FEE:
   A.   Application For Wiring Permit: All applications for electrical wiring
permits shall be made in writing to the electrical inspector.
   B.   Permit Fee: The inspector shall issue the permits after payment of the
following fee: Seven dollars fifty cents ($7.50) per each one hundred (100)
amps.
   C.   Fee Paid By Contractor: The contractor making the application for the
permit shall pay the fee. (1983 Code § 5-407)
9-3-8: TEMPORARY PERMITS; NOTICE OF DEFECTS:
   A.   Temporary Permit; Fee: When for good and sufficient reasons at the
discretion of the city electrical inspector it appears necessary, and upon
payment of applicant of a fee of ten dollars ($10.00), the electrical inspector
may issue permits for connection to a temporary pole or unfinished or defective
wiring for a period of time not to exceed thirty (30) days; otherwise, no
electric light or power company shall connect to any installation of any kind
whatsoever until furnished with the certificate of inspection from the
electrical inspector.
   B.   Remedial Action: The electric light or power companies shall, upon
written notice from the electrical inspector, disconnect from any service
designated by the notice from the city electrical inspector stating any defects
or faults, until the defects or faults have been corrected. (1983 Code § 5-408)
9-3-9: INSPECTION OF WORK:
   A.   Responsibility To Notify Inspector: It is the responsibility of the
person obtaining the permit for each respective job to notify the electrical
inspector upon the completion of the "roughing in" work for inspection as well
as the completed job for final inspection.
   B.   Time Limit For Inspection: The electrical inspector, having received
such notice, must inspect, or cause to be inspected by a qualified
representative, any electric wiring within the city within forty eight (48)
hours, Saturdays, Sundays and holidays excepted. (1983 Code § 5-409)
9-3-10: UNSAFE OR DEFECTIVE WIRING OR EQUIPMENT:
   A.   Special Rulings Authorized: The electrical inspector shall have the
authority to make special rulings, when circumstances warrant, for the
safeguarding of life and property and improvement of electrical installations.
   B.   Notice Of Unsafe Condition: Whenever any electrical wiring or equipment
is found by the electrical inspector to be unsafe or defective, he shall notify
the owner or person in control thereof to repair or remove the same.
   C.   Discontinuance Of Service For Noncompliance: Upon the owner's failure
to comply within such time as the electrical inspector shall specify, the
inspector shall cause service to be discontinued. (1983 Code § 5-410)
9-3-11: ALTERATIONS OR CHANGES IN WIRING:
When any alterations or changes are made in the wiring of any building or any
new wires are installed, it shall be the responsibility of the person,
partnership or corporation doing or having such work done to first obtain a
permit from the electrical inspector and to notify the inspector in writing
immediately after the completion of the work. The inspector then shall inspect
the work as herein provided. (1983 Code § 5-411)
9-3-12: PLACEMENT OF WIRES ON POLES:
The electrical inspector is authorized, empowered and directed to have general
supervision over the placing or stringing or attaching of telegraph, telephone,
electric lights or other wires and placing of all poles and appliances so as to
prevent fires, accidents or injury to persons or property. (1983 Code § 5-412)
9-3-13: ELECTRICAL AND NEON SIGNS:
   A.   Electrical Signs: Service to an electrical sign shall be through a
rigid conduit to be of an approved safety type. This cabinet shall be enclosed
in a weatherproof box on which provision shall be made for locking. (1983 Code
§ 5-413)
   B.   Neon Signs:
      1.   On Or In Any Buildings:
         a.   When neon signs are placed on or in any building within the city
limits, they shall be installed in accordance with this subsection B1 and the
provisions of the national electrical code.
         b.   Transformers shall not be placed less than eight feet (8') off
the floor and not more than three feet (3') from the outlet to which they are
connected.
         c.   High tension lines shall be connected by approved metal clips
from transformers to electrodes. All connections shall be made with some
approved connector, which shall be encased in tin cases so arranged that they
cannot be reached without removing the case. (1983 Code § 5-414)
      2.   Outside Public Buildings:
         a.   This subsection B2 applies only to neon signs when placed on the
outside of public buildings. Wires feeding sign transformers shall be run in
conduit and fastened to the metal cabinet where the transformer is to be
placed.
         b.   High tension lines shall then be from transformer to electrode
through glass brackets and lines shall be taped so as to prevent the lines from
sliding. The connection in this type of sign shall also be made with approved
connector. No inspection fee for less than five dollars ($5.00) for any type of
sign shall be charged. (1983 Code § 5-415)
9-3-14: SERVICE ENTRANCE:
   A.   Location: All service entrance wires into a building shall be located
at a point on the building most convenient for connection to the service
company's lines. Where practical, all service conduits shall be extended
through the outside building wall on a street or alley side at such points as
will avoid open service wires being placed over roofs or through courts, light
and ventilating shafts and over adjoining property. Locations of points of
connections will be designated by the electrical inspector or authorized
employees of the service company. All such aerial service entrances shall be
located at points not less than ten feet (10') and not more than twenty five
feet (25') from the ground. In case the building is not of sufficient height
for service entrance to be at least ten feet (10') from the ground, the owner
shall furnish fixtures suitable to which the wires may be attached. Where
garages or other outbuildings in line with or interfering with the service
wires having code clearance, from the service pole to the house, the service
cabinet and meter shall be installed in the garage or other outbuildings.
   B.   Wire Specifications: All wires shall be of copper and of sufficient
size to carry the proper load. All conduit and fittings shall be weatherproof
when installed outside a building.
   C.   Business District: All service entrances, installed in the business
district shall be for three (3) phase or four (4) wire 208 VAC where the supply
is available.
   D.   Wires In Conduit: In such cases, the feeder wires from the service
cabinet to the distribution cabinet may be placed in underground conduit. All
service entrance wires making overhead entrances into a building shall be
carried in approved conduit with approved weatherproof service head, and the
conduit shall be brought through the meter base into the service switch inlet
without conduit fittings of any kind, other than conduit couplings or other
approved closed fittings; except in business areas where an inside meter is to
be installed, the conduit shall be brought directly into the service switch
cabinet. The service head should extend at least six inches (6") above the
point of service.
   E.   Length Limited: The service entrance to the service switch cabinet
shall be as short as possible, in no case greater than fifteen feet (15')
without special permission from the electrical inspector and then not to exceed
twenty five feet (25').
   F.   Service Wire Size: No service wire shall be smaller than no. 8 B&S
gauge. By special permission of the electrical inspector, an approved service
entrance cable may be used in certain remodeling work where steel tube or rigid
conduit would not be practical. All service entrance cable shall be clamped
securely to the wall each eighteen inches (18"). Length of outside service wire
extensions beyond service head shall not be less than thirty inches (30"). The
size of service wires and feeders for lighting, heat and power shall be
determined by application of the national electrical code then in force. (1983
Code § 5-416)
9-3-15: SERVICE SUPPORTS:
Where service wires enter a building through stucco, tile, brick or other
masonry walls, a substantial form of support for the service wires must be
provided and installed by the electrical contractor, such support to consist of
galvanized eye bolts, one bolt being installed for each contemplated service
wire and should be installed when possible, during the construction of the
supporting wall. (1983 Code § 5-417)
9-3-16: INSIDE WIRING:
   A.   Conditions For Certain Installations: All electrical wiring hereafter
installed in all buildings inside the fire district and in all buildings to be
used as commercial, industrial, fraternal, school or church purposes shall be
installed in a complete conduit or metal molding system. Rigid iron conduit,
steel tubing or metal molding shall be used under the following conditions,
regardless of location with respect to fire limits. Also a main switch of
proper size, not smaller than one hundred (100) ampere capacity is required.
      1.   For all buildings not used exclusively as residence;
      2.   For all basements; and
      3.   In all garages having living quarters above same;
wires shall be carried in a conduit to the first opening above, whether switch
or plug, and may be continued from there in nonmetallic sheathed cable.
   B.   Prohibited Locations: In locations not mentioned in subsection A of
this section, nonmetallic sheathed cable may be used, except that it shall not
be embedded in concrete, fill or plaster, nor run in a shallow case or in
masonry or concrete or covered with plaster or similar finish.
   C.   Air Voids: Nonmetallic sheathed cable may be run or fished in the air
voids of concrete masonry blocks or tile walls where such walls are not exposed
or subject to moisture or damage.
   D.   Black Boxes, Conduit: Black boxes and black conduit may be used only
indoors and under the following exceptions: they shall not be used underground
or embedded in concrete.
   E.   Heating And Cooling Systems: For all central heating systems, floor
furnaces or other heating or cooling equipment requiring permanent electrical
connections, there must be a permit issued and all electrical connections must
be made by a licensed electrician. (1983 Code § 5-418)
9-3-17: WIRE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Lighting Inside Buildings: For general lighting inside buildings, not
more than eight (8) light outlets shall be permitted on any one circuit. There
shall be not over one thousand (1,000) watts on any branch lighting circuit of
no. 12 wire. No conductors smaller than no. 12 B&S gauge shall be permitted for
installation of any electrical wiring in the city, except low voltage
bellringer circuits.
   B.   Materials Approved By Inspector: Materials, other than those specified
in this chapter, which the electrical inspector approves as being equally
efficient, may be permitted. (1983 Code § 5-419)
9-3-18: UNDERGROUND SERVICE WIRE:
   A.   Weatherproofing: When a service entrance or any part of it is installed
underground, it must be protected by conduit with weatherhead extending
vertically at least ten feet (10') above grade, terminating on a support
adequate for attachment of the standard overhead service connection. There
shall be a weatherproof fused disconnect and meter mounting located six feet
(6') above the ground on such support. The electrical service company's pole
shall not be used for the support of the service entrance of meter.
   B.   Moisture Resistant Wire Or Lead Cable In Conduit: All connections for
this type of service shall be made with moisture resistant wire or lead cable
in conduit. Trenchlay, parkway cable or similar approved underground cable may
be used for underground service; provided, that such cable is protected by
conduit to a point where it enters a service disconnect, enters a building, or
to a distance of at least eight feet (8') above the ground. (1983 Code § 5-420)
9-3-19: SERVICE AND CONDUIT GROUNDS:
   A.   Service Grounds:
      1.   On each service, a ground wire not smaller than no. 6 must be run
from the line ground wire terminal inside the entrance switch cabinet to the
nearest water pipe, or other suitable ground in accordance with the
requirements of the national electrical code.
      2.   Grounds must not be connected to gas pipe nor to copper water pipe
having a soldered connection between ground connection and ground. Ground wires
are to have no type of splice between meter base and earth ground. (1983 Code §
5-421)
   B.   Conduit Ground: In addition to the service ground, a separate ground
wire of the proper size must be provided for the conduit and service cabinet as
required by the national electrical code. (1983 Code § 5-422)
9-3-20: WIRING IDENTIFICATION REQUIRED:
On all single phase installations, the conductors connected to the line ground
terminal must be identified by the use of an outer braid of some color other
than black finish ordinarily used on rubber covered wire. Fixtures and
receptacles shall be grounded to these identified conductors. No electrical
wire of any kind shall be grounded to any gas pipe. (1983 Code § 5-423)
9-3-21: METERS AND ASSOCIATED EQUIPMENT:
   A.   Installation; Conditions: All meters and related electrical equipment
shall be installed subject to, and in compliance with, the following
conditions:
      1.   Indoor and outdoor meters shall be installed so that the top of the
meter will not be more than six feet six inches (6'6") above the floor or
ground.
      2.   A meter board of soft lumber, and of suitable dimensions for
mounting the meter and cabinet, shall be provided as a part of the "roughing
in" job. It shall be located near the service entrance on the wall of structure
free of excessive vibration and readily accessible at all reasonable hours.
      3.   Except in business areas, outdoor metering installations shall be
installed in all new or remodeled buildings where service is to be supplied
from an overhead electricity supply system through a single meter and when the
load does not exceed one hundred (100) amperes, single phase. Such meters shall
be installed in the service entrance conduit, on the outside of the building
and on the supply side of the service disconnect device. The electric service
shall be installed as part of the service entrance by the electrical
contractor. Outdoor metering installations shall be in a protected area and not
on walls adjacent to passageways along which traffic may move.
      4.   Each set of service entrance conductors shall be provided with a
safety type fused switch or circuit breaker which shall be accessible to the
occupants of the premises being served and be of ample capacity to carry and to
interrupt the connected load.
      5.   Main service switches may be omitted on installations of not more
than six (6) branch circuits where circuit breaker panels are used, provided
the total load does not exceed sixty (60) ampere. A master service switch must
be provided for installations requiring more than six (6) switches or circuit
breakers.
      6.   Where meters are installed outside of main buildings, branch panel
cabinets shall be placed inside the buildings where they will be readily
accessible to the occupants. Outside panels may be used only by special
permission of the electrical inspector.
      7.   Circuit breakers or fuse panels approved for branch circuit
protection shall be installed on all new or remodeled old wiring installations
for lighting circuits. Breakers or panels must be in place when the electrical
inspector makes the final inspection. They shall not be installed in bathrooms,
toilet rooms or storage closets, but placed in a safe, dry, readily accessible
place.
      8.   When metering installations of one hundred (100) amperes or less are
made indoors, the electric service company shall furnish an approved meter
connection cabinet which shall be installed and connected on the load side of
the electrical city supply disconnection device by the electrical contractor
when wiring the premises. All metering installations on electricity supply
systems rated above two hundred forty (240) volts and those designated for a
capacity over one hundred (100) amperes require instrument transformers; and
for installations of this type, approved metal cabinets of sufficient size to
enclose the instrument transformers and the wiring raceway between the
instrument transformer cabinet and meters shall be furnished and installed by
the contractor as a part of the wiring. The plans and specifications of such
installations must be approved by the electrical inspector and the electric
service company before the cabinets are installed.
      9.   Not more than one circuit may be taken from any meter base, meter
cabinet or current transformer cabinet without special permission of the
electrical inspector. If more than two (2) circuits are permitted, wiring
gutters must be used.
      10.   Under no circumstances shall any meter or meters be moved or
relocated, except by authorized employees of the electric service company.
(1983 Code § 5-424)
   B.   Sealing Of Service Cabinets:
      1.   The service company shall install and maintain seals on all service,
meter and instrument transformer cabinets. Only an authorized employee of the
service company, the city electrical inspector or authorized member of the fire
department shall have authority to break the seal for inspection. In case of
emergency, an authorized employee of a licensed electrical contractor may break
the seal to replace a fuse, but in all such cases the service company shall be
notified by the party breaking the seal within twenty four (24) hours in order
that the box may be resealed.
      2.   On all new installations or remodeled installations, plug fuses and
plug fuse holders for same shall not be of the Edison type and shall be of such
type and so designed as to be subject to tampering or bridging only with
difficulty; or a multibreaker panel may be used. If an adapter is used as the
fuse holder, it shall be so designed that once inserted in its receptacle it
cannot be removed without destruction. The city electrical inspector shall, in
places where he finds overfusing or overloading of one or more circuits, have
the authority and is granted such authority to give the offender one ten (10)
day written notice to correct the same by inserting the proper size fuse
installation; and if such offender fails or refuses to correct the same within
such ten (10) day period, then the electrical inspector is granted authority to
require the installation of proper size installations or to disconnect electric
service to the offender. (1983 Code § 5-425)
   C.   Meter Loops: A separate loop shall be provided for each meter and the
length of wire in each loop shall depend on the size of the meter, but must be
sufficient to allow for the proper installation of the meter and in no case
shall the separate leads be shorter than thirty inches (30"). No meter loop
wires shall be smaller than no. 8 B&S gauge. The potential tap to the meter
shall not be less than no. 10 B&S gauge and must be suitably connected in a
permanent manner to a load side terminal of the service entrance switch. (1983
Code § 5-426)
   D.   Meter Boards: In apartment houses and buildings requiring more than one
meter, the meters shall be mounted on a common board with an approved safety
type switch provided for each meter; provided, that such for buildings of more
than two (2) stories, the meters for all customers on the same floor may be
mounted on a common board on that floor and the service entrance switch to the
distribution centers on the different floors. These conduits shall be brought
into the individual service switch cabinets without conduit fittings of any
kind other than buildings where there is more than one lighting meter. All
branch cabinets must be located in the apartment which they control. (1983 Code
§ 5-427)
   E.   Location: Meters shall be located as near as possible to the point
where the service enters the buildings, in a clean, dry place, readily
accessible at all reasonable hours, free from vibration. Meters or circuit
boxes shall not be installed in bathrooms, toilet rooms, under stairways,
storage closets, nor in any part of a building usually kept locked. They will
not be installed in kitchens or restaurants or similar places when it is
possible to place them elsewhere, and they shall in no case be installed over a
stove or range. Meters will not be located within twelve inches (12") of bus
bars, large bodies of iron or main conductor carrying a heavy current. Under no
circumstances shall any meter be moved or relocated except by the authorized
employees of the service company. It shall be the duty of the service company
to move and reset any meter upon notice of approval of the same by the city
electrical inspector. All wiring and installation including conduit, piping and
weatherheads placed in or on the side of any building in the city shall be done
by a bonded and licensed electrician, except that the power company shall run
service lines up to and bracket wires on the building to be served and make
connections to wiring leading from weatherhead to meter, and shall set the
meter when work is approved by the electrical inspector. (1983 Code § 5-428)
   F.   Shunting Prohibited: It is unlawful for any person, except a duly
authorized representative of the service company, to shunt or bypass any
current around any meter, connect or disconnect any meter, or in any manner
tamper with any electric meter. (1983 Code § 5-429)
9-3-22: LIGHTS IN OPENINGS:
All electric lights operated and maintained in bathrooms, closets, toilets,
kitchens, open porches and all outdoor lights, basement lights, or any opening
operated on the ground, shall be controlled and operated by a switch and all
openings shall be of the keyless type. (1983 Code § 5-430)
9-3-23: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter, either by doing that
which is prohibited or by failing or refusing to do that which is commanded, is
subject to punishment as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1983 Code § 5-431)
CHAPTER 4
HOUSING CODE
SECTION:
9-4-1: Housing Code Adopted
9-4-1: HOUSING CODE ADOPTED:
The southern standard housing code, latest edition, is hereby adopted in its
entirety as and for the housing code of the city. At least one copy of the code
adopted in this section shall be on file in the office of the city clerk and
available for inspection by the general public. (1983 Code § 5-501; amd. 2005
Code)
CHAPTER 5
MECHANICAL CODE
SECTION:
9-5-1: Mechanical Code Adopted
9-5-2: Definitions
9-5-3: License Required For Mechanics; Fees
9-5-4: Penalty
9-5-1: MECHANICAL CODE ADOPTED:
There is hereby adopted by reference the standard mechanical code, the latest
edition thereof, issued by the Southern Building Code Congress International,
as the mechanical code for the city. At least one copy of the code adopted in
this section shall be on file in the office of the city clerk and available for
inspection by the general public. (1983 Code § 5-901; amd. 2005 Code)
9-5-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions are applicable:
AIR CONDITIONING SYSTEM: The process of treating air by controlling its
temperature, humidity, and cleanliness, to meet the requirements of a
designated area.
BOARD: The state board of health.
COMMITTEE: The state committee of mechanical examiners.
DEPARTMENT: The Oklahoma state department of health.
GAS PIPING: Means and includes all natural gas piping within or adjacent to any
building, structure, or conveyance, on the premises and to the connection with
a natural gas meter, regulator, or other source of supply.
HEATING SYSTEMS: Mean and include systems consisting of air heating appliances
from which the heated air is distributed and shall include any accessory
apparatus and equipment installed in connection therewith.
MECHANICAL APPRENTICE OR APPRENTICE: Any person sixteen (16) years of age or
older whose principal occupation is learning mechanical work on the job under
the direct supervision of a journeyman or contractor.
MECHANICAL CONTRACTOR OR CONTRACTOR: Any person engaged in the business of
planning, contracting, supervising or furnishing labor or labor and materials
for mechanical work.
MECHANICAL FIRM: Any corporation, partnership, association, proprietorship or
other business entity which plans or engages, or offers to engage, in
mechanical work for another within this state.
MECHANICAL JOURNEYMAN OR JOURNEYMAN: Any person other than a contractor or
apprentice who engages in mechanical work.
MECHANICAL WORK: The installation, maintenance, repair, or renovation, in whole
or in part, of any heating system, cooling system, mechanical refrigeration
system or ventilation system or any equipment or material including process
piping used in the installation, maintenance, repair or renovation of such
systems; provided, that minor repairs are excluded.
REFRIGERATION SYSTEM: The erection, installation, repairing and servicing of a
system employing a fluid which normally is vaporized and liquefied in an air
conditioning system, food preservation measure or manufacturing process.
SHEET METAL: The erection, installation and repairing of all ferrous or
nonferrous duct work and all other materials used in all air conditioning.
(1983 Code § 5-902)
9-5-3: LICENSE REQUIRED FOR MECHANICS; FEES:
   A.   State And City Licenses Required: No person, firm or corporation shall
engage or offer to engage in, by advertisement or otherwise, any mechanical
work as a journeyman or contractor unless such person, firm or corporation has:
(1983 Code § 5-902; amd. 2005 Code)
      1.   Applied for and obtained from the state board of health a license to
engage in such business;
      2.   Obtained from the city clerk a city license to conduct the business
within the city.
   B.   License Fees: License fees are:
 
Contractor $50.00 per year
Journeyman 10.00 per year
Apprentice 3.00 per year
 
   C.   License Term: All such licenses will expire June 30 of each year. (1983
Code § 5-902)
9-5-4: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation who violates the provisions of this chapter by
doing that which is prohibited, or by failing or refusing to do that which is
required is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be
punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1983 Code § 5-903)
CHAPTER 6
FIRE PREVENTION CODE
SECTION:
9-6-1: Fire Prevention Code Adopted
9-6-2: Storage Of Flammables Or Explosives
9-6-3: Modifications
9-6-4: Appeals
9-6-5: Penalty
9-6-1: FIRE PREVENTION CODE ADOPTED:
   A.   Adoption:
      1.   There is hereby adopted by the city council for the purpose of
prescribing regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property
from fire or explosion, that certain code known as the fire prevention code,
latest edition, recommended by the American Insurance Association, being
particularly the current edition thereof and the whole thereof, save and except
such portions as are hereinafter deleted, modified or amended.
      2.   Not less than one copy of said code has been and now is filed in the
office of the city clerk and the same is hereby adopted and incorporated as
fully as if set out at length herein. (1983 Code § 13-101)
   B.   Definition: Wherever the word "municipality" is used in the fire
prevention code hereby adopted, it shall be held to mean the city. (1983 Code §
13-103)
   C.   Enforcement: The code hereby adopted shall be enforced by the chief of
the fire department. (1983 Code § 13-102)
9-6-2: STORAGE OF FLAMMABLES OR EXPLOSIVES:
The limits referred to in the fire prevention code in which storage of
flammable liquids in outside aboveground tanks is prohibited, the limits
referred to in which bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted, and
the limits referred to in which storage of explosives and blasting agents is
prohibited, are hereby established as the fire limits provided in section
9-1-9 of this title. (1983 Code § 13-104)
9-6-3: MODIFICATIONS:
The chief of the fire department shall have power to modify any of the
provisions of the code hereby adopted in his own discretion or upon application
in writing by the owner or lessee, or his duly authorized agent, when there are
practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the letter of the code;
provided, that the spirit of the code shall be observed, public safety secured
and substantial justice done. The particulars of such modifications when
granted or allowed and the decision of the chief of the fire department thereon
shall be entered upon the records of the department, and for applications
requesting change, a signed copy shall be furnished the applicant. (1983 Code §
13-105)
9-6-4: APPEALS:
Whenever the chief of the fire department shall disapprove an application or
refuse to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions
of the code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the code have
been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the
decision of the chief of the fire department to the city council within thirty
(30) days from the date of the decision appealed. (1983 Code § 13-106)
9-6-5: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this chapter
shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined
as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1983 Code § 13-107)
CHAPTER 7
GAS PIPING REGULATIONS
SECTION:
9-7-1: Fuel Gas Code Adopted
9-7-1: FUEL GAS CODE ADOPTED:
   A.   Adoption: Pamphlet no. 54 published by the National Fire Protection
Association, entitled "National Fuel Gas Code", is hereby adopted by reference.
This pamphlet shall be in full force and effect in the city, and shall govern
the installation of gas piping and gas appliances in buildings in the city.
(1983 Code § 5-601)
   B.   Copy On File: At least one copy of the code adopted in subsection A of
this section shall be on file in the office of the city clerk and available for
inspection by the general public. (2005 Code)
   C.   Violation: Any violation of the pamphlet shall be deemed a violation of
the ordinances of the city. (1983 Code § 5-601)
CHAPTER 8
LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GAS
SECTION:
9-8-1: Compliance With State Law
9-8-2: Inspection Required; Fee
9-8-3: Transporting Liquefied Petroleum Gas
9-8-4: Prohibited Travel
9-8-5: Delivery; Load Restriction
9-8-6: Time Of Delivery Restricted; Parking Trucks Prohibited
9-8-7: Penalty
9-8-1: COMPLIANCE WITH STATE LAW:
   A.   Compliance Required: It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation
to manufacture, fabricate, assemble, install, or repair any system, container,
apparatus, or appliance to be used for the transportation, storage, dispensing,
or utilization of liquefied petroleum gas; or to transport, handle, or store
such gas, unless such person has complied with and complies with all provisions
of the law and ordinances relating thereto, and has any license or permit which
may be required by state law. Pamphlet no. 58, "Liquefied Petroleum Gases,
Storage And Handling", issued by the National Fire Protection Association, and
adopted by the Oklahoma liquefied petroleum gas board, shall have full force
and effect within the city. (1983 Code § 5-701)
   B.   Copy On File: At least one copy of the pamphlet referred to in
subsection A of this section shall be on file in the office of the city clerk
and available for inspection by the general public. (2005 Code)
   C.   Violation: Any violation of these rules and regulations shall be deemed
a violation of the ordinances of the city and shall be punishable accordingly.
(1983 Code § 5-701)
9-8-2: INSPECTION REQUIRED; FEE:
   A.   Inspection: All liquefied petroleum installations within the city, upon
completion, shall be inspected by the plumbing inspector, or by the gas
inspector if a gas inspector is appointed, and shall not be used by the
occupants until approved by the inspector as complying with sections
9-4-1 and
9-5-1 of this title and the rules and regulations adopted thereby, and any
other applicable codes. (1983 Code § 5-702; amd. 2005 Code)
   B.   Fee: The fee for such inspection shall be set by the city council by
motion or resolution. (1983 Code § 5-702)
9-8-3: TRANSPORTING LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GAS:
It is unlawful and an offense for any person, firm or corporation to operate
any tank, tank truck or other container carrying liquefied petroleum gas on any
street or highway within the city or to store or possess any liquefied
petroleum gas or container thereof in violation of the terms of this chapter.
(1983 Code § 5-703)
9-8-4: PROHIBITED TRAVEL:
Tank trucks or tank trailers used for the transportation of liquefied petroleum
gas where the contents of such tank trucks or tank trailers is not destined for
delivery within the city shall not come within the corporate limits of the
city, or travel any street or alley within the corporate limits of the city,
except that such tank trucks or tank trailers shall be permitted to travel on
the route of U.S. 270 and on the route of State Highway 56, and on 14th Street
east and west of the city. The chief of the fire department may designate other
routes within the city to be used by such tank trucks and tank trailers in the
event of emergency or necessity. Any such tank truck or tank trailer, while so
traveling within the city limits on U.S. 270 and on State Highway 56, and on
14th Street east and west of the city, and other streets as herein provided
for, shall not be permitted to park or stop, except momentarily at designated
stop lines, and in the event of any breakdown or other mechanical emergency
where such tank truck or tank trailer is unable to proceed, the driver thereof
shall immediately notify the chief of the fire department. (1983 Code § 5-704)
9-8-5: DELIVERY; LOAD RESTRICTION:
For delivery within the limits of the city, no tank truck shall be loaded with
more than one thousand (1,000) gallons of liquefied petroleum gas. It is the
duty of the driver or operator of such tank truck to procure and have with him
at all times while making deliveries within the city, a certificate issued by
the refinery loading such tank truck and showing the amount of liquefied
petroleum gas contained in the tank truck. It is the duty of any refinery
loading such tank truck with liquefied petroleum gas for delivery within the
city to furnish the driver or operator of such tank truck such certificate
showing the amount of liquefied petroleum gas placed in such tank truck. (1983
Code § 5-705)
9-8-6: TIME OF DELIVERY RESTRICTED; PARKING TRUCKS PROHIBITED:
   A.   Time Limit: Tank trucks used for delivery of liquefied petroleum gas
within the city shall make deliveries only between the hours of eight o'clock
(8:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. While engaged in such deliveries, the
truck shall not stop or park upon any street or alley within the city except in
the observance of stop signs. When such delivery or deliveries have been
completed, such tank truck shall immediately thereafter be removed from the
city limits.
   B.   Truck Storage Prohibited In City:
      1.   No tank truck or trailer used or designed for transportation of
liquefied petroleum gas shall be stored or kept or be allowed to remain at any
time in any building within the city. No tank truck or tank trailer used for
the delivery of liquefied petroleum gas shall at any time be parked upon any
highway within the city or upon any street, parking lot, or other lot within
the city. In the event of a breakdown or other mechanical difficulty, by reason
of which such truck or tank trailer is unable to proceed, it shall be the duty
of the operator to report immediately such to the chief of the fire department.
      2.   No storage tanks or other containers of liquefied petroleum gas
shall be permitted or allowed within the city limits except the necessary tanks
and container for recreational use and within the industrial light district
when used for equipment/machine for business operation only and approved by
fire chief. (Ord. 408, 3-14-1995)
9-8-7: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of this
chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1983 Code § 5-707)
CHAPTER 9
OIL AND GAS CODE
SECTION:
9-9-1: Short Title
9-9-2: Intent And Purpose
9-9-3: Definitions
9-9-4: Applicability To Existing Conditions
9-9-5: Nondrilling Oil And Gas Well Zone
9-9-6: Enforcement
9-9-7: Permit Requirements
9-9-8: Insurance And Bond
9-9-9: Enhanced Production Wells; Disposal Wells Prohibited
9-9-10: Commencement Of Drilling Operations
9-9-11: Derricks And Rigs
9-9-12: Mud And Reserve Pits
9-9-13: Disposal Of Deleterious Substances
9-9-14: Casing
9-9-15: Valves And Blowout Preventers
9-9-16: Drill Stem Tests
9-9-17: Bradenhead
9-9-18: Christmas Tree And Wellhead Connections
9-9-19: Gaseous Discharges To Atmosphere
9-9-20: Premises Kept Clean And Sanitary
9-9-21: Motive Power
9-9-22: Storage Tanks
9-9-23: Fencing; Landscaping
9-9-24: Movement Of Heavy Equipment
9-9-25: Well Location Setbacks
9-9-26: Noise, Dust, Odors And Other Nuisances
9-9-27: Facilities; Sign And Information Required
9-9-28: Fire Prevention
9-9-29: Fracture And Acidizing
9-9-30: Plugging And Restoration
9-9-31: Rupture Of Surface Casing
9-9-32: Depositing Hazardous Materials
9-9-33: Safety Precautions
9-9-34: Appeals
9-9-35: Zoning
9-9-36: Violations
9-9-37: Penalty
9-9-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as the OIL AND GAS CODE and may be cited as such.
(Ord. 462, 2-12-2008)
9-9-2: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
   A.   Imprudent operation of an oil and gas facility, whether that facility
is involved in drilling or production, can and has constituted a menace to the
public health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city, and includes:
      1.   The potential for serious contamination of water wells within the
city;
      2.   A threat to the health and physical safety of children and other
residents of the city who may live, work or play in the area of operation; a
disturbance of the city's peace and serenity through noxious odors, dust, and
loud noises;
      3.   A general threat to the well being in the community through
potential fire dangers, fluid spills and other damages to the surface; and
      4.   A threat of physical destruction of municipal facilities caused by
heavy equipment.
   B.   It is therefore the intent and purpose of this chapter to recognize the
legitimate interests of oil and gas operations but to reasonably and uniformly
regulate those operations in harmony with the activities and land uses within
the city for the general benefit of the public good. (Ord. 462, 2-12-2008)
9-9-3: DEFINITIONS:
All technical or oil and gas industry words or phrases used herein and not
specifically defined in this chapter shall have that meaning customarily
attributable thereto by prudent operators of the oil and gas industry.
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the scope and
meanings hereafter defined and set out in connection with each, and this scope
and meanings shall apply wherever and whenever used:
ABANDONED WELL: Any natural production well in which production casing has been
run but which has not been operated for six (6) months. The term shall also
mean any well in which no production casing has been run and for which drilling
operations have ceased for thirty (30) consecutive days, or which has otherwise
not been developed or operated with due diligence.
COMPLETION PROCESS: Any operations conducted after the setting and cementing of
the casing and after notification thereof in writing given to the city building
official or his designee.
CORPORATION COMMISSION: The Oklahoma corporation commission.
DELETERIOUS SUBSTANCE: Any chemical, salt water, oil field brine, waste oil,
waste emulsified oil, basic sediment, freshwater drilling fluids, or injurious
substances produced or used in the drilling, development, production,
transportation, refining, or processing of oil, gas or condensate, and all
substances used in the completion process.
DEVELOPED AREA: Any area within the corporate limits of the city and designated
with a zoning classification other than AG agricultural, IL industrial (light),
or IH industrial (heavy).
DRILLING PROCESS: Any operations from the beginning of operations until the
beginning of the completion process.
ENHANCED PRODUCTION: Any secondary or tertiary operation by which potable or
treated water is introduced into a source of supply for the purpose of
stimulating recovery therefrom.
INSPECTOR: Any person designated by the city manager to make inspections
provided for in this chapter, whether or not other duties are additionally
assigned.
LEASE: Any tract of land subject to an oil, gas or mineral lease or other oil
and gas development contract, or any unit composed of several tracts and leases
but operated as a single lease; and any tract of land in which the minerals are
owned by an operator or someone holding under him, which, due to the royalty
ownership, is developed as a separate tract.
MUD PROGRAM: The planned usage of drilling fluid lubricants (also known in the
industry as "mud"), specifying with particularity the type names, physical and
chemical composition, and the characteristics of all ingredients thereof,
together with such laboratory and other technical data as may be necessary or
required by the city to evaluate the same as a potential source of pollution.
NATURAL PRODUCTION: The raising of petroleum and/or natural gas to the surface
of the earth by natural flow.
NONDELETERIOUS SUBSTANCE: Only nontoxic and nonpolluting water based drilling
fluids and solids.
PERMITTEE: The person to whom is issued a permit under the terms of this
chapter.
PERSON: Shall include both the singular and plural and shall also mean and
include any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, club,
society, cooperative, trust, municipal corporation, or political subdivision
regardless of form. When and after activity or omission is forbidden to a
person, that activity or omission is forbidden whether the person is acting for
himself or for another, and whether the activity or omission is performed
directly or through an agent, servant, employee, subcontractor or independent
contractor.
POLLUTION: The contamination or other alteration of the physical, chemical, or
biological properties of any natural waters of the city or lands within the
city; or such discharge of any liquid, gaseous, or solid substance into any
water of the city or upon any lands within the city as will or is likely to
create a nuisance or render such waters or such lands harmful or detrimental to
public health, safety or welfare; or which will render such waters or such
lands harmful or detrimental to domestic, commercial, industrial, agricultural,
recreational, or other beneficial uses; or which will render such waters or
such lands harmful or detrimental to livestock, animals, or aquatic life.
WATER OR WATER OF THE CITY: All streams, lakes, ponds, marshes, watercourses,
waterways, wells, springs, irrigation systems, and all other bodies or
accumulations of water whether on the surface or underground, whether natural
or artificial, whether publicly or privately owned or maintained, and which are
either contained within, flow through, or border upon the city or any portion
thereof.
WELL: Shall include and mean any hole or holes, bore or bores, to any sand,
formation, strata, or depth for the purpose of producing and recovering any
petroleum, oil, gaseous liquid hydrocarbon, or any other liquefied matter or
gaseous matter. (Ord. 462, 2-12-2008)
9-9-4: APPLICABILITY TO EXISTING CONDITIONS:
This chapter and all amendments hereto shall apply to any person drilling an
original well, reentering an abandoned well, or maintaining a well within the
city on or after January 1, 1983. Every person whose activity preexists January
1, 1983, shall be exempt from all of the requirements of this chapter. (Ord.
462, 2-12-2008)
9-9-5: NONDRILLING OIL AND GAS WELL ZONE:
   A.   Boundaries Designated:
      1.   There is created a nondrilling oil and gas well zone, which zone is
included within the following boundaries: commencing at the intersection of
Tenth Street with Wewoka Avenue, thence west along Tenth Street to Seminole
Avenue; thence north along Seminole Avenue to Park Street; thence east on Park
Street to the point where Park Street intersects with CRI and Pacific Railroad
right of way to Muskogee Avenue; thence south on Muskogee Avenue to Fourth
Street; thence east on Fourth Street to Brown Avenue; thence south on Brown
Avenue to Sixth Street; thence west on Sixth Street to Muskogee Avenue; thence
west on Ninth Street to Wewoka Avenue; thence south on Wewoka Avenue to the
point of beginning and the SE/4 SE/4 Section 20, T8N, R83 Seminole County,
Oklahoma commonly described as the Wewoka Municipal Golf Course. (Ord. 471, 7-
14-2009)
      2.   All property within the above described limits shall constitute a
nondrilling oil and gas well zone.
   B.   Drilling Unlawful: It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation
to drill, sink, dig or bore or cause to be drilled, sunk, dug or bored an oil
or gas well on any of the property embraced within the above described
nondrilling zone. (Ord. 462, 2-12-2008)
9-9-6: ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Enforcement Officials: The city manager and his duly authorized
representatives, including the chief of the fire department, the fire marshal,
the city engineer, and the building official, shall enforce the provisions of
this chapter and shall have all of the power and authority granted by law to
peace and health officers.
   B.   Right Of Entry: Enforcement personnel may enter the leased premises for
any purpose pursuant to this chapter at all reasonable times to inspect same or
to perform any duty imposed by this chapter. No person having an ownership
interest in, or control of, the leased premises shall fail or neglect to permit
prompt entry, after proper demand, to the site of the oil and gas operations.
(Ord. 462, 2-12-2008)
9-9-7: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Required; Transfer Of Permit:
      1.   No person shall engage in or authorize any work or erect any
structures, tanks, machinery, pipelines, or other appurtenances incident to the
drilling of a well or drilling for or production of petroleum, natural gas, or
their products; nor operate, maintain, or permit any equipment, structures or
appurtenances incident to such production to exist or be maintained; nor allow
any flow therefrom without a permit having first been issued by the city in
accordance with this chapter.
      2.   A permit is transferable to the person who acquires the legal right
to produce oil or gas from the well in question, but notices served upon the
record permittee shall be binding upon the transferee until such time as the
transferee designates a new service agent. The transferee shall notify the city
in writing of the name and address of transferee and his service agent within
ten (10) days of the effective date of the transfer.
   B.   Application And Filing Fee:
      1.   Every application for a permit to drill and operate a well,
including a reentry to an abandoned well, shall be verified under oath and in
writing, and signed by the applicant or some duly authorized person who may
sign on the applicant's behalf.
