landmark site shall be granted by the building inspector as provided in this
city code without the prior written approval of the commission. (1983 Code §
12-610)
   C.   Application Review; Minimum Performance Conditions: In reviewing
applications for permits, the commission shall be guided in its review of such
permits by the intent and purpose of this chapter and by the following minimum
performance conditions, which shall be followed within the Wewoka switch
development district and in any district hereinafter designated pursuant to the
provisions of this chapter. (1983 Code § 12-611)
9-11-8: PERMIT CRITERIA:
The commission shall issue a permit for any proposed work as described in
subsections
9-11-7B and C, and sections
9-11-10 and
9-11-11 of this chapter if it determines:
   A.   In the case of a designated landmark or landmark site, that the
proposed work will not detrimentally alter, destroy, or adversely affect any
exterior architectural feature;
   B.   In the case of any property located within the designated district, the
proposed construction, removal, rehabilitation, alteration, remodeling,
excavation or exterior alteration conforms to the minimum performance
conditions as set forth in subsection and
9-11-7C, and sections
9-11-10 and
9-11-11 of this chapter, and does not adversely affect the character of the
district; or
   C.   In the case of construction of a new improvement, building or structure
upon a landmark site, the exterior of such improvement will not adversely
affect and will be compatible with the external appearance of other existing
improvements, buildings and structures of the site. (Ord. 415, 3-12-1996)
9-11-9: PERMIT PROCEDURE:
The following procedure shall be followed in processing applications for
building permits required by this chapter:
   A.   Filing Initial Application: An initial application for approval of work
as defined in this chapter shall be filed with the commission.
   B.   Accompanying Documents: Such application shall be accompanied by the
following documents:
      1.   An elevation of each side of the existing or proposed building,
drawn to scale, with all materials, textures and colors to be used identified
and shown. Samples of such materials may be requested by the commission for
processing the application.
      2.   A site plan, drawn to scale, indicating existing topography,
vegetation, structures, and adjacent development.
      3.   Drawings of exterior building details including light standards and
fixtures, screens for mechanical equipment or trash, meters and meter boxes,
existing and proposed signs and such other details as may exist on any
building.
      4.   Drawings of structures or furniture to be placed on parcels of land
within the designated district including, but not limited to, fences, signs and
lighting standards.
      5.   True, correct and complete copies of old photographs or historical
records, if available, which pertain to the existing building or site.
      6.   Where the application includes grading and drainage work, a plan
indicating existing (with a solid line) and proposed (with a dashed line)
contours at two foot (2') or five foot (5') intervals, plus all existing
features of the grade.
      7.   Conceptual landscaping plans where changes of landscaping are
proposed.
      8.   Construction which will significantly interrupt the view or vista
from a public street or sidewalkway must be visually apparent on the site plan.
Documentation showing that alternative methods of preserving public sight lines
have been considered must be submitted.
   C.   Time Limit For Commission Decision: The commission shall complete the
review and make a decision within thirty (30) days of the date of receipt of
the application. (1983 Code § 12-615)
9-11-10: NEW CONSTRUCTION CONDITIONS:
In any new construction, the design shall relate to those elements historically
found in adjacent buildings and shall also relate to the total design character
of the district:
   A.   Brick Siding: Brick shall be the preferred exterior siding material for
new buildings. The color and texture of new brick shall approximate that of
predominant brick material used historically in the city.
   B.   Facades: Facades for new commercial buildings in the Wewoka switch
development district shall be rectangular in shape and their proportions of
width in relation to height shall be compatible with the proportions of other
existing buildings in the same block; however, the principal directional
expression of new facades may be either horizontal or vertical.
   C.   Awnings: Awnings or triangular shaped sidewalk roofs attached above
street level storefronts shall be encouraged, and mansard, freeform or
geometric sidewalk roofs shall be discouraged.
   D.   Construction Scale: The construction scale of any new building shall be
compatible with the scale of historic buildings and other buildings in the
Wewoka switch development district. Materials, signs, and other elements of new
construction shall be consistent with the scale of other similar elements found
in the historic buildings in the district.
   E.   Landscaping: Landscaping shall follow the minimum performance
conditions for rehabilitation and preservation under the terms of this chapter.
Street furniture, trash containers and all planting beds shall be compatible
with the character of the district.
   F.   Conformance With Minimum Performance Conditions: Canopies, awnings,
exterior colors and signs or markers shall be in conformance with the minimum
performance conditions for rehabilitation and preservation under the terms of
this chapter. (1983 Code § 12-611)
9-11-11: REHABILITATION AND PRESERVATION CONDITIONS:
In any rehabilitation or preservation, the design shall relate to those
elements historically found in adjacent buildings and shall also relate to the
total design character of the district:
   A.   Facades:
      1.   Each original facade within the Wewoka switch development district
shall not be changed and shall be preserved in its entirety or in an amount not
less than seventy five percent (75%) of the original surface area of the
facade. Facades that have been altered shall be restored where possible
retaining original material wherever such original material is still in place.
Cast iron or stone steps, brick or stone sills and other elements contributing
to the character of facade entries shall be preserved.
      2.   Where existing architectural design dates from an interim remodeling
and such remodeling adds to the historical character of the district,
restoration may conform to the remodeling and not to the original design.
      3.   Where the original design of the building cannot be determined, or
where full scale restoration is determined not to be economically feasible by
the commission, a design of a facade in keeping with the remainder of the
buildings in the same block shall be deemed acceptable. A contemporary design
may be approved by the commission in such circumstances; provided, that the
design is compatible with the remainder of the buildings in the same block in
scale, proportion, material, color, rhythm of solids to voids, repetition of
design elements and directional expression whether such expression shall be
vertical or horizontal.
      4.   Facades finished in decorative metal shall be preserved and
refinished so that such metal appointments will be retained. Textured metal
interior or exterior ceilings shall be retained.
      5.   The use of canvass awnings within the district shall be encouraged.
The size and scale of such awnings shall be appropriate for the building to
which they are attached, and the installation of such awnings shall be based
upon historical photographic or pictorial evidence where available. (1983 Code
§ 12-613)
      6.   Any business sign, logo or advertisement attached to or suspended
from the facade of any building or painted on the show windows and/or doors of
any business within the district shall be kept maintained and cleaned so as to
be presentable and present a positive image. Rusted, faded, broken or in any
other way deteriorated signs shall be repaired or replaced. Businesses that
move or cease operation shall remove such signs from the facade, windows and
doors of their buildings. In cases where the building is or was a rental
property, the property owner has the ultimate responsibility for removal of
signs from closed or vacated businesses. (Ord. 422, 7-8-1997)
   B.   Windows And Doors:
      1.   Original sills, lintels, frames, sash, and glass windows and
transoms shall be preserved and repaired. Original doorway elements shall be
preserved. Replacements for original materials shall duplicate original
specifications for such materials.
      2.   Translucent or clear glass may be used in windows, doors and
transoms. Plastic or synthetic glazing shall be prohibited.
      3.   Blocking of existing wall openings to accommodate standard door
frames, window sashes, and glass sizes to hide ceilings lowered beneath the
tops of existing windows shall be discouraged. Original dimensions of existing
wall openings shall be retained.
      4.   Decorative wood or metal lintels, brackets, and other window or
doorway trim shall be preserved and should be restored where possible.
      5.   Aluminum sashes and screens, when used, shall match historic frames
and sash features in white bronze or black finish. The same conditions shall
apply to aluminum door frames and screen doors.
      6.   Any remaining fire shutters or doors which are in original condition
shall be preserved. In restoration, where documents or photographs indicate the
presence of such features, reinstallation shall be encouraged. Replica fire
shutters and doors need not duplicate original specifications.
   C.   Cornices:
      1.   Restoration of cornices in original materials shall be preferred to
duplication in contemporary materials. When the commission determines that
restoration using original materials is not feasible, the use of contemporary
materials shall be acceptable. An acceptable alternative to full scale
restoration is construction of a new cornice with contemporary materials
duplicating original design. Surviving original cornice elements shall be
preserved where possible.
      2.   Wood and metal cornices shall be painted duplicating original
colors. When original colors cannot be determined, use of subdued tones shall
be encouraged including blacks and browns, bone whites, or buff colors.
Florescent or "day-glo" colors shall be prohibited.
      3.   Brick corbels shall be preserved and shall be restored and treated
in the same manner as brick wall surfaces where possible.
      4.   All gutters, downspouts and flashing shall be visually
inconspicuous.
   D.   Roofs And Rooflines:
      1.   All building roofs and rooflines shall retain their original shapes.
      2.   Contemporary roofing materials shall be acceptable. Where visible
from a public street or sidewalk, roofing materials shall be dark and
unobtrusive.
   E.   Brick And Stone:
      1.   Brick and stone are the predominant building materials in the Wewoka
switch development district. Such materials shall be treated in a manner which
will foster preservation, and they shall not be defaced or treated in a manner
which will accelerate deterioration. Synthetic materials shall not be used as a
covering. Stucco, asbestos shingles or siding, wood, aluminum siding or
plastics as covering shall be prohibited.
      2.   Since sandblasting accelerates brick and stone deterioration, this
process shall not be used as a cleaning method.
      3.   Brick and stone may be cleaned by applying mild chemical solutions;
by scrubbing with soft wire brushes; or by spraying with water under high
pressure or by steam cleaning.
      4.   Brick or stone which has been sandblasted prior to the adoption of
this chapter should be silicone treated once every four (4) years to repel
moisture.
      5.   In repointing, deteriorated mortar shall be raked out to a depth of
one-half inch (1/2") in both vertical and horizontal joints and then washed to
remove small loose particles. Hammer and chisel shall be the preferred means
for old mortar removal. New mortar shall approximate the proportions of lime,
sand, and other materials in the old mortar. The process of matching old mortar
will be such that it will assure proper color and texture and will match the
chemical composition of existing mortar.
      6.   When deteriorated brick or stone must be replaced, such replacement
brick or stone shall match the old material in color, texture, size and
alignment or coursing technique. Replacement brick shall be placed flush with
other bricks and mortar shall be laid in the same area of bond as the original.
      7.   Repainting is the preferred treatment for brick or stone material
which has been painted previously; however, the color of paint applied shall
match as closely as possible the natural color of the material. Brick or stone
which has not been painted previously shall be painted only when it is required
to unify a facade where repair work fails to match original appearance and is
visually disruptive.
      8.   The treatment recommended for brick that has been covered with
stucco prior to the adoption of this chapter is smoothing the surface with a
skim or light coat of stucco and painting such surface a color approaching the
natural color of brick or stone. Artificial mortar joints may be suggested by
painting in mortar joints in a color approximating the natural color of mortar.
   F.   Color:
      1.   Color choices may express individual taste, but shall always be
colors which contribute to the character of the individual district. Such color
choices shall be based on precedent and shall harmonize with other colors on
the same building and on the same streetscape. Bright and high gloss paints and
colors shall be prohibited.
      2.   Where wood or metal surfaces of windows, doors, porches, and other
details other than cornices are to be painted, a range of color choices shall
be available. Muted and earth as well as off white or buff colors shall be
favored, including, but not limited to, gray, brown, blue gray, beige, brick
red and terra cotta. Lead white shall be an appropriate trim and detail color.
      3.   Where brick and stone work has been painted, repairing in a color
equivalent to the color of natural brick or stone shall be preferred. Mortar
joints may also be painted in a color equivalent to natural mortar color. Lead
white shall be an acceptable color where the paint history of the building
indicates the previous use of colors other than brick red. Brick or stone
buildings which have not been painted previously shall not be painted, except
as indicated in subsection E7 of this section.
      4.   The use of one or two (2) colors in addition to white, black or gray
shall be acceptable. Secondary colors shall be used on major design or
structural elements and shall not be used to pick out individual details.
   G.   Street Accessories:
      1.   Signs and graphics for which the city is responsible shall be of
traditional style single lettering consistent in color.
      2.   Parking lots and waste receptacles shall be screened from public
view by fences, earth berm or shrubbery. (1983 Code § 12-613)
9-11-12: DEMOLITION OR REMOVAL:
It shall be unlawful to demolish, take down, or remove any improvement,
structure, building, or landmark within the Wewoka switch development district
or within any district designated by this chapter, unless such improvement,
structure, building or landmark has become so damaged or dilapidated that it is
a threat to the safety, health, and general welfare of the citizens of the
city. (1983 Code § 12-616)
9-11-13: ORDINARY MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR:
Nothing in this chapter shall prevent the ordinary maintenance and repair of
any architectural feature in or on any property within the designated district
and which maintenance or repair does not involve any change in design,
material, or external appearance thereof. (1983 Code § 12-618)
9-11-14: REQUIRED MAINTENANCE; PENALTY FOR NEGLECT:
   A.   Repair Of Defects: All buildings and structures within the Wewoka
switch development district or within any district hereinafter designated
pursuant to the terms of this chapter shall be preserved against decay and
deterioration and shall be kept free from certain structural defects by the
owner thereof. Such owner shall repair such building or structure if the
building inspector of the city determines that such building or structure has
any one or a combination of the following defects:
      1.   Any unsafe or nonweather sound condition.
      2.   Any exterior or interior architectural feature or supporting member
which has fallen or separated from or is likely to fall or separate from the
building or structure.
      3.   Deteriorated, inadequate and unsafe foundations, floors, walls,
joists, ceilings, roofs, chimneys and any ineffectively watertight exterior
feature, door, or window.
   B.   Notice Of Defect; Failure To Correct:
      1.   Upon a finding by the building inspector that any one or a part or
combination of the above conditions exists, the inspector shall forthwith issue
a notice to correct such defects, which notice shall be delivered in person or
by mail to the owner or owners as listed on the tax rolls of the treasurer of
Seminole County. Such notice shall contain the title and section of this
chapter applicable thereto, and shall, upon postmark or personal delivery,
provide the owner with ninety (90) consecutive calendar days to correct such
defect or defects.
      2.   Failure of the owner to take any action to correct such defects
within such ninety (90) day period shall be deemed an offense and shall be
punishable by a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. Each day of continuing violation shall be deemed a separate
offense.
   C.   Extension Of Time: If the owner has begun but not finished repair or
corrective work on such building or structure within the ninety (90) day period
defined herein, the inspector may grant an extension of time in which such work
must be completed, but such extension shall be for a period of not more than
one hundred eighty (180) days from the end of the initial ninety (90) day
notification period defined herein.
   D.   Injunctive Relief: In addition to any of the foregoing remedies, the
commission may institute an action for injunctive relief to restrain or enjoin
or to cause the correction or removal of any violation of this chapter, or for
a permanent injunction in an appropriate case, and based on the individual
merits of such a case. (Ord. 415, 3-12-1996)
9-11-15: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any part or provision of this chapter shall be guilty
of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this code. Each day of continuing violation shall be deemed a separate
offense. (1983 Code § 12-620)
TITLE 10
ZONING REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
PURPOSE; INTERPRETATION; DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
10-1-1: Short Title
10-1-2: Purposes
10-1-3: Interpretation
10-1-4: Jurisdiction
10-1-5: Definitions
10-1-1: SHORT TITLE:
This title shall be known and may be cited and referred to as the WEWOKA ZONING
CODE. (Ord., 3-8-1971; amd. 2005 Code)
10-1-2: PURPOSES:
This title is enacted for the following purposes:
   A.   Cooperating with the state of Oklahoma in conserving the natural
resources of the state and promoting the health, safety, peace, morals,
comfort, convenience, prosperity, order, and general welfare of the people of
the state.
   B.   Lessening danger and congestion of public transportation and travel.
   C.   Securing safety from fire and other dangers.
   D.   Preventing overcrowding of land.
   E.   Avoiding undue concentration of population.
   F.   Providing adequate police protection, transportation, water, sewerage,
schools, parks, forests, recreational facilities, military and naval
facilities, and other public requirements, and preventing undue encroachment
thereon. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-1-3: INTERPRETATION:
   A.   Abrogation And Greater Restriction: Where this title imposes a greater
restriction upon the use of structures or land or upon height or bulk of
structures, or requires larger open spaces or yards than are imposed by other
ordinances or regulations, the provisions of this title shall govern.
   B.   Severability: In case any portion of this title shall be invalid or
unconstitutional, as declared by a court of competent jurisdiction, the
remainder of this title shall not thereby be invalid, but shall remain in full
force and effect.
   C.   Provisions Not Affected By Headings: Chapter, article, section, and
subsection headings contained in this title shall not be deemed to govern,
limit, modify, or in any other manner affect the scope, meaning, or intent of
any provision of this title. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-1-4: JURISDICTION:
   A.   Territorial Jurisdiction: This title shall be in full force and effect
in the corporate limits of the city.
   B.   Annexed Territory: When any territory shall be brought into the zoning
jurisdiction of the city, by annexation or otherwise, such territory shall be
deemed to be in an AG agriculture district. This provision shall not operate to
preclude subsequent rezoning of such property by amendment in the manner set
forth in chapter 10 of this title.
   C.   City Owned Or Operated Property: Property owned, leased or operated by
the city, or any other public or governmental body or agency, shall be subject
to the terms of this title. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-1-5: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this title, certain terms and words are to be used and
interpreted as defined in this section. Words used in the present tense shall
include the future tense; words in the singular number include the plural and
words in the plural number include the singular, except where the natural
construction of the writing indicates otherwise. The word "shall" is mandatory
and not directory.
ACCESSORY USE OR STRUCTURE: A use or structure on the same lot with, and of a
nature customarily incidental and subordinate to, the principal use or
structure.
BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT: The board of adjustment of the city.
BUILDING: Any structure which:
   A.   Is permanently affixed to the land.
   B.   Has one or more floors and a roof.
   C.   Is bounded by either another building with a common party wall, open
air, or the lot lines of a lot.
CARE HOME: Premises used for the housing and caring for the aged or infirm, and
includes convalescent homes, homes for the aged, and nursing homes.
CITY COUNCIL: The mayor and council members of the city.
COMMUNITY BASED CARE FACILITY: A facility where two (2) or more persons are
housed under partial or total restraint for incarceration, detention, reform,
behavior modification or other similar purposes.
CURB LEVEL: The mean level of the established curb at the frontage of a lot.
Where no curb has been established, the city engineer shall establish such curb
level or its equivalent for the purposes of this title.
DISPLAY SURFACE: The surface of a sign upon, against or through which the
message is displayed or illustrated.
DISPLAY SURFACE AREA: The net geometric area enclosed by the display surface of
the sign including the outer extremities of all letters, figures, characters
and delineations; provided, however, "display surface area" shall not include
the structural supports for freestanding signs if said structural supports are
not arranged to become a part of the attention attracting aspects of the sign;
provided further, that both faces of a double faced sign shall be included in
the computation of "display surface area".
DWELLING: A building or structure used in whole or in part for human
habitation.
DWELLING, DUPLEX: A building containing two (2) dwelling units, designed for
occupancy by not more than two (2) families.
DWELLING, MOBILE HOME: A detached dwelling unit designed for transportation,
after fabrication, on streets or highways on its own wheels or on a flatbed or
other trailer, and arriving at the site where it is to be occupied as a
dwelling complete and ready for occupancy, except for minor and incidental
unpacking and assembly operations, location on jacks or other temporary or
permanent foundation, connection to utilities, and similar installation
activities.
DWELLING, MULTI-FAMILY: A building containing three (3) or more dwelling units.
DWELLING, SINGLE-FAMILY: A building, other than a mobile home, containing one
dwelling unit designed for occupancy by not more than one family.
DWELLING UNIT: A room or group of rooms arranged, intended or designed as a
habitable unit, containing kitchen, bath, and sleeping facilities, for not more
than one family living independently of any other family.
FAMILY: One or more persons occupying a single dwelling unit; provided, that
unless all members are related by blood, marriage, or adoption, no such family
shall contain over five (5) persons; but further provided, that domestic
servants may be housed on the premises without being designated as a family.
FLOODPLAIN: The land area adjoining a watercourse or drainway which would be
inundated by the floodwater of the 100-year frequency flood, based on full
urbanization of the watershed, as predicted by the city engineer, or as
predicted by the USDA soil conservation service and confirmed by the city
engineer.
FLOOR AREA: The sum of the gross horizontal areas of the several floors,
including basement, of a building measured from the exterior faces of the
exterior walls or from the centerline of walls separating two (2) buildings.
Provided that for the purpose of determining compliance with the permitted
floor area, the floor area of enclosed required off street parking areas shall
not be included.
FLOOR AREA RATIO: The floor area of a building or buildings on a zoning lot
divided by the lot area.
FRONTAGE: The lineal measurement of a zoning lot boundary or boundaries which
abut a public street.
HEIGHT, BUILDING OR STRUCTURE: The vertical distance measured, in the case of
flat roofs, from the curb level to the level of the highest point of the roof
beams adjacent to the street wall, and in the case of pitched roofs, from the
curb level to the mean height level of the gable. Where no roof beam exists,
the height shall be measured from the curb level to the highest point of the
building or structure.
LAND AREA: The area of a lot, plus one-half (1/2) or thirty feet (30'),
whichever is less, of the right of way of any abutting street to which the lot
has access.
LIVABILITY SPACE: The open space of a lot which is not allocated to or used for
off street parking or loading areas.
LOADING BERTH, OFF STREET: A space of at least ten feet (10') in width and
thirty feet (30') in length and having a vertical clearance of at least
fourteen feet (14'), designed and located in a lot for the temporary parking of
commercial vehicles while loading or unloading merchandise or materials.
LOT: A lot of record.
LOT LINE: Any boundary of a lot.
LOT LINE, FRONT: The boundary of a lot which abuts a public street. Where the
lot abuts more than one street, the owner may select the front lot line.
LOT LINE, REAR: The boundary of a lot which is most distant from and most
nearly parallel to the front lot line.
LOT LINE, SIDE: Any boundary of a lot which is not a front lot line or a rear
lot line.
LOT OF RECORD: A lot which is a part of a subdivision, the plat of which has
been recorded in the office of the county clerk of the county in which the lot
is located or a parcel of land, the deed of which is recorded in the office of
the county clerk of the county in which the parcel is located.
LOT WIDTH: The average horizontal distance between the side lot lines.
MAJOR STREET PLAN: The city major street and highway plan.
NEC: Not elsewhere classified.
100-YEAR FREQUENCY FLOOD: A flood having an average frequency of occurrence
once in one hundred (100) years although the flood may occur in any year, based
on statistical analyses of stream flow records available for the watershed and
analyses of rainfall and runoff characteristics in the general region of the
watershed, as predicted by the city engineer, or as predicted by the USDA soil
conservation service and confirmed by the city engineer.
OPEN SPACE: The portions of a lot which are open and unobstructed from its
lowest level to the sky; provided, that fences and patios shall not be deemed
obstructions.
PARKING SPACE, OFF STREET: A space on a lot intended and reserved for the
parking of an automobile. Such space shall be at least ten feet in width by
twenty feet in length (10' x 20'), together with a driveway connecting the
space with a street or alley and permitting ingress or egress of an automobile.
PLANNING COMMISSION: The Wewoka planning commission.
SETBACK: A horizontal distance determining the location of a building with
respect to a street, use district boundary line, or another use. Where the term
"setback" is used in conjunction with a modifying word or words such as
"parking area", the setback shall in its application include, but not be
limited to, building.
SIGN, BUSINESS: A sign which directs attention to a business, commodity,
service or entertainment conducted on the premises.
SIGN, OUTDOOR ADVERTISING: A sign which directs attention to a business,
commodity, service, or entertainment, sold or offered elsewhere than the
premises and only incidentally on the premises, if at all.
SPECIAL EXCEPTION: A use or a design element of a use which is not permitted by
right in a particular district because of potential adverse effect, but which
if controlled in the particular instance as to its relationship to the
neighborhood and to the general welfare, may be permitted by the board of
adjustment, where specifically authorized by this title, and in accordance with
the substantive and procedural standards of this title.
STREET WALL: The wall or part of the building nearest to the street line.
STRUCTURE: Anything constructed or erected with a fixed location on the ground,
or attached to something having a fixed location on the ground, and includes
buildings, walks, fences, and signs.
VARIANCE: A relaxation of a restriction of the zoning title, granted by the
board of adjustment, where by reason of exceptional narrowness, shallowness,
shape, topography, or other extraordinary or exceptional situation, condition
or circumstance of a particular property, the literal enforcement of this title
restriction, would result in unnecessary hardship.
YARD: An open unoccupied space on a lot between a building and a lot line.
YARD, FRONT: A yard extending along the full length of the front lot line
between the side lot lines.
YARD, REAR: A yard extending along the full length of the rear lot line between
the side lot lines.
YARD REQUIRED: The minimum permitted distance of open unoccupied space between
a building and a lot line.
YARD, SIDE: A yard extending along a side lot line between the front yard and
the rear yard. (Ord., 3-8-1971; amd. Ord. 435, 9-23-1999)
CHAPTER 2
ENFORCEMENT
SECTION:
10-2-1: Building Inspector And Other Officials
10-2-2: Zoning Clearance Permit
10-2-3: Penalty
10-2-1: BUILDING INSPECTOR AND OTHER OFFICIALS:
   A.   Enforcement Authority Delegated: It shall be the duty of the building
inspector to enforce this title. If the building inspector shall find that any
of the provisions of this title are being violated, he shall notify in writing
the persons responsible for such violations, indicating the nature of the
violation and ordering the action necessary to correct it, and shall take such
other action as is authorized by this title to ensure compliance with or to
prevent violation of its provisions.
   B.   Compliance By City Officials: All departments, officials, and employees
of the city vested with the duty or authority to issue permits or licenses
shall comply with the provisions of this title and shall issue no permit or
license for any use, purpose, excavation, construction, structure, building, or
sign in conflict with the provisions of this title. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-2-2: ZONING CLEARANCE PERMIT:
   A.   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, move,
add to or structurally alter any building or structure, or to use or change the
use of any building or land or to permit the aforementioned actions, until a
zoning clearance permit has been issued by the building inspector.
   B.   Application For Permit: An application for a zoning clearance permit
shall be accompanied by a legal description of the zoning lot, and plans in
duplicate, drawn to scale in black line or blueprint, showing the actual shape
and dimension of the lot; the location, size, and height of any existing
buildings or structures and the location, size, and height of any buildings or
structures to be erected or altered; the existing and intended use of each
building or structure and portion of the lot; the number of dwellings the
building is intended to accommodate, if any; and such other information with
regard to the lot and neighboring lots as may be necessary to determine and
provide for the enforcement of this title.
   C.   Time Limit For Action: The building inspector shall act upon each
application for a zoning clearance permit within three (3) days after it is
filed in compliance with the provisions herein. He shall return one copy of the
plans and issue a zoning clearance permit or notify the applicant, in writing,
of his refusal to issue a permit setting forth the reasons therefor.
   D.   Permit Fees: No zoning clearance permit shall be issued until a fee of
two dollars ($2.00) shall have been paid; provided that, upon the payment of
ten dollars ($10.00), a group zoning clearance permit may be issued covering
five (5) or more residential lots in the same subdivision. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-2-3: PENALTY:
   A.   Penalty Imposed: Any person, firm or corporation violating any
provisions of this title or failing to comply with any of its requirements,
including violations of conditions and safeguards established in connection
with grants of variances or special exceptions, shall be deemed guilty of an
offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not more than one hundred
dollars ($100.00), and each day's violation thereof shall constitute a separate
offense.
   B.   Remedial Action: Nothing herein contained shall prevent the city or its
authorized officials from taking such other lawful action as is necessary to
prevent or remedy violations. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
CHAPTER 3
BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT
SECTION:
10-3-1: Board Established; Membership
10-3-2: Powers
10-3-3: Meetings And Proceedings
10-3-4: Appeals From Building Inspector Decisions
10-3-5: Interpretation Of Zoning Text And Map
10-3-6: Variances
10-3-7: Special Exceptions
10-3-8: Appeals From Board Decisions
10-3-1: BOARD ESTABLISHED; MEMBERSHIP:
   A.   Board Established: There is hereby established a board of adjustment of
the city with the powers and duties hereinafter set forth. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
   B.   Membership; Terms; Compensation: The board of adjustment shall consist
of five (5) members and one alternate, who shall be nominated by the mayor and
confirmed by the council, and shall serve without pay for a term of three (3)
years. (Ord. 478, 3-13-2012)
   C.   Vacancies: Vacancies shall be filled for an unexpired term of any
member in the manner set forth for appointments to a full term.
   D.   Removal: A board member may be removed for cause by the appointing
authority after notice, written charges and public hearing.
   E.   Organization; Officers: The board shall organize, elect its chairman
and secretary and adopt rules necessary to the conduct of its affairs. (Ord.,
3-8-1971)
10-3-2: POWERS:
The board shall have the power to hear appeals from the determinations of the
building inspector in enforcing this title, to grant special exceptions, to
grant variances, and to make interpretations of the zoning map and text, in
accordance with the substantive and procedural standards hereinafter set forth.
(Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-3-3: MEETINGS AND PROCEEDINGS:
   A.   Times For Meetings: Meetings shall be held at the call of the chairman
and at such other times as the board may determine.
   B.   Administer Oaths, Compel Attendance: The chairman, or in his absence,
the acting chairman, may administer oaths and compel the attendance of
witnesses.
   C.   Meetings; Records: All meetings of the board shall be open to the
public. The board shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of
each member upon each question, or if absent or failing to vote, indicating
such fact, and shall keep records of its examinations and other official
actions, all of which shall be immediately filed in the office of the board and
shall be a public record.
   D.   Time Limit For Decisions: In all matters, the board shall decide within
thirty (30) days after the close of the hearing.
   E.   Quorum; Other Board Requirements: The quorum, notice, filing, and
substantive requirements of the board shall be as set forth in the following
sections concerning the board's exercise of a particular power. (Ord., 3-8-
1971)
10-3-4: APPEALS FROM BUILDING INSPECTOR DECISIONS:
   A.   General: An appeal to the board of adjustment may be taken by any
person aggrieved or by any officer, department, board or bureau of the city
affected, where it is alleged there is error in any determination of the
building inspector in the enforcement of this title.
   B.   Notice Of Appeal And Fees:
      1.   An appeal shall be taken within ten (10) days from the determination
of the building inspector by filing with the building inspector and with the
secretary of the board, a notice of appeal specifying the grounds thereof.
      2.   The notice of appeal shall be accompanied by the payment of a fee to
be set by the city council. Cost of notice and posting of signs shall be billed
to the appellant.
      3.   The building inspector, upon receipt of notice of appeal, shall
forthwith transmit to the secretary of the board, certified copies of all the
papers constituting the record of said matters.
   C.   Public Hearing And Notice Required:
      1.   Upon receipt of the record, the secretary shall set the matter for
public hearing and give at least fifteen (15) days' notice thereof by
publication in a newspaper of general circulation.
      2.   Where deemed necessary by the board, additional notice shall be
given by the posting of a sign or signs on the property.
      3.   Notice shall be fairly and reasonably calculated to give notice of
the nature of the proceedings and the determination appealed from.
   D.   Board Action: The board shall hold the public hearing and upon the
concurring vote of four (4) members may, so long as such action is in
conformity with the terms of this title, reverse or affirm, wholly or partly,
or may modify the order, requirement, decision, or determinations appealed from
and may make such order, requirement, decision, or determinations as ought to
be made, and to that end shall have the powers of the building inspector from
whom the appeal is taken.
   E.   Stay Of Proceedings: An appeal stays all proceedings in furtherance of
the action appealed from, unless the building inspector from whom the appeal is
taken certifies to the board of adjustment, after the notice of appeal shall
have been filed with him, that by reason of facts stated in the certificate, a
stay would in his opinion cause imminent peril to life or property. In such
case, proceedings shall not be stayed other than by a restraining order granted
by the board on due and sufficient cause shown. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-3-5: INTERPRETATION OF ZONING TEXT AND MAP:
The board of adjustment shall interpret the text of this title or the official
zoning map upon:
   A.   Appeal from the determination of the building inspector after
compliance with the procedural standards of section
10-3-4 of this chapter.
   B.   Upon written request of the building inspector.
   C.   Upon written request of the secretary of the board. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-3-6: VARIANCES:
   A.   Authority To Grant: The board of adjustment, upon application, and
after notice and public hearing, and subject to the procedural and substantive
standards hereinafter set forth, may grant such variance from the terms of this
title as will not be contrary to the public interest or to the spirit and
intent of this title, where by reason of exceptional narrowness, shallowness,
shape, topography, or other extraordinary or exceptional situation, condition,
or circumstance of a particular property, the literal enforcement of this title
will result in unnecessary hardship. Provided, nothing herein contained shall
be construed as authorization for the board to vary any jurisdictional
requirement, such as notice, or to permit by variance a use not otherwise
permitted in the applicable use district.
   B.   Application And Fees:
      1.   A request for a variance shall be initiated by the filing of an
application with the secretary of the board. An application shall be in such
form and content as the board may by resolution establish and shall be
accompanied by the payment of a fee established by the city council. Costs of
notice and posting of signs shall be billed to the applicant.
      2.   An application shall be filed with the board, and may be set for
public hearing by the secretary, in accordance with the rules established by
the board.
   C.   Notice Required: The board shall give fifteen (15) days' notice of a
public hearing on a proposed variance by publication in a newspaper of general
circulation, and where deemed necessary by the board, additional notice shall
be given by the posting of a sign or signs on the property. Notice shall be
fairly and reasonably calculated to give notice of the nature of the
proceedings and the proposed variance.
   D.   Board Action:
      1.   The board shall hold the public hearing and, upon the concurring
vote of four (4) members, may grant a variance after finding:
         a.   That by reasons of stated extraordinary or exceptional conditions
or circumstances which are peculiar to the land, structure, or building
involved, the literal enforcement of the terms of this title would result in
unnecessary hardship.
         b.   That such extraordinary or exceptional conditions or
circumstances do not apply generally to other property in the same use
district.
         c.   That the variance to be granted will be in harmony with the
spirit and intent of this title and will not be injurious to the neighborhood
or otherwise detrimental to the public welfare.
      2.   Provided, that the board, in granting a variance, shall prescribe
appropriate conditions and safeguards, and may require such evidence and
guarantee or bond as it may deem necessary to enforce compliance with the
conditions attached. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-3-7: SPECIAL EXCEPTIONS:
   A.   Conditions For Granting: The board of adjustment, upon application, and
after notice and public hearing, subject to the procedural and substantive
standards hereinafter set forth, may grant the following special exceptions:
      1.   Special exception uses as designated and regulated within the
general use districts.
      2.   Special exception uses as designated and regulated within section
10-5E-4 of this title, floodplain district regulations 1 .
      3.   The restoration of a partially destroyed nonconforming use as
provided in chapter 9 of this title.
      4.   Modification of a screening requirement.
      5.   Off street parking use of properties located within a residential
district, when such properties are abutting an office, commercial, or
industrial district.
   B.   Application And Fees:
      1.   A request for a special exception shall be initiated by the filing
of an application with the secretary of the board. An application shall be in
such form and content as the board may by resolution establish and shall be
accompanied by the payment of a fee established by the city council. Costs of
notice and posting of signs shall be billed to the applicant.
      2.   An application shall be filed with the board, and may be set for
public hearing by the secretary, in accordance with the rules of the board.
   C.   Notice Required:
      1.   The board shall give fifteen (15) days' notice of a public hearing
on a proposed special exception by publication in a newspaper of general
circulation and, where deemed necessary by the board, additional notice shall
be given by the posting of sign or signs on the property.
      2.   Notice shall be fairly and reasonably calculated to give notice of
the nature of the proceedings and the proposed special exception.
   D.   Board Action: The board of adjustment shall hold the public hearing
and, upon the concurring vote of four (4) members, may grant a special
exception after finding that the special exception will be in harmony with the
spirit and intent of this title and will not be injurious to the neighborhood
or otherwise detrimental to the public welfare. Provided that the board, in
granting a special exception, shall prescribe appropriate conditions and
safeguards, and may require such evidence and guarantee or bond as it may deem
necessary to enforce compliance with the conditions attached.
   E.   Time Limitation On Special Exceptions: A special exception which has
not been utilized within a period of two (2) years from the date of the order
granting same shall thereafter be void. For the purposes of this provision,
"utilization" shall mean the issuance of a building permit, provided
construction is diligently carried to completion. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
 
Notes
1 1. See also title 12, chapter 1 of this code.
10-3-8: APPEALS FROM BOARD DECISIONS:
   A.   Procedure:
      1.   An appeal from any action, decision, ruling, judgment, or order of
the board of adjustment may be taken by any person or persons aggrieved, or any
taxpayer or any officer, department, board or bureau of the city to the
district court by filing with the city clerk and with the secretary of the
board within ten (10) days from the date of such action, a notice of appeal,
which notice shall be required for such appeal.
      2.   Upon filing of the notice of appeal, the board shall forthwith
transmit to the court clerk of the county, the original or certified copies of
all the papers constituting the record in the case, together with the order,
decision or ruling of the board.
      3.   Said case shall be heard and tried de novo in the district court of
Seminole County, Oklahoma.
      4.   An appeal shall lie from the action of the district court as in all
other civil actions. All issues in any proceedings under this section shall
have preference over all other civil actions and proceedings, and a trial shall
be given in the district court with all reasonable expedition.
      5.   Costs shall not be allowed against the board unless it shall appear,
to the court, that it acted with gross negligence or in bad faith, or with
malice in making the decision appealed from.
   B.   Stay Of Proceedings: An appeal to the district court stays all
proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from unless the chairman of
the board certifies to the court clerk, after notice of appeal shall have been
filed, that by reason of facts stated in the certificate, a stay would cause
imminent peril of life or property. In such case, proceedings shall not be
stayed other than by a restraining order granted by the district court. (Ord.,
3-8-1971)
CHAPTER 4
ZONING DISTRICTS; MAP; GENERAL REQUIREMENTS
SECTION:
10-4-1: Zoning Districts Established
10-4-2: Official Zoning Map
10-4-3: Boundary Description And Interpretation
10-4-4: Limitation On Land Use
10-4-5: Division Of Lots
10-4-6: Number Of Dwelling Units Per Lot
10-4-7: Street Frontage Required
10-4-8: Height Exceptions
10-4-9: Lot Area And Width Modifications
10-4-10: Yards
10-4-11: Building Encroachment Into Yards Or Setbacks
10-4-12: Screening Walls Or Fences
10-4-13: Platting Requirement
10-4-1: ZONING DISTRICTS ESTABLISHED:
The zoning districts set forth below are hereby established. The district
symbol is in the column to the left.
AG   Agriculture district
RS-1 Residential single-family low density district
RS-2 Residential single-family high density district
RM   Residential multi-family district
RMH  Residential mobile home district
CC   Commercial convenience district
CG   Commercial general district
CH   Commercial highway district
CS   Commercial service district
CM   Commercial medical center district
HC   Heavy commercial district
IL   Industrial light district
IH   Industrial heavy district
FP   Floodplain district
CCF  Community-based care facility district
 
(Ord., 3-8-1971; amd. Ord. 435, 9-23-1999)
10-4-2: OFFICIAL ZONING MAP:
The locations and boundaries of the various districts as defined herein shall
be established by ordinance and shall be shown and delineated on the official
zoning map of the city. The official zoning map shall be maintained by the
planning commission of the city, and may be divided into parts, and such parts
may be separately employed for identification purposes when adopting or
amending the official zoning map or for any reference to the official zoning
map. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-4-3: BOUNDARY DESCRIPTION AND INTERPRETATION:
District boundary lines shall be described by legal description or by a map.
When a map is used, district boundary lines shall be established by dimensions,
property lines, recorded lot lines, or the centerline of abutting street, alley
or railroad rights of way, as the same were of record at the time of adoption.
In all cases where there is doubt as to the exact location of district boundary
lines, the same shall be determined by the board of adjustment. (Ord., 3-8-
1971)
10-4-4: LIMITATION ON LAND USE:
No land shall be used and no building, structure, or improvement shall be made,
erected, constructed, moved, altered, enlarged, or rebuilt which is designed,
arranged, or intended to be used or maintained for any purpose or in any manner
except in accordance with the use, height, area, yard, space, and other
requirements established in the district in which such land, building,
structure, or improvement is located, except as provided by chapter 9 of this
title. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-4-5: DIVISION OF LOTS:
An improved lot shall not hereafter be divided into two (2) or more lots,
unless all improved lots resulting from such division conform to all the
applicable bulk, area and off street parking regulations of the zoning district
in which located. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-4-6: NUMBER OF DWELLING UNITS PER LOT:
   A.   Multiple Units: Within a lot containing more than one detached
residential building, there shall not be more than forty (40) dwelling units.
   B.   Single-Family Dwellings: As applied to the use of land for single-
family dwellings, not more than one single-family dwelling may be constructed
on a lot. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-4-7: STREET FRONTAGE REQUIRED:
No lot shall contain any building used in whole or part for residential
purposes unless such lot has a minimum of thirty feet (30') of frontage on a
public street, except as provided for a substandard lot of record. (Ord., 3-8-
1971)
10-4-8: HEIGHT EXCEPTIONS:
The following structures shall not be subject to the height limitations of the
district in which they are located:
   A.   Farm buildings and structures.
   B.   Aerials, belfries, chimneys, cupolas, domes, elevators, penthouses,
flagpoles, masts, monitors, smokestacks, spires, towers (cooling, fire hose),
and ventilators; provided, that they are not intended for human occupancy.
(Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-4-9: LOT AREA AND WIDTH MODIFICATIONS:
   A.   Residential Districts: In the residential districts, a single- family
detached dwelling may be erected on any lot of official record at the effective
date hereof, irrespective of its area or width, provided the other requirements
of the use district are complied with.
   B.   Districts Other Than Residential: In districts other than residential
districts, any use permitted by right in the applicable district may be located
on any lot of official record at the effective date hereof, irrespective of its
area or width, provided the other requirements of the use district are complied
with.
   C.   Lot Area And Width; Public Protection And Utility Facilities: The lot
area and width requirements of the use districts shall not apply to the uses
included within use unit 4, public protection and utility facilities; provided,
that a minimum lot area of ten thousand (10,000) square feet and a minimum lot
width of one hundred feet (100') shall apply to fire protection facilities.
(Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-4-10: YARDS:
   A.   Compliance With Yard Requirements: Except as otherwise provided,
required yards and open spaces shall be open and unobstructed from the ground
to the sky. Yards or open spaces provided for a building, for the purpose of
complying with the provisions of this title, shall not be considered the yard
or open space for any other building, and yards or open spaces provided for a
lot shall not be considered the yard or open space of any other lot.
   B.   Permitted Yard Obstructions: Provided, that within the larger of the
required side yards of an interior or through lot, at least eight feet (8') of
horizontal clearance is maintained, unobstructed by other than a gate,
obstructions are permitted in required yards and courts as follows:
      1.   Cornices, canopies, eaves and similar architectural features may
project not more than two feet (2') into a required yard or court.
      2.   Fire escapes may project not more than four and one-half feet (41/
2') into a required yard.
      3.   Fences, hedges, plant materials and walls may be located in any
yard; provided, that corner traffic visibility is maintained.
      4.   Signs which are permitted as accessory uses in residential districts
may be located within any yard which is bounded by a public street.
      5.   In the RS districts, detached accessory buildings may be located in
a required rear yard, provided the building does not cover more than twenty
percent (20%) of the area of the minimum required rear yard.
   C.   Use Of Yards In AG And R Districts: Within the front and exterior side
yards in the AG or R districts, no inoperative or unlicensed motor vehicle
shall be stored. No vehicle shall be parked except on a hard surfaced area, and
not more than one vehicle shall be parked for each six hundred (600) square
feet of area contained in the front or exterior side yard. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-4-11: BUILDING ENCROACHMENT INTO YARDS OR SETBACKS:
   A.   Required Front Yard Or Building Setback: Where an existing building or
buildings on the same side of the street and within the same block encroach on
the required front yard or building setback, the required front yard or
building setback for new construction shall be established as follows:
      1.   If the proposed building is to be located more than two hundred feet
(200') from an encroaching building, the proposed building shall conform to the
front yard or setback established for the district in which the proposed
building is to be located.
      2.   If the proposed building is to be located between adjacent buildings
which conform to the required front yard or building setback, or between a
conforming building and an intersecting street, the proposed building shall
conform to the front yard or setback established for the district in which the
proposed building is to be located.
      3.   If the proposed building is to be located within two hundred feet
(200') of encroaching buildings on both sides and there are no intervening
buildings, the front yard or building setback shall be the average of the front
yard or setback of the two (2) nearest front corners of the encroaching
buildings.
      4.   If the proposed building is to be located within two hundred feet
(200') of an encroaching building on one side, and there are no intervening
buildings, the front yard or building setback shall be the average of the
otherwise required front yard or setback and the setback of the nearest front
corner of the encroaching building.
   B.   Reduction In Size: Provided, however, that in the application of
subsection A3 or A4 of this section, the front yard or building setback shall
not be reduced to less than five feet (5') plus one-half (1/2) of the right of
way width designated on the major street plan for the abutting street, or five
feet (5') plus twenty five feet (25') if the street is not designated on the
major street plan. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-4-12: SCREENING WALLS OR FENCES:
   A.   Specifications: When the provisions of this title require the
construction of a screening wall or fence as a condition for the initiation and
subsequent continuance of a use, the screening wall or fence:
      1.   Shall be constructed, designed, and arranged to provide visual
separation of uses, irrespective of vegetation.
      2.   Shall not be less than five feet (5') in height.
      3.   Shall be constructed with all braces and supports on the interior.
   B.   Maintenance: The screening wall or fence shall be maintained by the
owner of the zoning lot containing the use requiring the construction of the
screening. Failure to maintain after notice by the building inspector shall
constitute an offense hereunder.
   C.   Modification Of Requirements: Under the provisions of section
10-3-7 of this title, the board of adjustment may grant special exceptions to
the screening wall or fence requirements. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-4-13: PLATTING REQUIREMENT:
For the purposes of providing a proper arrangement of streets and assuring the
adequacy of open spaces for traffic, utilities, and access of emergency
vehicles, commensurate with the intensification of land use customarily
incident to a change of zoning, a platting requirement is established as
follows:
For any land which has been rezoned upon application of a private party, no
building permit shall be issued until that portion of the tract on which the
permit is sought has been included within a subdivision plat or replat, as the
case may be, submitted to and approved by the planning commission, and filed of
record in the office of the county clerk where the property is situated.
Provided that the planning commission, pursuant to their exclusive jurisdiction
of subdivision plats, may remove the platting requirement upon a determination
that the above stated purposes have been achieved by previous platting and that
a replat identical to the existing plat would be approved if submitted to the
planning commission. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
CHAPTER 5
DISTRICT REGULATIONS
ARTICLE A. AGRICULTURE DISTRICT
SECTION:
10-5A-1: Purposes
10-5A-2: Principal Uses
10-5A-3: Accessory Uses
10-5A-4: Bulk And Area Requirements
10-5A-5: Special Exception Uses
10-5A-1: PURPOSES:
   A.   General: The agriculture district is designed to:
      1.   Protect agricultural land until an orderly transition to urban
development has been accomplished.
      2.   Discourage wasteful scattering of development in rural areas.
      3.   Obtain economy of public fund expenditures for improvements and
services.
      4.   Promote stability of neighborhoods.
      5.   Prevent unsightly development.
      6.   Increase scenic attractiveness.
      7.   Conserve open space.
   B.   AG Agriculture District: The AG agriculture district is designed to
preserve and protect agricultural land yet provide for the orderly transition
of those portions of agricultural land which will ultimately be developed as
urban or industrial areas. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-5A-2: PRINCIPAL USES:
The principal uses permitted in the agriculture district are designated by use
units. The use units are groupings of individual uses and are fully described,
including their respective off street parking, screening requirements and other
use conditions in chapter 7 of this title. The use units permitted in the
agriculture district are set forth in table 1 of this section.
   TABLE 1
   USE UNITS PERMITTED IN AGRICULTURE DISTRICT

(Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-5A-3: ACCESSORY USES:
   A.   Accessory Uses Permitted: Accessory uses customarily incident to a
principal use permitted in an agriculture district are permitted in such
district. In addition, the uses set forth in table 2 of this section are
permitted as accessory uses.
   TABLE 2
   ACCESSORY USES PERMITTED IN AGRICULTURE DISTRICT
 
   Uses                 Districts

2. Identification signs AG
3. Real estate signs    AG
 
   B.   Accessory Use Conditions:
      1.   General Conditions:
         a.   An accessory building erected as an integral part of the
principal building shall be made structurally a part thereof, shall have a
common wall therewith, and shall comply with the requirements applicable to the
principal building.
         b.   Accessory buildings shall meet the minimum yard or building
setback requirements of the applicable district.
         c.   A detached accessory building shall be located at least six feet
(6') from any dwelling.
      2.   Signs:
         a.   One bulletin board may be erected on each street frontage of an
educational, religious, institutional, or similar use requiring announcement of
its activities. The bulletin board shall not exceed twelve (12) square feet in
surface area nor fifteen feet (15') in height; and illumination, if any, shall
be constant light.
         b.   One identification sign may be erected on each street frontage of
a single-family subdivision or permitted nonresidential use. The sign shall not
exceed twelve (12) square feet in surface area, nor fifteen feet (15') in
height; and illumination, if any, shall be by constant light.
         c.   During the period of construction, a real estate sign advertising
the sale, rental, or lease of the premises may be erected on each street
frontage of the development. The sign shall not exceed eighty (80) square feet
in surface area, nor fifteen feet (15') in height, and illumination, if any,
shall be by constant light. (Ord., 3-8-1971)

10-5A-5: SPECIAL EXCEPTION USES:
The special exception uses permitted in the agriculture district as designated
in table 1, section
10-5A-2 of this article, are subject to the following requirements:
   A.   Signs: The accessory use provisions of the agriculture district
pertaining to signs are applicable to accessory signs for uses permitted by
special exception.
   B.   Minimum Tract Size; Frontage: A minimum tract size of ten thousand
(10,000) square feet and a minimum frontage of one hundred feet (100') are
requirements of the special exception uses unless the use unit requirements are
more restrictive, in which case the more restrictive shall control.
   C.   Bulk And Area: Special exception uses, except as provided in subsection
B of this section, shall conform to the bulk and area requirements of the use
district in which located. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
ARTICLE B. RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS
SECTION:
10-5B-1: Purposes
10-5B-2: Principal Uses
10-5B-3: Accessory Uses
10-5B-4: Bulk And Area Requirements
10-5B-5: Special Exception Uses
10-5B-1: PURPOSES:
   A.   General: The residential districts are designed to:
      1.   Achieve the residential objectives of the comprehensive plan.
      2.   Protect the character of residential areas by excluding inharmonious
commercial and industrial activities.
      3.   Achieve a suitable environment for family life by permitting in
residential areas appropriate neighborhood facilities, such as churches,
schools, and certain cultural, and recreational facilities.
      4.   Preserve openness of the living areas and avoid overcrowding by
requiring minimum yards, open spaces, lot areas, and by limiting the bulk of
structures.
      5.   Permit a variety of dwelling types and densities to meet the varying
needs of families.
      6.   Control the density of residential development to facilitate the
planning for and economical provision of streets, utilities, and other public
facilities.
   B.   RS Residential Single-Family Districts: The RS-1 and RS-2 districts are
designed to permit the development and conservation of single-family detached
dwellings in suitable environments in a variety of densities to meet the
varying requirements of families.
   C.   RM Residential Multi-Family District: The RM district is designed to
permit the development of multi-family dwellings and similar high density
residential dwellings.
   D.   RMH Residential Mobile Home Park District: The RMH district is designed
to recognize mobile home living as a unique residential use necessitating
location in residential areas yet requiring unique regulation to ensure a
suitable living environment. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-5B-2: PRINCIPAL USES:
The principal uses permitted in the residential districts are designated by use
unit. The use units are groupings of individual uses and are fully described,
including their respective off street parking, and screening requirements and
other use conditions in chapter 7 of this title. The use units permitted in
residential districts are set forth in table 1 of this section
   TABLE 1
   USE UNITS PERMITTED IN RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS
No.    Use Units NaDistricts
                      RS RM RMH
No.    Use Units Name                                      Districts
                                                              RS RM RMH
1.  Areawide uses by right                                    X  X  X
2.  Areawide special exception uses                           E  E  E
4.  Public protection and utility facilities                  E  E  E
5.  Community services, cultural, and recreational facilities E  E  E
6.  Single-family dwelling                                    X  X   
7.  Duplex dwelling                                           E  X   
8.  Multi-family dwelling and similar uses                      X   
9.  Mobile home dwelling                                      E  E  X
 
   X = use by right
    E = special exception
 
(Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-5B-3: ACCESSORY USES:
   A.   Accessory Uses Permitted By Right: Accessory uses customarily incident
to a principal use permitted in a residential district are permitted in such
district. In addition, the following uses set forth in table 2 of this section
are permitted as accessory uses:
   TABLE 2
   ACCESSORY USES PERMITTED IN RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS
 
   Uses                   Districts
   
1. Roomers and boarders All R districts
2. Shelters             All R districts
   Signs:
3. Bulletin board       All R districts
   Identification sign
   Real estate
4. Swimming pool        All R districts
 
   B.   Accessory Use Conditions:
      1.   General Conditions:
         a.   An accessory building erected as an integral part of the
principal building shall be made structurally a part thereof, shall have a
common wall therewith, and shall comply with the requirements applicable to the
principal building.
         b.   A detached accessory building shall not be located in the front
or side yard or encroach upon a minimum building setback line; but, this
limitation shall not apply to carports, provided the minimum required front
yard or side yard or setback line is observed. If on a corner lot, the
accessory building shall not project in front of the front building line
required or existing on the adjacent lots.
         c.   A detached accessory building shall be located at least six feet
(6') from any dwelling, and at least three feet (3') from any interior lot
line.
      2.   Roomers And Boarders: In a dwelling unit occupied as a private
residence, one or more rooms may be rented or table board be furnished, to not
exceeding four (4) persons not members of the family occupying said premises,
provided no window display or sign board is used to advertise such use.
      3.   Signs:
         a.   One bulletin board may be erected on each street frontage of an
educational, religious, institutional, or similar use requiring announcement of
its activities. The bulletin board shall not exceed twelve (12) square feet in
surface area, nor fifteen feet (15') in height; and illumination, if any, shall
be by constant light.
         b.   One identification sign may be erected on each street frontage of
a multi-family development, single-family subdivision or permitted
nonresidential use. The sign shall not exceed twelve (12) square feet in
surface area, nor fifteen feet (15') in height; and illumination, if any, shall
be by constant light.
         c.   During the period of construction, a real estate sign advertising
the sale, rental, or lease of the premises may be erected on each street
frontage of the development. The sign shall not exceed eighty (80) square feet
in surface area, nor fifteen feet (15') in height; and illumination if any,
shall be by constant light.
   C.   Home Occupations; Special Exception:
      1.   General Conditions; Definitions: A person occupying a dwelling as
his private residence, upon being granted a special exception by the board of
adjustment as provided in chapter 3 of this title, may engage in one of the
following customary home occupations:
Beauty shop or barbershop having only one chair.
Sewing and clothing alterations.
Small appliances repair such as toasters, fans, vacuum cleaners, sewing
machines.
Small arms repair.
Teaching private music, voice, instrumental or art lessons.
Giving private art lessons.
Tutoring.
And; provided, that the following requirements are complied with:
         a.   Home occupations, collectively, shall not occupy more than thirty
percent (30%) of the gross floor area of one floor of the dwelling unit, or
more than three hundred (300) square feet, whichever is smaller.
         b.   No exterior alterations of the structure shall be made which
would detract from the residential character of the structure.
         c.   No signs, display or advertising shall be permitted.
         d.   No person shall be employed in the home occupation other than a
member of the immediate family residing on the premises.
         e.   No mechanical equipment shall be used which creates a noise,
dust, odor, or electrical disturbance.
Merchandising, such as a shop or store, radio or television repair, beauty shop
or barbershop having more than one chair, offices for the treatment of
patients, or the regular caring for five (5) or more children not members of
the immediate family, shall not be permitted as a home occupation, either by
right or by special exception.
      2.   Off Street Parking: Any off street parking shall be hardstand,
neatly constructed and maintained. (Ord. 398, 3-10-1992)

10-5B-5: SPECIAL EXCEPTION USES:
The special exception uses, permitted in the residential districts, as
designated in table 1, section
10-5B-2 of this article, are subject to the following requirements:
   A.   Signs: The accessory use provisions of the residential districts
pertaining to signs are applicable to accessory signs for uses permitted by
special exception.
   B.   Duplex Use: In the RS districts, duplex use shall comply with the
height, yard, and livability space requirements for single- family use and in
addition shall comply with the following requirements:
      1.   Minimum lot area of nine thousand (9,000) square feet.
      2.   Minimum land area per dwelling unit of five thousand (5,000) square
feet.
      3.   Minimum frontage of seventy five feet (75').
      4.   Livability space per dwelling unit of two thousand five hundred
(2,500) square feet.
   C.   Mobile Home Use: Mobile home use where permitted by special exception
shall comply with the single-family bulk and area requirements of the
residential district in which located.
   D.   Children's Nurseries: In the RS districts, children's nurseries shall
comply with the lot width, lot area, height and yard requirements for single-
family use and in addition, a floor area ratio of 0.5 shall apply.
   E.   Yard And Height Requirements: Except as provided in subsections B, C
and D of this section, and subs
10-4-9C of this title, special exception uses shall comply with the least
restrictive yard and height requirements of the district in which located and
in addition, shall comply with the following requirements:
      1.   Maximum floor area ratio of 0.5.
      2.   Minimum lot size of ten thousand (10,000) square feet.
      3.   Minimum frontage of one hundred feet (100').
      4.   A minimum building setback of twenty five feet (25') from adjoining
property lines in the RS districts.
Provided, that if the use unit requirements are greater, the use unit
requirements shall control.
   F.   Outdoor Lighting: All outdoor lighting facilities shall be shaded to
prevent glare being cast on any residential district. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
ARTICLE C. COMMERCIAL DISTRICTS
SECTION:
10-5C-1: Purposes
10-5C-2: Principal Uses
10-5C-3: Accessory Uses
10-5C-4: Bulk And Area Requirements
10-5C-5: Special Exception Uses
10-5C-6: Retail Liquor, Mixed Beverage And Beer Establishments
10-5C-1: PURPOSES:
   A.   General: The commercial districts are designed to:
      1.   Achieve the commercial objectives of the comprehensive plan.
      2.   Meet the needs for commercial services and goods of the Wewoka trade
area.
      3.   Develop sound, efficient, and stable commercial areas and to
minimize the adverse effects of commercial uses on other land uses and
thoroughfares, by:
         a.   Differentiating the types and purposes of commercial activities.
         b.   Establishing bulk and area controls to minimize congestion and
encourage compatibility with adjoining districts.
         c.   Requiring off street parking facilities to minimize and
facilitate traffic flow.
         d.   Controlling the number, area, location, and types of signs.
         e.   Protecting the character of commercial districts and their
peculiar suitability for commercial uses.
   B.   CC Commercial Convenience District: The CC district is designed to
accommodate convenience and neighborhood shopping centers, providing a limited
range of retail and personal service uses.
   C.   CG General Commercial District: The CG district is designed to
accommodate existing developments of mixed commercial uses which are well
established, while providing a degree of protection to adjacent residential
areas.
   D.   CH Commercial Highway District: The commercial highway district is
designed to:
      1.   Accommodate the commercial and related uses needed along the
highway.
      2.   Accommodate the grouping of certain commercial uses that are not
compatible with uses in the general commercial district.
   E.   CS Commercial Service District: The CS district is designed to:
      1.   Accommodate certain retail trade and service uses that are not
compatible with uses in other commercial districts.
      2.   Accommodate the grouping of certain commercial uses that are
recognized as having peculiar needs in terms of land area and location.
   F.   CM Commercial Medical Center District: The CM district is designed to
accommodate medical and dental offices and laboratories and certain other
compatible and supporting uses adjacent to the hospital.
   G.   HC Heavy Commercial District: The HC district is designed to:
      1.   Accommodate certain retail and wholesale trade and service
establishments that are not compatible with uses in other commercial districts.
      2.   Accommodate the grouping of certain commercial uses that are
recognized as having specific needs in terms of land area, location, and
accessibility. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-5C-2: PRINCIPAL USES:
The principal uses permitted in the commercial districts are designated by use
units. The use units are groupings of individual uses and are fully described,
including their respective off street parking and screening requirements and
other use conditions in chapter 7 of this title. The use units permitted in
commercial districts are set forth in table 1 of this section:
   TABLE 1

   A.   Accessory Uses Permitted: Accessory uses customarily incident to a

district.
   B.   Accessory Use Conditions:

the applicable district.
      2.   An accessory building erected as an integral part of the principal
building shall be made structurally a part thereof, shall have a common wall
therewith, and shall comply with the requirements applicable to the principal
building.
      3.   Signs in the commercial districts, whether accessory or principal
uses, are subject to the use conditions of use unit 22. (Ord., 3-8-1971)

district in which located. (Ord., 3-8-1971)

or commercial service zoning district, except that no special exception shall
be required for the location for which a special event license is issued under
section

ARTICLE D. INDUSTRIAL DISTRICTS
SECTION:
10-5D-1: Purposes
10-5D-2: Principal Uses
10-5D-3: Accessory Uses
10-5D-4: Bulk And Area Requirements
10-5D-5: Special Exception Uses
10-5D-1: PURPOSES:
   A.   General: The industrial districts are designed to:
      1.   Achieve the industrial objectives of the comprehensive plan.
      2.   Meet the needs for industrial services and goods of the Wewoka trade
area.
      3.   Develop sound, efficient, and stable industrial areas and minimize
the adverse effects of industrial uses on other land uses and thoroughfares by:
         a.   Differentiating the types and purposes of industrial activities.
         b.   Establishing bulk and area controls to minimize congestion and
encourage compatibility with adjoining districts.
         c.   Requiring off street loading and parking facilities to minimize
and facilitate traffic flow.
         d.   Controlling the number, area, location, and types of signs.
         e.   Protecting the character of industrial districts and their
peculiar suitability for industrial uses.
   B.   IL Light Industrial District: The IL district is designed to provide
areas suitable for manufacturing, wholesaling, warehousing, and other
industrial activities which have no objectionable environmental influences.
   C.   IH Heavy Industrial District: The IH district is designed to provide
areas for manufacturing and other industrial activities which may constitute
substantial environmental influences or hazards. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
10-5D-2: PRINCIPAL USES:
The principal uses permitted in the industrial districts are designated by use
units. The use units are groupings of individual uses and are fully described,
including their respective off street parking, loading, and screening
requirements, and other use conditions in chapter 7 of this title. The use
units permitted in the industrial districts are set forth in table 1 of this
section:

   A.   Accessory Uses Permitted: Accessory uses customarily incident to a

   B.   Accessory Use Conditions:
      1.   Accessory buildings shall meet the minimum building setback lines of
the applicable district.
      2.   An accessory building erected as an integral part of the principal
building shall be structurally a part thereof, shall have a common wall
therewith, and shall comply with the requirements applicable to the principal
building.
      3.   Accessory storage of materials, equipment, or products, within two
hundred feet (200') of an adjoining R or AG district shall be screened by the
erection of a screening wall or fence along the lot line or lines in common
with the adjoining R or AG district. (Ord., 3-8-1971)
